choices.text: IV fluids and antibiotics followed by laparotomy

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, fever, nausea, vomiting, and difficulty breathing. His blood pressure is 80/40 mmHg, and pulse rate is 115/min. A chest X-ray taken on arrival is as shown below. What should be the immediate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IV fluids and antibiotics followed by laparotomy

 

  • This patient has peritonitis with shock, most likely due to hollow viscus perforation as indicated by free air under the diaphragm on chest X-ray.
  • Initial stabilization with intravenous fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics is essential before proceeding to emergency laparotomy to correct the underlying cause.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CECT abdomen: CECT may be done in a stable patient, if there is diagnostic doubt.

 

Option C. Wait and watch: Antibiotics and definitive surgical intervention are also required to control sepsis and source of peritonitis.

 

Option D. Intravenous potassium: Potassium replacement is not an immediate priority here. In fact, aggressive potassium infusion in shock without laboratory confirmation of hypokalemia can be dangerous. The priority is resuscitation, infection control, and surgical management.

 

Educational Objective:


In cases of peritonitis with hollow viscus perforation, immediate management involves resuscitation with IV fluids and antibiotics, followed by emergency laparotomy to treat the source of infection.

choices.text: Police should cut and remove clothing at the scene
Clothing should be removed during embalming
Doctor should remove, examine, seal, and document clothing during autopsy
Clothing is irrelevant if there are no visible injuries

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate way to handle the deceased's clothing during a custodial death investigation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Doctor should remove, examine, seal, and document clothing during autopsy

 

  • In custodial death investigations, clothing is a vital piece of forensic evidence. 
  • It may show signs of trauma (bloodstains, tears, bullet holes, or fabric impressions) and must be preserved in its original state for accurate assessment.
  • The doctor performing the autopsy is solely responsible for:
    • Careful removal of clothing without damaging potential evidence
    • Detailed documentation of each item
    • Descriptive notes on any stains, tears, or markings
    • Sealing and preservation of clothing for forensic laboratory analysis
  • According to NHRC guidelines, police or non-medical personnel must not remove or tamper with the deceased’s clothing. 
  • Improper handling can compromise evidence and obstruct justice in cases involving alleged custodial abuse.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Police should cut and remove clothing at the scene: Incorrect. Police are not trained for forensic handling and must not interfere with potential evidence. Cutting or prematurely removing clothes can destroy critical signs of trauma or contamination patterns.

 

Option B. Clothing should be removed during embalming: Incorrect. Embalming occurs after the autopsy and is not part of forensic evaluation. Removing clothing at this stage is too late to preserve trace evidence and can result in evidence degradation.

 

Option D. Clothing is irrelevant if there are no visible injuries: Incorrect. Absence of visible injuries does not rule out trauma or foul play. Clothing may contain microscopic blood splatter, gunshot residue, or pressure marks that are vital in legal investigations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In custodial death cases, only the autopsy doctor should remove, examine, and preserve the deceased’s clothing in a controlled, documented manner, as clothing is considered crucial forensic evidence.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman reports patchy discoloration of the skin over her shoulders and upper chest for the past few months. The lesions appear as hypopigmented macules with fine scaling, and she notices they become more obvious after spending time in the sun. A KOH preparation of skin scrapings is as shown below. Which organism is the most likely cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Malassezia species

 

  • Pityriasis (Tinea) versicolor is a superficial fungal infection caused by Malassezia species, a lipophilic yeast that is part of the normal skin flora.
  • Under certain conditions (e.g., humidity, excessive sweating, immunosuppression), it can overgrow and cause characteristic hypopigmented, hyperpigmented, or erythematous macules with fine scaling.
  • KOH mount finding: Classic "spaghetti and meatballs" appearance, due to the presence of hyphae and yeast cells.
  • Wood’s lamp examination: Shows yellow-gold fluorescence.
  • Treatment: Topical antifungals (selenium sulfide, ketoconazole), or oral antifungals in extensive cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichophyton rubrum: A dermatophyte causing tinea corporis, tinea pedis, and onychomycosis but does not show spaghetti and meatballs appearance.

 

Option B. Microsporum canis: A dermatophyte associated with tinea capitis, fluoresces under Wood’s lamp, but does not match the description of pityriasis versicolor.

 

Option D. Epidermophyton floccosum: Causes tinea cruris and tinea pedis, not associated with Malassezia or KOH findings in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Malassezia species cause pityriasis versicolor, characterized by hypopigmented or hyperpigmented macules and KOH mount showing the "spaghetti and meatballs" appearance.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man with a prior diagnosis of vitiligo presents with new depigmented macules that have appeared along linear areas where he sustained minor abrasions a few weeks earlier. The lesions follow the sites of trauma and show no associated scaling or inflammation. This clinical presentation is most consistent with which phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Koebner phenomenon

 

  • The Koebner phenomenon (also called the isomorphic response) is the appearance of new skin lesions of a pre-existing dermatosis at the site of trauma.
  • It is seen in conditions such as vitiligo, psoriasis, and lichen planus.
  • In this vignette, the patient with vitiligo developed new depigmented patches precisely at the sites of minor scratches, which is characteristic of the Koebner phenomenon.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Darier’s sign: Incorrect. Darier’s sign is seen in urticaria pigmentosa (cutaneous mastocytosis). Stroking the lesion causes localized urticaria and erythema due to mast cell degranulation. It does not explain the development of depigmented patches after trauma in vitiligo.

 

Option C. Nikolsky sign: Incorrect. Nikolsky sign refers to epidermal shearing and blister formation when lateral pressure is applied to intact skin. It is a feature of condition like pemphigus vulgaris, not vitiligo.

 

Option D. Auspitz sign: Incorrect. Auspitz sign is the appearance of pinpoint bleeding spots when psoriatic scales are scraped off. It is a diagnostic clue for psoriasis, not for vitiligo or trauma-induced depigmentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Koebner phenomenon is the appearance of new lesions at sites of trauma and is seen in conditions such as vitiligo, psoriasis, and lichen planus.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents for evaluation after three consecutive first-trimester pregnancy losses. She has no chronic medical illnesses and her cycles are regular. Which of the following investigations is most likely to help identify the cause of her recurrent pregnancy loss?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Testing for antiphospholipid antibodies

 

Recurrent pregnancy loss (RPL) — defined as three consecutive first-trimester losses in this case — is most often due to:

  • Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APLA) → the most obvious cause of recurrent first-trimester losses, especially three consecutive losses
  • Endocrine disorders (particularly thyroid) → also important in first-trimester losses
  • Anatomical defects → think of these more in second-trimester losses or early preterm labor

 

While both APLA and thyroid should be considered for recurrent first-trimester losses, APLA is the better answer when you have to choose between options, particularly with three consecutive first-trimester losses.

 

TORCH infection testing is NOT useful in RPL because TORCH infections would cause very significant and obvious signs in a previous fetus/fetal loss but do not cause recurrent pregnancy losses.

 

TORCH is completely separate from RPL workup and should be ruled out.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hysteroscopy: Think of this in patients with second-trimester loss or early preterm labor, when suspecting anatomical problems like anomalies or space-occupying lesions (fibroids).

 

Option B. Thyroid function tests: Important for recurrent first-trimester losses as endocrine causes matter, though APLA would be the more obvious cause with three losses.

 

Option D. Testing for TORCH infections: TORCH will usually not cause RPL. TORCH would cause very significant, very obvious signs especially in a previous fetal loss, but not recurrent losses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Workup for recurrent first-trimester losses should focus on APLA as the most likely cause, though endocrine (thyroid) evaluation is also important. TORCH testing is out - it does not cause recurrent pregnancy losses. Hysteroscopy is more appropriate for second-trimester losses or suspected anatomical problems.

questions.text: A researcher is studying mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation. She adds a compound to isolated mitochondria that specifically blocks the transport of ADP into the mitochondrial matrix and ATP out into the cytosol by inhibiting the adenine nucleotide translocase (ANT) of the inner mitochondrial membrane. Which of the following agents produces this effect?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atractyloside

 

  • Atractyloside is a plant-derived toxin that inhibits the adenine nucleotide translocase (ANT), an antiporter in the inner mitochondrial membrane responsible for exchanging cytosolic ADP with mitochondrial ATP.
  • Inhibition of ANT prevents ADP from entering the mitochondrial matrix, which halts ATP synthesis because the ATP synthase (complex V) requires ADP as a substrate. 
  • As ATP cannot be exported and ADP cannot be imported, oxidative phosphorylation is effectively stopped even if the electron transport chain remains functional.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oligomycin: Incorrect.Oligomycin inhibits ATP synthase (Complex V) directly, blocking proton flow through it. This stops ATP synthesis but does not inhibit the ADP/ATP exchange transporter.

 

Option C. Rotenone: Incorrect. Rotenone inhibits Complex I (NADH dehydrogenase) of the electron transport chain, preventing electron transfer from NADH to ubiquinone, halting ATP production at an upstream step.

 

Option D. Cyanide: Incorrect. Cyanide inhibits Complex IV (cytochrome c oxidase), preventing reduction of oxygen to water and shutting down electron transport completely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atractyloside inhibits the adenine nucleotide translocase in the inner mitochondrial membrane, preventing ADP import into the mitochondrial matrix and ATP export to the cytosol, thereby halting oxidative phosphorylation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with non-cystic fibrosis bronchiectasis has recurrent pulmonary exacerbations despite standard antimicrobial therapy. He is started on a long-term, low-dose antibiotic regimen primarily for its additional anti-inflammatory and immunomodulatory properties beyond its antimicrobial effects. Which of the following antibiotics is most appropriate in this setting?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Macrolides

 

  • Antimicrobial action: Bind the 50S ribosomal subunit, blocking translocation.
  • Immunomodulatory effects: Robust and clinically exploited—macrolides reduce neutrophil chemotaxis, inhibit pro‑inflammatory cytokines (IL‑8, TNF‑α), decrease mucus production, and modulate biofilm formation. 
  • These properties underpin their use in chronic airway diseases (e.g., diffuse panbronchiolitis, cystic fibrosis, non‑CF bronchiectasis) to improve symptoms and reduce exacerbations, independent of direct antimicrobial activity.
  • Talrolimus is also a chemically similar to macrolides 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tetracyclines:

 

  • Antimicrobial action: Inhibit the 30S ribosomal subunit, blocking bacterial protein synthesis.
  • Immunomodulatory effects: Tetracyclines (especially doxycycline and minocycline) do exhibit some anti‑inflammatory actions—matrix metalloproteinase inhibition, suppression of microglial activation, and reduced cytokine release—but these are more niche and less consistently leveraged clinically than with macrolides.

 

Option B. Polypeptide antibiotics:

 

  • Polypeptide antibiotics (e.g., polymyxins, bacitracin).
  • Antimicrobial action: Disrupt bacterial cell membranes (polymyxins) or inhibit cell wall synthesis (bacitracin).
  • Immunomodulatory effects: They lack meaningful systemic anti‑inflammatory or immunomodulatory properties; their toxicity profile (nephrotoxicity, neurotoxicity) limits any off‑target benefits.

 

Option C. Fluoroquinolones:

 

  • Antimicrobial action: Inhibit bacterial DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV.
  • Immunomodulatory effects: Some in vitro data suggest fluoroquinolones can modulate cytokine production, but these effects are weak, inconsistent, and overshadowed by safety concerns (e.g., tendinopathy). They are not used clinically for immunomodulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While several antibiotics exert minor anti‑inflammatory effects, macrolides (e.g., azithromycin, clarithromycin) are uniquely leveraged for their immunomodulatory benefits in chronic respiratory diseases, beyond their antimicrobial roles.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man from Chennai, with no alcohol use, presents with several months of epigastric pain relieved by food, nausea, and no gastrointestinal bleeding. Endoscopy reveals a duodenal ulcer, and testing confirms H. pylori infection. He has never received prior eradication therapy. Which of the following is not an appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) PPI, amoxicillin, levofloxacin for 14 days

 

  • H. pylori Eradication Therapy: Initial treatment for H. pylori infection requires a regimen with high eradication rates, typically involving a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) or vonoprazan combined with two antibiotics for 10–14 days, tailored to local resistance patterns in regions like Chennai.
  • The image provides possible first-line regimens, including: 
    • Optimized BQT: PPI  + bismuth subsalicylate or subcitrate + tetracycline + metronidazole for 14 days.
    • BQT: PPI + bismuth subcitrate + tetracycline + metronidazole for 10 days.
    • Rifabutin-amoxicillin-PPI triple: PPI + rifabutin + amoxicillin for 14 days.
    • Vonoprazan-amoxicillin dual: Vonoprazan + amoxicillin for 14 days.
    • Vonoprazan-amoxicillin-clarithromycin triple: Vonoprazan + amoxicillin + clarithromycin for 14 days.
  • However, PPI, amoxicillin, and levofloxacin for 14 days is NOT recommended as a first-line treatment by current guidelines (e.g., Maastricht V/Florence Consensus, 2017) due to the rapid development of fluoroquinolone resistance, especially in India. It is typically reserved for rescue therapy after failure of first-line regimens, making it inappropriate as an initial option.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vonoprazan, amoxicillin for 14 days: Appropriate as a first-line dual therapy in specific high-dose regimens or regions with high clarithromycin resistance.

 

Option B. Vonoprazan, amoxicillin, clarithromycin for 14 days: A standard first-line triple therapy, effective where clarithromycin resistance is low.

 

Option C. Vonoprazan, amoxicillin, rifabutin for 14 days: Suitable as a first-line option in areas with high resistance to other antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Levofloxacin-based triple therapy is not a first-line H. pylori treatment due to fluoroquinolone resistance.
  • First-line regimens include bismuth quadruple, rifabutin triple, vonoprazan dual, or triple therapies, tailored to local resistance.
  • Preserving levofloxacin for rescue therapy maintains future treatment efficacy.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe hyperkalemia confirmed on laboratory testing. ECG shows peaked T waves. Which of the following interventions can be used in the management of his condition? 

 

  1. Intravenous sodium bicarbonate
  2. Intravenous calcitonin
  3. Oral sodium polystyrene sulfonate
  4. Intravenous calcium gluconate
questions.solution:
Ans. B) I, III, and IV

 

Severe hyperkalemia is a life-threatening condition requiring immediate intervention to stabilize cardiac membranes, shift potassium into cells, and remove potassium from the body.

 

Statement I. Intravenous sodium bicarbonate: Helps shift potassium into cells, especially in the setting of metabolic acidosis.

 

Statement III. Oral sodium polystyrene sulfonate: Removes potassium from the body by binding it in the gut.

 

Statement IV. Intravenous calcium gluconate: Is used to stabilize the myocardial membrane and prevent arrhythmias.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement II. Intravenous calcitonin: This is not used in hyperkalemia management; it is primarily indicated for acute treatment of hypercalcemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of severe hyperkalemia involves cardiac stabilization (calcium gluconate), shifting potassium into cells (e.g., insulin/glucose, sodium bicarbonate), and potassium elimination (e.g., sodium polystyrene sulfonate, diuretics, dialysis).

questions.text: A newly developed lipophilic drug has an apparent volume of distribution (Vd) of 6 L/kg. Which of the following best describes the distribution characteristics of this medication?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sequestered extensively in body tissues

 

  • An apparent volume of distribution (Vd) significantly greater than total body water (> 0.6 L/kg) indicates that the drug extensively leaves the plasma and accumulates in tissues. 
  • This usually occurs because the drug is lipophilic or binds strongly to tissue proteins and fats, reducing plasma concentration and increasing calculated Vd.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Confined to vascular compartment: Drugs restricted to the vascular space have a very low Vd (~0.04 L/kg), such as those bound to large plasma proteins, which is opposite of the high Vd in this case.

 

Option B. Highly bound to plasma proteins: High plasma protein binding keeps the drug in the bloodstream, leading to low Vd, which does not match the finding of 6 L/kg.

 

Option D. Rapidly eliminated via kidneys: Renal elimination rate depends on drug filtration, secretion, reabsorption, and metabolism, not directly on Vd. High Vd drugs are often less available in plasma for immediate renal clearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A high apparent volume of distribution (Vd) indicates extensive tissue sequestration, often due to lipophilicity or strong tissue binding, rather than confinement to the plasma or rapid renal elimination.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with chronic liver disease presents with confusion and altered mental status, suspected to be due to hepatic encephalopathy. The elevated ammonia levels are normally detoxified through transamination and subsequent entry into the urea cycle. However, not all amino acids can undergo transamination. Which of the following amino acids cannot undergo transamination?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lysine

 

  • Transamination: Transfer of an amino group from an amino acid to α-ketoglutarate (or oxaloacetate), forming a new amino acid + a new keto acid.
  • Enzyme: Aminotransferase (transaminase), requires pyridoxal phosphate (Vitamin B6).
  • Most amino acids can participate, except:
    • Lysine 
    • Threonine 
    • Proline

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alanine:

 

  • Undergoes transamination via alanine aminotransferase (ALT).
  • Converts alanine + α-KG → pyruvate + glutamate.

 

Option B. Aspartate:

 

  • Transaminated by aspartate transaminase (AST).
  • Forms oxaloacetate + glutamate.

 

Option D. Glutamate:

 

  • Both a product and donor in transamination reactions.
  • Central to nitrogen handling in the liver and brain.

 

 Educational Objective:

 

  • Lysine and a few other amino acids (threonine, proline) do not undergo transamination, making them exceptions in nitrogen metabolism.
  • Recognizing these exceptions is crucial in understanding hepatic encephalopathy and amino acid metabolism disorders.

choices.text: Apixaban for 3 months, then reassess for ongoing anticoagulation

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes presents with left lower extremity pain and swelling. D-dimer is 1200 ng/mL, and ultrasound confirms a popliteal vein DVT. She has no known risk factors or provoking events. Cancer screening is unremarkable. What is the most appropriate anticoagulation approach?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Apixaban for 3 months, then reassess for ongoing anticoagulation

 

  • Unprovoked DVT requires 3 months of anticoagulation (e.g., apixaban).
  • Reassessment after 3 months evaluates recurrence risk versus bleeding risk.
  • No identifiable triggers suggest a higher recurrence risk, warranting careful follow-up.
  • Compression stockings aid symptom relief but are not primary therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Apixaban for 4 weeks: Too short; used for provoked DVTs (e.g., post-surgery).

 

Option C. Lifelong apixaban: Reserved for recurrent DVTs or high-risk conditions (e.g., hereditary thrombophilia).

 

Option D. No anticoagulation; compression stockings only: Inadequate to prevent pulmonary embolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Unprovoked DVT requires 3 months of anticoagulation with reassessment.
  • Apixaban is a first-line direct oral anticoagulant.
  • Compression stockings support but do not replace anticoagulation.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with breast cancer is scheduled to receive high-dose cisplatin chemotherapy. She requires prophylaxis against chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV). However, she has a history of congenital long QT syndrome. Which antiemetic would be both effective and safe in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aprepitant (NK-1 receptor antagonist)

 

  • Aprepitant (NK-1 receptor antagonist) → Blocks substance P in the brainstem vomiting center. 
  • Highly effective for delayed CINV, usually combined with dexamethasone + 5-HT3 blocker for maximal protection.
  • Does not prolong QT, hence safest choice in long QT syndrome. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ondansetron (5-HT3 antagonist): Effective against acute CINV, but contraindicated in long QT syndrome since 5-HT3 blockers (esp. ondansetron, dolasetron) prolong QT interval. Not safe here.

 

Option C. Metoclopramide (D2 antagonist, prokinetic): Older antiemetic, sometimes used for breakthrough CINV, but associated with extrapyramidal side effects and can also contribute to QT prolongation. 

 

Option D. Prochlorperazine (phenothiazine, D2 antagonist): Dopamine antagonist used in CINV, but also associated with QT prolongation + EPS + sedation. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients at high risk of CINV and with congenital long QT syndrome, aprepitant is an effective and safe choice as it does not significantly affect QT interval and covers both acute and delayed nausea when used in combination with other non–QT-prolonging agents.

choices.text: Increased risk of diabetic renal disease

questions.text: A 69-year-old man with chronic heart failure and long-standing type 2 diabetes is being considered for addition of empagliflozin to his treatment regimen. While discussing potential adverse effects with him, which of the following risks should be highlighted?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased risk of Fournier’s gangrene

 

  • Empagliflozin is an SGLT-2 inhibitor that lowers blood glucose by blocking reabsorption of glucose in the proximal tubule, thereby causing glucosuria.
  • Beyond glycemic control, it has cardioprotective and renoprotective benefits—it reduces mortality in patients with type 2 diabetes and established cardiovascular disease, and importantly, reduces hospitalization and progression of CHF. 
  • However, because of persistent glycosuria and associated perineal infections, there have been rare but serious reports of necrotizing fasciitis of the perineum (Fournier’s gangrene).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Worsening of CHF: Incorrect. SGLT-2 inhibitors actually improve outcomes in CHF, reducing hospitalization and death. They do not worsen heart failure.

 

Option B. Increased risk of diabetic renal disease: Incorrect. These agents slow the progression of diabetic nephropathy by reducing intraglomerular pressure and albuminuria, hence they are renoprotective.

 

Option C. Nephrolithiasis from calcium-rich urine: Incorrect. While SGLT-2 inhibitors cause osmotic diuresis and glucosuria, they are not associated with calcium nephrolithiasis as a notable risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • SGLT2 inhibitors like empagliflozin reduce glucose reabsorption in the proximal tubules, causing glycosuria. 
  • While they improve heart failure outcomes and slow diabetic kidney disease progression, they are associated with an increased risk of genital infections, including Fournier’s gangrene.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman at 24 weeks gestation undergoes a routine glucose tolerance test. Her fasting blood glucose level is measured. According to the International Association of the Diabetes and Pregnancy Study Groups (IADPSG), what is the fasting blood glucose threshold for diagnosing gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM)?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) >92 mg/dL

 

  • The IADPSG guidelines specify that a fasting blood glucose level of greater than 92 mg/dL is one of the criteria for diagnosing gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM). 
  • The diagnosis of GDM can be made if any one of the following criteria is met during a 75-gram oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT): fasting glucose >92 mg/dL, 1-hour glucose >180 mg/dL, or 2-hour glucose >153 mg/dL.
  • These thresholds are aimed at identifying levels of glucose intolerance that may increase the risk of adverse pregnancy outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The IADPSG criteria for diagnosing gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) include a fasting blood glucose level >92 mg/dL as one of the thresholds during a 75-gram OGTT.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with a history of multiple episodes of fever and dysuria over the past year. Urine culture confirms recurrent urinary tract infections. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vesicoureteric reflux

 

  • Vesicoureteric reflux (VUR) refers to the retrograde flow of urine from the bladder into the ureter and renal pelvis. 
  • It is the most common cause of recurrent urinary tract infections in children. 
  • VUR predisposes to pyelonephritis, renal scarring, and hypertension, making early diagnosis crucial. 
  • A micturating cystourethrogram (MCU) is the investigation of choice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior urethral valves: This condition typically occurs in boys and causes obstructive uropathy. It presents with poor urinary stream, recurrent infections, and bilateral hydronephrosis. While it can cause UTIs, it is less common compared to VUR.

 

Option C. Renal calculi: Kidney stones can cause hematuria, abdominal pain, and secondary infection, but they are an uncommon cause of recurrent UTIs in children compared to congenital anomalies like VUR.

 

Option D. Neurogenic bladder: Seen in children with spinal dysraphism or neurological disorders, neurogenic bladder leads to urinary stasis and infections. However, it is less common than VUR as a cause of recurrent childhood UTIs.

 

Educational Objective:


The most frequent cause of recurrent urinary tract infections in children is vesicoureteric reflux, which predisposes to renal scarring and long-term complications.

questions.text: A 29-year-old HIV-positive male from northeast India presents with fever, weight loss, and generalized papular skin lesions resembling molluscum contagiosum. A skin biopsy is stained and shows intracellular sausage-shaped yeast cells with central transverse septum. Culture at 25°C is shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Penicillium marneffei

 

  • Penicillium marneffei (now called Talaromyces marneffei) is an opportunistic dimorphic fungus, endemic in Southeast Asia and Northeast India.
  • Seen commonly in HIV/AIDS patients.
  • Clinical features: fever, weight loss, generalized skin lesions resembling molluscum contagiosum.
  • Microscopy: intracellular sausage-shaped yeast cells with central transverse septum (pathognomonic).
  • Culture at 25°C: produces a characteristic red soluble pigment (as seen in the image).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Histoplasma capsulatum:

 

  • Also, intracellular yeast, but found within macrophages, without transverse septum.
  • No red pigment on culture – shows narrow-based budding 
  • Causes more respiratory problems than cutaneous problems.

 

Option B. Fonsecaea pedrosoi:

 

  • Causes chromoblastomycosis with sclerotic (Medlar) bodies in tissue.
  • Produces verrucous lesions, not molluscum-like papules.

 

Option D. Trichophyton rubrum:

 

  • Dermatophyte causing superficial infections (tinea, onychomycosis).
  • Not associated with systemic disease in HIV, nor molluscum-like lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Penicillium marneffei is a dimorphic fungus causing systemic mycosis in HIV patients, especially in Southeast Asia and Northeast India.
  • Hallmarks:
    • Intracellular yeast with central septum
    • Red pigment on culture at 25°C
    • Molluscum contagiosum–like skin lesions

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia is scheduled for elective inguinal hernia repair. During preoperative preparation, he received a medication. Later that evening, he develops severe urinary hesitancy, suprapubic discomfort, and inability to void. Which of the following drugs administered preoperatively is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glycopyrrolate

 

  • Glycopyrrolate is a quaternary ammonium antimuscarinic drug commonly used preoperatively to decrease airway and oral secretions, prevent vagal bradycardia, and reduce intraoperative secretions. 
  • In patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), anticholinergic agents can precipitate acute urinary retention by inhibiting parasympathetic stimulation of the detrusor muscle, which is necessary for bladder emptying. 
  • The patient’s postoperative inability to void is consistent with drug-induced urinary retention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Midazolam: A short-acting benzodiazepine used for anxiolysis and sedation before surgery; it does not have significant anticholinergic effects and is unlikely to cause urinary retention.

 

Option B. Fentanyl: An opioid analgesic. While opioids can sometimes cause urinary retention by increasing sphincter tone, in the perioperative setting, the stronger and more typical cause is anticholinergic use.

 

Option D. Metoclopramide: A dopamine antagonist with prokinetic and antiemetic properties; it does not impair detrusor muscle contraction and is not a common cause of urinary retention in BPH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anticholinergic drugs used in preoperative settings, such as glycopyrrolate, should be avoided or used cautiously in patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia because they can trigger acute urinary retention by impairing detrusor muscle contraction.

questions.text: A 3-week-old male infant is brought with recurrent non-bilious projectile vomiting after feeds. On examination, a palpable “olive-shaped” mass is felt in the epigastrium. Laboratory results show metabolic alkalosis. Which of the following electrolytes does not require replenishment in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻)

 

  • In hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, persistent vomiting leads to loss of gastric hydrochloric acid, causing hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis.
  • Management requires replenishment of sodium, potassium, and chloride.
  • Bicarbonate is already elevated due to alkalosis, and supplementation would worsen the imbalance, hence it is not replenished.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sodium: Sodium is often lost with gastric fluid losses. Volume repletion with isotonic saline corrects both sodium and chloride deficits, making sodium supplementation necessary.

 

Option B. Potassium: Hypokalemia develops due to renal potassium loss, aggravated by paradoxical aciduria in the setting of metabolic alkalosis. Potassium replacement is crucial once adequate urine output is confirmed.

 

Option C. Chloride: Chloride loss is a key abnormality in pyloric stenosis because hydrochloric acid is lost during repeated vomiting. Replacement with chloride-containing fluids (like normal saline) is mandatory to correct alkalosis.

 

Educational Objective:


In hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, fluid therapy requires correction of sodium, potassium, and chloride deficits, but bicarbonate is never replaced since patients already have metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease has been taking low-dose aspirin daily for secondary prevention of myocardial infarction. During a routine checkup, he reports black, tarry stools over the past week. Fecal occult blood testing is positive. The gastrointestinal symptoms are most likely due to the inhibition of which of the following pathways by aspirin?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thromboxane synthesis

 

  • Aspirin irreversibly inhibits cyclooxygenase (COX) enzymes (COX-1 and COX-2), leading to decreased synthesis of prostaglandins and thromboxane A2.
  • Inhibition of thromboxane A2 in platelets reduces platelet aggregation, prolonging bleeding time.
  • In the gastrointestinal tract, reduced protective prostaglandins from COX-1 inhibition compromise the gastric mucosal barrier, increasing the risk of erosions and ulcers, which may lead to occult or overt GI bleeding.
  • The patient’s melena (black stools) is due to GI bleeding secondary to this mechanism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phospholipase C: Involved in the inositol triphosphate (IP3) and diacylglycerol (DAG) pathway for intracellular signaling; not inhibited by aspirin.

 

Option C. Phospholipase D: Participates in phospholipid metabolism, not related to aspirin’s mechanism.

 

Option D. Phospholipase A2: This enzyme releases arachidonic acid from membrane phospholipids, but aspirin does not directly inhibit it; corticosteroids do.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspirin irreversibly inhibits COX enzymes, reducing thromboxane A2 synthesis in platelets and prostaglandin production in the stomach, leading to both antiplatelet effects and increased risk of GI bleeding.

choices.text: Combination chemotherapy with lenalidomide and dexamethasone (RD)
Combination chemotherapy with lenalidomide, bortezomib, and dexamethasone (RVD)
Referral to radiation oncology for radiation to the right humerus

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with right shoulder pain for one month, initially attributed to muscle strain from weightlifting. The pain has worsened, and a CT scan shows a destructive osseous lesion in the humerus with an extraosseous soft-tissue component. Biopsy reveals clonal plasma cell proliferation. Bone scan shows no other bony lesions, and bone marrow biopsy shows normal hematopoiesis without plasma cell clones. Labs are normal, including creatinine (0.8 mg/dL), calcium (9.0 mg/dL), albumin (4.0 g/dL), hemoglobin (12.9 g/dL), platelets (198,000/µL), and no M spike on SPEP. What is the next appropriate step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Referral to radiation oncology for radiation to the right humerus

 

  • The findings suggest solitary bone plasmacytoma, a localized plasma cell malignancy.
  • Destructive humerus lesion with clonal plasma cells, no systemic involvement (normal labs, bone marrow), and no M spike support this diagnosis.
  • Localized radiation therapy is the standard treatment for solitary plasmacytoma, often curative.
  • No evidence of multiple myeloma (e.g., CRAB criteria: hypercalcemia, renal failure, anemia, bone lesions).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Combination chemotherapy with lenalidomide and dexamethasone (RD): Used for multiple myeloma, not solitary plasmacytoma without systemic disease.

 

Option B. Combination chemotherapy with lenalidomide, bortezomib, and dexamethasone (RVD): Indicated for active multiple myeloma, not localized plasmacytoma.

 

Option C. Observation and physical therapy referral: Inadequate, as the destructive lesion requires active treatment to prevent progression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Solitary plasmacytoma presents as a single destructive bone lesion without systemic myeloma features.
  • Localized radiation therapy is the primary treatment.
  • Monitor for progression to multiple myeloma.

choices.text: Overexpression of a protein that regulates the G1→S phase transition
Activation of a tyrosine kinase receptor involved in hematopoietic cell proliferation
Increased expression of an anti-apoptotic protein in B lymphocyte
Loss of a tumor suppressor gene responsible for DNA repair

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with fatigue, unintentional weight loss, and generalized lymphadenopathy. Laboratory testing reveals normocytic anemia and elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH). Lymph node biopsy demonstrates a diffuse population of small- to medium-sized lymphoid cells with irregular nuclear contours. Immunohistochemistry is positive for CD5 and cyclin D1. Cytogenetic analysis reveals a balanced translocation involving chromosomes 11 and 14. Which of the following best describes the molecular consequence of this translocation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Overexpression of a protein that regulates the G1→S phase transition

 

  • Mantle cell lymphoma is a mature B-cell neoplasm typically affecting older adults and often presenting with painless lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, and B symptoms (fever, night sweats, weight loss).
  • It is characterized by a t(11;14) translocation that juxtaposes the CCND1 gene (cyclin D1) on chromosome 11 with the immunoglobulin heavy chain (IgH) gene promoter on chromosome 14.
  • The IgH promoter is highly active in B cells, leading to overexpression of cyclin D1.
  • Cyclin D1 promotes the G1→S phase transition in the cell cycle, driving uncontrolled cell proliferation.
  • Immunophenotype: CD5+, CD19+, CD20+, cyclin D1+.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Activation of a tyrosine kinase receptor involved in hematopoietic cell proliferation: Describes chronic myeloid leukemia with BCR-ABL fusion from t(9;22), not mantle cell lymphoma.

 

Option C. Increased expression of an anti-apoptotic protein in B lymphocyte: Refers to follicular lymphoma with BCL2 overexpression from t(14;18).

 

Option D. Loss of a tumor suppressor gene responsible for DNA repair: May occur in retinoblastoma (RB gene) or Li-Fraumeni syndrome (TP53 gene), not mantle cell lymphoma.

 

Educational Objective:


t(11;14) translocation → overexpression of cyclin D1 (CCND1 gene) → promotes G1→S phase cell cycle transition → mantle cell lymphoma.

choices.text: Persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn

questions.text: A full-term newborn weighing 3.5 kg develops severe respiratory distress shortly after birth. The infant does not improve with surfactant therapy. The family reports that an older sibling died at one month of age due to a similar respiratory illness. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis

 

  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP) is caused by abnormal surfactant metabolism, most often due to surfactant protein B deficiency. 
  • It presents in full-term newborns with severe respiratory distress unresponsive to surfactant replacement, often with a family history of early neonatal death. 
  • Lung biopsy reveals PAS-positive eosinophilic material filling alveoli.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyaline membrane disease: This disease, also called neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, occurs in premature infants due to surfactant deficiency. It typically responds to exogenous surfactant therapy, unlike the case described.

 

Option C. Meconium aspiration syndrome: This condition occurs in term or post-term infants who pass meconium in utero, leading to airway obstruction and chemical pneumonitis. It does not present with family history or failure to respond to surfactant therapy.

 

Option D. Persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn: This presents with cyanosis, hypoxemia, and pulmonary hypertension, often unresponsive to oxygen therapy but unrelated to surfactant deficiency or family history.

 

Educational Objective:


Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis due to surfactant protein B deficiency should be suspected in a term neonate with respiratory distress unresponsive to surfactant therapy, especially with a family history of neonatal death.

questions.text: A brain biopsy shows multinucleated, lipid-laden macrophages (globoid cells) in the CNS and perivascular regions, as shown in the image. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Krabbe disease

 

  • Krabbe disease is an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder caused by deficiency of galactocerebrosidase.
  • The hallmark histological finding is the presence of globoid cells—large, multinucleated, lipid-laden macrophages—in the CNS and around blood vessels.
  • The accumulation of galactocerebroside is toxic to oligodendrocytes, leading to demyelination and severe neurodegeneration.
  • Clinically, infants present with irritability, stiffness, developmental regression, seizures, and early death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gaucher disease: Characterized by Gaucher cells—macrophages with a wrinkled tissue paper appearance—due to glucocerebrosidase deficiency. Involves liver, spleen, and bone marrow more than CNS.

 

 

Option C. Niemann–Pick disease: Shows foam cells (lipid-laden macrophages) due to sphingomyelinase deficiency, often with hepatosplenomegaly and cherry-red macula.

 

 

Option D. Metachromatic leukodystrophy: Due to arylsulfatase A deficiency, causing sulfatide accumulation; histology shows metachromatic granules on special staining, not globoid cells.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Globoid cells—multinucleated macrophages packed with lipids—are pathognomonic for Krabbe disease, a demyelinating leukodystrophy due to galactocerebrosidase deficiency.

choices.text: Tympanic membrane perforation with ossicular dislocation
Ossicular dislocation with an intact tympanic membrane

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman develops decreased hearing in her right ear following a road traffic accident. Pure tone audiometry demonstrates a 55 dB conductive hearing loss, and otoscopic evaluation reveals that the tympanic membrane is intact without signs of perforation. Which underlying condition best explains her hearing deficit?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ossicular dislocation with an intact tympanic membrane

 

  • The patient presents with conductive hearing loss (55 dB) after trauma and an intact tympanic membrane. 
  • This suggests a problem in the middle ear that disrupts sound conduction but preserves the tympanic membrane's integrity.
  • Ossicular dislocation is the most likely cause, specifically involving the incus or stapes, which are more prone to injury. 
  • Trauma can disrupt the ossicular chain, creating a gap that impairs sound transmission, leading to significant conductive hearing loss (~55 dB).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tympanic membrane perforation with ossicular dislocation: If there was a tympanic membrane perforation, the patient would typically have less conductive hearing loss (~30-38 dB) because the sound waves can still reach the cochlea directly via the perforation. This scenario does not match the intact tympanic membrane described in this case.

 

Option C. Serous otitis media: Serous otitis media involves fluid accumulation in the middle ear and typically causes mild conductive hearing loss (~ 35-40 dB). It is not associated with trauma and would not cause a hearing loss of 55 dB.

 

Option D. Cholesteatoma: Cholesteatoma is a chronic condition involving abnormal epithelial growth in the middle ear. It often causes foul-smelling discharge, erosion of ossicles, and conductive hearing loss. It is not directly linked to trauma and is unlikely to present with an intact tympanic membrane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ossicular dislocation with an intact tympanic membrane is the most likely cause of significant conductive hearing loss (~55 dB) following trauma. 
  • It disrupts sound conduction by creating a discontinuity in the ossicular chain.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents 24 hours after cutting her left foot on a boat propeller in a lake. The abrasion is painful, with erythema to the ankle and boggy tissue. She is diaphoretic, febrile (40.1°C), with pulse 112/min, respiratory rate 16/min, and blood pressure 100/62 mmHg. Labs show creatinine 1.7 mg/dL, WBC 22,400/µL (98% neutrophils, 6% bands), and lactate 3.4 mmol/L. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Necrotizing fasciitis

 

  • The presentation suggests necrotizing fasciitis, a rapidly progressive soft tissue infection.
  • Pain out of proportion, boggy tissue, fever, and elevated lactate indicate severe infection.
  • Lake water exposure increases risk of Aeromonas infections. 
  • Urgent surgical debridement and broad-spectrum antibiotics are required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pyoderma gangrenosum: Inflammatory ulcers, not infectious, linked to systemic diseases.

 

Option C. Pyomyositis: Muscle infection, lacks boggy tissue or rapid progression.

 

Option D. Severe cellulitis: Less likely to cause lactate elevation or disproportionate pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Necrotizing fasciitis presents with severe pain, systemic signs, and lactate elevation.
  • Water exposure increases polymicrobial infection risk.
  • Urgent surgery and antibiotics are critical for survival.

choices.text: It can be found in Pseudomonas spp. and Acinetobacter baumannii
It is inhibited by EDTA in laboratory tests
It confers resistance to all β-lactams, including monobactams
It is encoded by mobile genetic elements such as plasmids

questions.text: Which of the following statements about New Delhi metallo-β-lactamase is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It confers resistance to all β-lactams, including monobactams

 

  • New Delhi metallo-β-lactamase (NDM) is a Class B metallo-β-lactamase that hydrolyzes most β-lactam antibiotics — including carbapenems, cephalosporins, and penicillins — by a zinc-dependent hydrolytic mechanism.
  • However, monobactams (e.g., aztreonam) are not hydrolyzed by NDM, which means they can remain active unless the bacteria also produce other β-lactamases that inactivate monobactams.
  • NDM production is a major cause of carbapenem resistance in Enterobacteriaceae, Pseudomonas spp., and Acinetobacter baumannii.
  • Laboratory detection often uses EDTA to inhibit the enzyme (chelation of zinc cofactor).
  • Genes for NDM are typically plasmid-borne, allowing rapid horizontal spread between species.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It can be found in Pseudomonas spp. and Acinetobacter baumannii: True. NDM has been reported in both these non-fermenters as well as in Enterobacteriaceae.

 

Option B. It is inhibited by EDTA in laboratory tests: True. EDTA removes zinc from the enzyme's active site, inhibiting its function.

 

Option D.  It is encoded by mobile genetic elements such as plasmids: True. This facilitates horizontal gene transfer between bacterial species.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • NDM is a plasmid-mediated, zinc-dependent Class B metallo-β-lactamase that hydrolyzes most β-lactams except monobactams. 
  • EDTA inhibition is used in detection. Its plasmid location promotes rapid global dissemination among Gram-negative pathogens.

questions.text: Match the drug with its primary role in gout management:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1–c, 2–d, 3–b, 4–a

 

  • 1–c (Allopurinol): Xanthine oxidase inhibitor; decreases uric acid production, preventing long-term gout attacks.
  • 2–d (Colchicine): Anti-inflammatory for acute attacks and prophylaxis but not the mainstay for urate lowering.
  • 3–b (Ibuprofen): NSAID for symptomatic relief in acute flares; no impact on uric acid levels.
  • 4–a (Prednisone): Corticosteroid used in acute settings; unsuitable for chronic use due to side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Allopurinol, a xanthine oxidase inhibitor, is the preferred long-term urate-lowering therapy in gout because it decreases uric acid production and prevents recurrent attacks. 
  • Medications like colchicine, NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen), and corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone) are primarily for acute flare management or short-term prophylaxis and do not address long-term uric acid control.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with fever, refusal to bear weight, and a swollen, tender knee. The child has no history of trauma. The white blood cell count is elevated. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Septic arthritis

 

  • This is a medical emergency characterized by a bacterial infection in a joint, which can lead to rapid cartilage destruction and permanent joint damage if not treated promptly. 
  • The classic presentation includes fever, refusal to bear weight (pseudoparalysis), and a swollen, tender joint—all of which are present in this case. 
  • The elevated white blood cell (WBC) count supports an infectious process.
  • The triad of fever, refusal to bear weight, and a hot, swollen, tender joint is the classic presentation of septic arthritis in a child. 
  • The acute onset and elevated WBC count are strong indicators of a bacterial infection. 
  • The lack of trauma history is also typical, as the infection often reaches the joint through the bloodstream (hematogenous spread).
  • The Kocher's criteria are a clinical prediction tool used to help differentiate between septic arthritis and transient synovitis, especially in children with a painful hip. While they were originally developed for the hip, they are often applied to other joints like the knee due to the similarity in symptoms.
  • The four criteria are:
    • Non-weight-bearing: The child is unable to bear weight on the affected leg.
    • Fever: A temperature greater than 38.5°C (101.3°F).
    • Elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR): An ESR greater than 40 mm/hr.
    • Elevated white blood cell (WBC) count: A WBC count greater than 12,000 cells/mm³.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA): 

 

  • JIA is a chronic autoimmune disease characterized by joint inflammation lasting at least six weeks. 
  • While it can cause joint swelling and pain, the onset is typically gradual, and fever may not be as prominent or acute as in septic arthritis. 
  • The refusal to bear weight and high fever in an acutely ill child point more toward an infection than an inflammatory process.

 

Option C. Osgood-Schlatter disease: 

 

  • This condition is an inflammation of the patellar tendon where it attaches to the tibial tuberosity. 
  • It is an overuse injury common in adolescents (not a 6-year-old) who are active in sports. The primary symptom is localized pain and swelling at the tibial tuberosity, not fever or a swollen joint cavity, and there is no associated systemic illness.

 

Option D. Transient synovitis: 

 

  • This is a self-limiting inflammatory condition of the hip joint. 
  • It is a common cause of limp and hip pain in children, often following a viral illness. 
  • While it can cause refusal to bear weight and a low-grade fever, it does not typically present with the acute, high fever and marked systemic signs of a serious bacterial infection. 
  • It is also more common in the hip than the knee, and the WBC count is usually normal or only slightly elevated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The outcome of septic arthritis is highly dependent on how quickly it is diagnosed and treated. 
  • Delayed treatment can lead to irreversible joint damage, chronic arthritis, growth plate abnormalities, or even systemic sepsis and death. 
  • Therefore, a high index of suspicion is critical for any child presenting with an acutely swollen and painful joint.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms cannot be diagnosed by Giemsa staining of a peripheral blood smear and is instead usually confirmed by serologic detection of specific antibodies?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Coxiella burnetii

 

  • Coxiella burnetii (the causative agent of Q fever) is not detectable on routine Giemsa staining of peripheral blood smears because it is an obligate intracellular organism residing mainly in macrophages and tissues. 
  • Diagnosis is primarily based on serology, detecting phase I and phase II antibodies. PCR can also be used, but smear microscopy is not helpful.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bartonella henselae : Bartonella henselae and Bartonella bacilliformis can be visualized in peripheral blood smears with Giemsa or Wright staining (especially in Carrion’s disease caused by B. bacilliformis).

 

Option B. Toxoplasma (tachyzoites): Toxoplasma gondii tachyzoites can be identified on Giemsa-stained smears, though more often diagnosis relies on serology or molecular techniques.

 

Option C. Ehrlichia: Ehrlichia chaffeensis can be seen in peripheral blood smears as morulae inside monocytes using Giemsa or Wright stain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Coxiella burnetii cannot be detected in peripheral blood smears using Giemsa stain. Its diagnosis relies on serological testing or PCR. 
  • In contrast, Bartonella, Toxoplasma (tachyzoites), and Ehrlichia can be detected in peripheral blood smears.

choices.text: It is a remnant of the vitellointestinal duct
It is located on the mesenteric border of the ileum
It may contain heterotopic gastric, colonic, or pancreatic mucosa
When found within an inguinal or femoral hernia, it is termed Littre’s hernia

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Meckel’s diverticulum is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is located on the mesenteric border of the ileum

 

  • Meckel’s diverticulum is classically located on the anti-mesenteric border of the ileum, not the mesenteric side. 
  • This is a key anatomical feature distinguishing it from other small bowel outpouchings.

 

Option A. It is a remnant of the vitellointestinal duct: This is correct. Meckel’s diverticulum develops due to incomplete obliteration of the vitellointestinal (omphalomesenteric) duct during embryonic development.

 

Option C. It may contain heterotopic gastric, colonic, or pancreatic mucosa: This is correct. Around 20% of Meckel’s diverticula contain heterotopic tissue, most commonly gastric mucosa, which can lead to ulceration and bleeding due to acid secretion.

 

Option D. When found within an inguinal or femoral hernia, it is termed Littre’s hernia: This is correct. A Meckel’s diverticulum that presents inside a hernia sac is known as Littre’s hernia, a recognized clinical entity.

 

Educational Objective:


Meckel’s diverticulum, a true diverticulum on the anti-mesenteric border of the ileum, may contain ectopic mucosa and rarely present as Littre’s hernia; mislabeling it as mesenteric in location is incorrect.

questions.text: BETT classification is used for the assessment of which condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ocular trauma

 

  • BETT (Birmingham Eye Trauma Terminology) classification is specifically designed for standardized assessment of ocular trauma.
  • It helps in categorizing eye injuries into open globe and closed globe injuries, with further sub classifications (rupture, penetrating, perforating, IOFB, etc.).
  • It is not used for retinopathy, corneal ulcers, or uveitis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retinopathy: Incorrect. Retinopathy (e.g., diabetic or hypertensive) is assessed using classifications like ETDRS (Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study), International Clinical Diabetic Retinopathy Classification, or Keith-Wagener-Barker for hypertensive retinopathy. BETT is not used here.

 

Option C. Corneal ulcers: Incorrect. Corneal ulcers are graded/classified by size, depth, location, causative organism, or Modified Jones classification. BETT does not deal with infective/inflammatory corneal pathology.

 

Option D. Uveitis: Incorrect. Uveitis classification is done by SUN (Standardization of Uveitis Nomenclature) working group, which classifies it into anterior, intermediate, posterior, and panuveitis. BETT is unrelated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The BETT classification (Birmingham Eye Trauma Terminology) provides a standardized system for describing ocular trauma, dividing it into:
    • Closed globe injuries (contusion, lamellar laceration)
    • Open globe injuries (rupture, penetrating, perforating, intraocular foreign body)
  • This classification ensures uniformity in communication, research, prognosis, and management planning in ocular trauma.

choices.text: Accumulation of abnormally folded, β-pleated prion proteins that induce conformational change in normal proteins
Intracellular neurofibrillary tangles composed of hyperphosphorylated tau

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his family due to rapidly progressive dementia over the past 6 weeks. His family reports that he has recently developed sudden jerking movements of his limbs and increasing difficulty walking. On examination, he has myoclonus, ataxia, and disorientation. MRI of the brain shows hyperintensities in the caudate and putamen. EEG demonstrates periodic sharp wave complexes. A brain biopsy is obtained and shown below. Which of the following best describes the underlying mechanism of this patient’s disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Accumulation of abnormally folded, β-pleated prion proteins that induce conformational change in normal proteins

 

  • The patient’s rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonus, and ataxia, along with MRI caudate/putamen hyperintensities, EEG periodic sharp waves, and spongiform histopathology, are classic for Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease (CJD), a prion disease.

 

Mechanism:

 

  • Normal cellular prion protein (PrP^C) has an α-helical structure and is found in healthy neurons.
  • In prion disease, PrP^C undergoes a conformational change into PrP^Sc, which has a β-pleated sheet structure.
  • PrP^Sc is resistant to proteases and can induce further misfolding of normal prion proteins, leading to a self-propagating cycle.
  • This results in neuronal death, vacuolation, and spongiform degeneration without inflammation.

 

Mechanism:

 

  • Normal cellular prion protein (PrPC) has an α-helical structure and is found in healthy neurons.
  • In prion disease, PrPC undergoes a conformational change into PrPSc, which has a β-pleated sheet structure.
  • PrPSc is resistant to proteases and can induce further misfolding of normal prion proteins, leading to a self-propagating cycle.
  • This results in neuronal death, vacuolation, and spongiform degeneration without inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Beta-amyloid accumulation in cortical neurons: Seen in Alzheimer disease, which has a slow onset over years, not weeks, and does not cause myoclonus early in the disease. Pathology shows extracellular amyloid plaques, not spongiform change.

 

Option C. Autoantibody-mediated demyelination of central white matter: This describes multiple sclerosis, which causes demyelinating plaques in white matter with relapsing neurological symptoms, not rapidly progressive dementia. Histology shows demyelination with inflammatory infiltrates, not vacuoles.

 

Option D. Intracellular neurofibrillary tangles composed of hyperphosphorylated tau: This is also associated with Alzheimer disease (and other tauopathies), presenting with gradual memory decline over years. Tangles are intraneuronal aggregates, not spongiform changes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease is caused by the accumulation of β-pleated sheet prion proteins (PrPSc) that convert normal α-helical prion proteins (PrPC) into abnormal forms. 
  • This leads to spongiform degeneration, neuronal loss, and rapid neurological decline.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with cough and shortness of breath. She denies joint pain, rashes, fevers, or night sweats but recalls a rash in her legs that she has pictured in her phone 2 weeks ago. She is a non-smoking secretary with no pets. Exam shows fine lung crackles. X-ray is shown below as well. PFTs show a mixed obstructive-restrictive pattern. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sarcoidosis

 

  • The presentation suggests sarcoidosis, a granulomatous disease.
  • Cough, dyspnea, and fine crackles indicate pulmonary involvement.
  • Prior erythema nodosum is a common sarcoidosis feature.
  • CT shows hilar lymphadenopathy and fibrosis; PFTs reflect mixed lung disease.
  • Sarcoidosis often affects young adults and may resolve spontaneously.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypersensitivity pneumonitis: Requires antigen exposure (e.g., dust), not reported here.

 

Option B. Idiopathic interstitial pneumonia: Lacks erythema nodosum or systemic features.

 

Option D. Scleroderma: Features skin thickening or Raynaud’s, absent in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sarcoidosis causes pulmonary symptoms with hilar lymphadenopathy and erythema nodosum.
  • CT and PFTs show characteristic lung changes.
  • Spontaneous resolution is possible, but corticosteroids may be needed.

questions.text: In the β-oxidation of palmitic acid, if the final product is acetoacetate, what is the net ATP yield?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 26

 

Step 1: Normal β-oxidation of palmitic acid (C16)

 

  • Palmitate undergoes 7 cycles of β-oxidation → produces:
    • 8 Acetyl-CoA
    • 7 FADH₂
    • 7 NADH

 

Step 2: ATP yield (if fully oxidized via TCA cycle)

 

  • 7 FADH₂ → 7 × 1.5 = 10.5 ATP
  • 7 NADH → 7 × 2.5 = 17.5 ATP
  • 8 Acetyl-CoA → 8 × 10 = 80 ATP
    (since 1 Acetyl-CoA → 10 ATP in TCA)

 

Total = 108 ATP

 

Subtract 2 ATP for activation of palmitate → Net = 106 ATP

 

Step 3: If final product is acetoacetate instead of complete oxidation

 

  • Instead of running Acetyl-CoA through the TCA cycle, acetyl-CoA condenses to form ketone bodies.
  • To form 1 acetoacetate, 2 Acetyl-CoA are required.
  • From palmitate (8 Acetyl-CoA) → 4 acetoacetates could be formed.
  • But here, question specifies: final product is acetoacetate (not oxidation via TCA).
  • So no ATP from TCA cycle (80 ATP lost).
  • Only ATP from β-oxidation itself (NADH + FADH₂).
    • 7 NADH = 17.5 ATP
    • 7 FADH₂ = 10.5 ATP
      Subtotal = 28 ATP
      Subtract 2 ATP (activation) = 26 ATP net
    • Complete oxidation of palmitate → 106 ATP
    • If diverted to ketone body (acetoacetate) synthesis → only 26 ATP

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases where β-oxidation leads to ketone body formation (like acetoacetate) instead of TCA cycle entry, the net ATP yield of palmitate oxidation is reduced to 26 ATP due to bypassing the acetyl-CoA oxidation steps.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with drug-resistant focal seizures is undergoing evaluation for alternative antiepileptic medications. He has been on multiple sodium channel–blocking agents without adequate seizure control. Which of the following drugs has a primary mechanism of action not based on sodium channel modulation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vigabatrin

 

  • Most conventional antiepileptic agents, such as phenytoin, lamotrigine, and to some extent valproate, exert their main antiseizure effects by inhibiting voltage-gated sodium channels, stabilizing the neuronal membrane and reducing repetitive firing.
  • Vigabatrin works differently — it irreversibly inhibits GABA transaminase, the enzyme responsible for GABA degradation, thereby increasing inhibitory neurotransmitter levels in the CNS. 
  • Its primary mechanism does not involve sodium channel modulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenytoin: Primarily blocks voltage-gated sodium channels, reducing repetitive neuronal firing.

 

Option B. Lamotrigine: Inhibits voltage-gated sodium channels and decreases glutamate release.

 

Option D. Valproate: Multiple mechanisms, including sodium channel blockade and increased GABA availability; sodium channel effect is significant in its antiepileptic action.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vigabatrin is unique among common antiepileptic drugs for acting via irreversible inhibition of GABA transaminase, enhancing inhibitory signaling without primarily targeting sodium channels.

choices.text: Adolescents can’t be employed in any industry
Maximum daily work duration for adolescents is 4.5 hours
Adolescents can only work night shifts
No restriction exists for synthetic industries

questions.text: A 16-year-old is employed in a factory producing synthetic dyes and works 9 hours daily. Which clause of the Factories Act is violated?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Maximum daily work duration for adolescents is 4.5 hours

 

  • Under the Factories Act (India), an “adolescent” is defined as a worker aged 15–18 years.
  • Adolescents can be employed in factories, but their working hours are restricted to a maximum of 4.5 hours per day.
  • They are also prohibited from working at night (between 7 pm and 6 am).
  • In this scenario, the boy is working 9 hours/day, clearly violating the Act.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adolescents can’t be employed in any industry: Incorrect. Adolescents may be employed, but with restrictions on hours and night work. Total prohibition applies to children (<14 years), not adolescents.

 

Option C. Adolescents can only work night shifts: Incorrect. In fact, adolescents are prohibited from working night shifts.

 

Option D. No restriction exists for synthetic industries: Incorrect. The Factories Act applies to all registered factories, including chemical industries. Restrictions are uniform across sectors.

 

Educational Objective:

  • Under the Factories Act, adolescents (15–18 years) can work but with limitations:
    • ≤ 4.5 hours per day
    • No night work (7 pm–6 am)
  • Children <14 years cannot be employed in factories at all.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents with intermittent chest pain and dysphagia to both solids and liquids over the past 6 months. The pain is not exertion-related and sometimes occurs at rest. Cardiac evaluation is normal. Barium swallow is shown below. Which of the following next investigations will most definitively confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Esophageal manometry

 

  • The corkscrew appearance on barium swallow is characteristic of diffuse esophageal spasm (DES), a motility disorder caused by uncoordinated, simultaneous, nonperistaltic contractions of the esophagus with preserved lower esophageal sphincter relaxation.
  • Esophageal manometry is the gold standard for diagnosis. 
  • In DES, manometry shows repetitive, high-amplitude, simultaneous contractions during swallowing instead of the normal sequential peristalsis.
  • Barium swallow is useful for suggesting the diagnosis, but definitive confirmation requires manometric evaluation of esophageal motility.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  24-hour esophageal pH monitoring: Used to diagnose gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), not motility disorders.

 

Option C. Upper endoscopy: Useful for excluding structural causes of dysphagia (eg, strictures, tumors) but cannot confirm motility abnormalities. It confirms the diagnosis of Ca esophagus.

 

Option D. CT chest: May detect extrinsic compression or mediastinal masses, but has no role in confirming DES. It can also rule out metastasis or a submucosal lesion like leiomyoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In suspected diffuse esophageal spasm, esophageal manometry is the definitive diagnostic test, revealing uncoordinated, simultaneous contractions with normal LES relaxation.

questions.text: A young boy presents with an insidious onset of a limp and knee pain over the past several months. The pain is worse with activity. On examination, he has limited internal rotation of the hip. A radiograph is shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Surgical fixation with percutaneous screws

 

  • The goal of surgery is to prevent further slippage of the femoral head and stabilize the growth plate. 
  • This is achieved by inserting one or more screws across the growth plate into the femoral head. 
  • The procedure is typically performed percutaneously (through the skin) and aims to stop the slip where it is, not to reduce it, unless the slip is acute.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Physical therapy and observation:

 

  • SCFE is a surgical emergency. The "slip" is a separation of the epiphysis (the end part of the bone) from the metaphysis (the neck of the bone) through the growth plate. 
  • It is unstable and will continue to slip without surgical intervention, leading to further deformity and potential complications like avascular necrosis. 
  • Physical therapy is not the primary treatment.

 

 

Option C. Pain medication and activity modification: 

 

  • This is insufficient and incorrect as the sole treatment. 
  • While pain medication and activity modification may temporarily relieve symptoms, they do not address the underlying mechanical instability of the SCFE. 
  • Delaying definitive surgical treatment significantly increases the risk of a more severe slip and long-term complications.

 

Option D. Non-weight bearing cast application:

 

  • A cast does not immobilize the hip joint sufficiently to prevent further slippage of the femoral head. 
  • It is not an effective way to manage SCFE and would lead to a worsening of the condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the classic clinical presentation of Slipped Capital Femoral Epiphysis (SCFE): insidious onset of limp and knee or hip pain in an adolescent or pre-adolescent, with pain that worsens with activity and an obligatory limited internal rotation of the hip on physical examination.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman reports multiple itchy, Silvery white scaly patches over her knees and elbows that have gradually worsened over several months. On examination, removal of the overlying scale reveals tiny bleeding points as shown in the image below. Which clinical feature is most typical of this disorder?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Auspitz sign

 

  • Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory skin condition characterized by well-demarcated, erythematous plaques with silvery-white scales, commonly affecting extensor surfaces (elbows, knees, scalp). 
  • It has several hallmark clinical findings:
    • Auspitz sign: The appearance of pinpoint bleeding when psoriasis scales are scraped off, due to exposure of capillaries in the dermal papillae.
    • Koebner phenomenon: The development of new lesions at sites of skin trauma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Darier’s sign: Urticaria formation when a lesion is rubbed, seen in cutaneous mastocytosis (Urticaria pigmentosa).

 

Option C. Nikolsky sign: Epidermal sloughing with slight pressure, seen in pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Option D. Wickham striae: White, lace-like patterns on mucosal surfaces, characteristic of lichen planus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Auspitz sign (pinpoint bleeding upon scale removal) is a key feature of psoriasis, along with Koebner phenomenon and well-demarcated erythematous plaques with silvery scales.

questions.text: A stool specimen from a patient with chronic non-bloody diarrhea is examined microscopically. Image A shows the trophozoite form, and image B shows the cyst form of the same protozoan. Based on these morphological features, which organism is most likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Entamoeba coli

 

  • Trophozoite (Image A): Coarse, irregular peripheral chromatin, eccentric karyosome, abundant cytoplasmic vacuoles with bacteria/debris but no ingested RBCs.
  • Cyst (Image B): Spherical with up to 8 nuclei, eccentric karyosome, irregular peripheral chromatin, occasionally chromatoid bodies with splintered ends.
  • E. coli is non-pathogenic but indicates fecal-oral contamination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Entamoeba histolytica: Pathogenic; cyst has up to 4 nuclei (quadrinucleate cyst), fine peripheral chromatin, central karyosome; trophozoites may contain ingested RBCs. The trophozoite also contains pseudopodia.

 

 

Option C. Giardia lamblia: Cyst is oval with 4 nuclei with an axostyle in centre; trophozoite has a “face-like” appearance with 2 nuclei, pear shape and ventral sucking disc.

 

 

Option D. Iodamoeba bütschlii: Cyst has single nucleus and large glycogen vacuole; karyosome is large and eccentric.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Entamoeba coli is a non-pathogenic commensal amoeba of the human large intestine. Diagnosis relies on recognizing morphological hallmarks:
  • Cyst: up to 8 nuclei, coarse chromatin, eccentric karyosome.
  • Trophozoite: coarse irregular chromatin, abundant vacuoles, no ingested RBCs.
  • Its presence is a marker of fecal contamination and poor sanitation but does not require treatment.

questions.text: Two vessels are compared as shown below. Assuming constant pressure along both the vessels and linear flow pattern, what will be the flow across the vessel 1 compared to vessel 2?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 8 times

 

Hemodynamics

 

Poiseuille’s Equation 

 

Poiseuille’s law states that the flow of fluid is related to a number of factors 

The viscosity (n) of the fluid 

The pressure gradient across the vessel (P) 

Length (L) and diameter (d) of the vessel 

The relationship is given by Poiseuille-Hagen formula: 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to Poiseuille’s law, flow in a tube increases with the fourth power of radius and decreases with tube length; doubling both radius and length results in an 8-fold increase in flow.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents to the psychiatry clinic with firm beliefs that a minor disagreement he had with a neighbor 5 years ago was actually a covert assassination attempt planned by intelligence agencies. He recalls the event accurately in terms of facts (e.g., location, time, person involved), but has now attached a fixed false belief to its meaning. What is the most appropriate description of this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Delusional memory

 

  • Delusional memory refers to when a real past event is remembered accurately in detail, but is later given a delusional interpretation or significance. 
  • In this case, the man correctly remembers the details of a past disagreement, but now believes it was an assassination attempt by intelligence agencies, which is a fixed false belief attached retrospectively.
  • This is characteristic of delusional memory.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Delusional perception: Involves a normal sensory perception being interpreted in a delusional way at the time of perception (e.g., seeing a red car and believing it means someone is spying on you). This does not involve memory.

 

Option C. Confabulation: Involves fabrication of false memories, often seen in organic brain syndromes (e.g., Korsakoff's), and the individual believes them to be true. In contrast, this patient’s memory is accurate in content but distorted in interpretation.

 

Option D. Delusional intuition: Refers to a sudden, unfounded belief arising without any perceptual input or prior event—essentially a "delusional idea out of the blue", which does not apply here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delusional memory involves attaching a delusional meaning to a genuinely remembered past event.

questions.text:
Isolation of infected individuals can help prevent transmission of certain infectious diseases. In which of the following conditions is isolation considered beneficial? 

 

  1. Diphtheria
  2. Measles
  3. Typhoid
  4. Tuberculosis
  5. Cholera
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4 and 5

 

Option 1. Diphtheria: Highly contagious respiratory disease; droplet isolation prevents spread.

 

Option 2. Measles: Extremely infectious airborne disease; isolation (airborne precautions) is essential until 4 days after rash onset.

 

Option 4. Tuberculosis: Spread via airborne droplets; isolation in negative-pressure rooms is critical until sputum conversion.

 

Option 5. Cholera: Though mainly water-borne, isolation in treatment settings prevents person-to-person spread via contaminated fomites.

 

Incorrect Option:

 

Option 3. Typhoid: Incorrect. Caused by Salmonella Typhi; spread is fecal-oral via contaminated food/water. Isolation of patients is not standard; focus is on sanitation, safe food handling, and treatment. Carriers can be infectious without showing symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Conservative strategy with aspirin, β-blocker, nitrates, and stress testing
Plan for coronary angiography within 24–72 hours
Urgent angiography with intent to revascularize

questions.text: A 63-year-old man with no past medical history presents with 20 minutes of substernal chest pressure radiating to his left arm at rest, resolving spontaneously. ECG is shown below. Serial troponins are undetectable. What is the next appropriate step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Conservative strategy with aspirin, β-blocker, nitrates, and stress testing

 

  • The presentation suggests unstable angina, a low-risk acute coronary syndrome (ACS).
  • Negative troponins and normal ECG indicate low risk (TIMI score 0–2).
  • Conservative management includes aspirin, β-blockers, nitrates, and statins.
  • Stress testing assesses for significant coronary artery disease.
  • High-risk stress test results warrant angiography.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Discharge the patient home: Unstable angina requires risk stratification to prevent acute events.

 

Option C. Plan for coronary angiography within 24–72 hours: Indicated for certain high-risk ACS patients (e.g., NSTEMI), not low-risk unstable angina.

 

Option Urgent angiography with intent to revascularize: Reserved for hemodynamic instability or refractory angina, not present here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Low-risk unstable angina is managed with antiplatelets, β-blockers, and stress testing.
  • Negative troponins and normal ECG guide conservative management.
  • Stress testing determines the need for angiography.
