questions.text: A 47-year-old woman with three children elects to undergo a prophylactic hysterectomy. During the ligation of the uterine artery, which nearby anatomical structure is at the greatest risk for accidental injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ureter

 

  • During hysterectomy, ligation of the uterine artery is a key surgical step. The ureter runs in close proximity to the uterine artery, passing just inferior to it near the lateral fornix of the vagina.
  • This anatomical arrangement makes the ureter particularly susceptible to iatrogenic injury during clamping or tying of the uterine artery. 
  • Such injury may result in partial transection, ligation, or thermal damage, leading to postoperative complications such as ureteral obstruction, fistula formation, or hydronephrosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lumbosacral trunk: Although present in the pelvic region, the lumbosacral trunk lies posteriorly and is not in the immediate operative field during uterine artery ligation. Its injury risk during this procedure is minimal.

 

Option C. Internal iliac lymph nodes: These nodes are located along the internal iliac vessels and may be encountered during pelvic lymphadenectomy, not routinely during a standard hysterectomy for benign conditions.

 

Option D. Internal iliac artery: While the uterine artery branches from the internal iliac artery, careful surgical technique typically avoids injury to the main trunk, which lies deeper and more laterally compared to the ureter’s close path with the uterine artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ureter runs beneath the uterine artery in the pelvis, making it the most vulnerable structure to injury during uterine artery ligation in hysterectomy procedures.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman is evaluated for a firm thyroid mass detected during a routine examination. Laboratory studies reveal normal thyroid function tests. Fine-needle aspiration cytology is shown below. Immunohistochemical staining is positive for chromogranin and synaptophysin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Medullary thyroid cancer

 

  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) arises from parafollicular C cells of the thyroid, which are derived from the neural crest. 
  • These cells produce calcitonin and are neuroendocrine in origin. As a neuroendocrine tumor, MTC typically shows immunoreactivity for neuroendocrine markers such as chromogranin and synaptophysin. 
  • The amyloid seen in the stroma is due to calcitonin deposition.
  • This tumor can occur sporadically or as part of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN 2A or MEN 2B) due to RET proto-oncogene mutations.
  • Identification of neuroendocrine markers in a thyroid mass is a strong clue toward medullary thyroid carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Follicular thyroid cancer: Arises from thyroid follicular cells and spreads hematogenously. It does not express neuroendocrine markers such as chromogranin or synaptophysin and is instead characterized by capsular and vascular invasion.

 

Option C. Anaplastic thyroid cancer: An undifferentiated tumor that occurs mostly in elderly patients with rapidly enlarging thyroid masses. It is highly aggressive and shows pleomorphic giant cells but lacks neuroendocrine differentiation.

 

Option D. Papillary thyroid cancer: The most common thyroid malignancy, associated with Orphan Annie eye nuclei, nuclear grooves, and psammoma bodies. It does not arise from C cells and does not express neuroendocrine markers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medullary thyroid carcinoma is a neuroendocrine tumor of parafollicular C cells that stains positive for chromogranin and synaptophysin and contains amyloid deposits derived from calcitonin.

choices.text: Schizophrenia typically shows an insidious onset and chronic course in most cases.
Presence of negative symptoms is associated with a poorer prognosis.
Good premorbid personality and acute onset are favorable prognostic indicators.
Suicide risk is negligible once positive symptoms are controlled.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the course of schizophrenia is not true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Suicide risk is negligible once positive symptoms are controlled.

 

  • This statement is not true. 
  • Individuals with schizophrenia continue to have a significant risk of suicide even after positive symptoms (e.g., hallucinations, delusions) are controlled. 
  • Suicide often occurs during periods of relative insight, especially in early stages, or due to depressive symptoms, social isolation, or loss of functioning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Schizophrenia typically shows an insidious onset and chronic course in most cases: This is true, especially in paranoid and disorganized subtypes, and is often associated with poorer outcomes.

 

Option B. Presence of negative symptoms is associated with a poorer prognosis: True. Negative symptoms such as avolition, anhedonia, and social withdrawal are more persistent and disabling, and less responsive to treatment.

 

Option C. Good premorbid personality and acute onset are favorable prognostic indicators: True. Other favorable factors include female gender, older age of onset, good social support, and predominantly positive symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Suicide risk in schizophrenia remains significant despite symptom control, and monitoring for suicidality is essential throughout the course of illness.
  • Insight, depressive features, and social loss can all contribute to suicidal behavior in these patients.

choices.text: Exposing the body to rule out hidden injuries
CT abdomen to identify intra-abdominal bleeding

questions.text: A 48-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. On arrival, he is hemodynamically unstable. During the primary survey of trauma management, which of the following is not included?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CT abdomen to identify intra-abdominal bleeding

 

  • CT scanning is part of the secondary survey and is not included in the primary survey. 
  • The primary survey focuses on immediate life-threatening conditions using the ABCDE approach (Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure).
  • CT requires patient stability, which is not a priority until after resuscitation and stabilization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Measuring blood pressure: This is part of assessing circulation in the primary survey. Monitoring vital signs such as blood pressure and pulse is essential to evaluate hemodynamic status and guide resuscitation.

 

Option B. Exposing the body to rule out hidden injuries: This belongs to the “E” (Exposure/Environment control) in the ABCDE protocol. Complete exposure is necessary to identify concealed injuries, but care must be taken to prevent hypothermia with warming measures.

 

Option D. Checking airway patency: This is the first step (“A” in ABCDE) of the primary survey. Ensuring airway patency with cervical spine protection is critical because airway obstruction is an immediate life threat.

 

Educational Objective:


The primary survey in trauma management follows the ABCDE approach—airway, breathing, circulation, disability, and exposure—while advanced imaging such as CT scans is reserved for the secondary survey after stabilization.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child in hypovolemic shock arrives at the emergency department, and intravenous access cannot be established despite multiple attempts. The team proceeds with the procedure shown in the image. What is this technique?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intraosseous access

 

  • Intraosseous (IO) access involves inserting a rigid, large-bore needle into the bone marrow cavity, most commonly into the proximal tibia (just below the tibial tuberosity). 
  • It provides rapid access for fluid and drug administration in emergency situations when venous access is difficult or impossible. 
  • It is especially valuable in pediatric resuscitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central venous line: Central venous access is achieved by inserting a catheter into large central veins such as the internal jugular or subclavian vein. While effective, it takes longer, requires expertise, and is not the first choice in critical emergencies when rapid access is needed.

 

Option B. Central arterial line: Arterial lines are used for continuous blood pressure monitoring and frequent arterial blood sampling, not for resuscitation fluid or drug delivery. They are not used as a substitute for IV access in emergencies.

 

Option C. Peripheral venous access: Peripheral IV cannulation is the first-line approach for drug and fluid delivery. However, in cases of severe shock, dehydration, or collapsed veins, establishing a peripheral IV may be extremely difficult, making IO access the faster and safer option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intraosseous access provides a rapid and reliable alternative for drug and fluid administration in emergencies, especially in children when intravenous access is difficult.

questions.text: After administration of a neuromuscular blocker, a patient suddenly develops flushing of the face and becomes hypotensive. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Atracurium

 

  • Atracurium is associated with histamine release, leading to flushing, hypotension, and sometimes bronchospasm.
  • This reaction is dose-related and more common with rapid injection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rocuronium: Minimal histamine release, primarily causes tachycardia at higher doses.

 

Option B. Vecuronium: Cardiovascularly stable, does not cause histamine release.

 

Option D. Cisatracurium: A stereoisomer of atracurium, but without significant histamine release.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Among non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers, atracurium causes histamine release, leading to flushing and hypotension.

questions.text: A 63-year-old postmenopausal woman is on estrogen therapy for significant vasomotor symptoms. She has an intact uterus and is otherwise healthy. To most effectively lower her risk of developing endometrial cancer while continuing hormone therapy, which of the following should be added to her regimen?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adding progesterone to estrogen

 

  • In postmenopausal women with an intact uterus, unopposed estrogen therapy increases the risk of endometrial hyperplasia and endometrial carcinoma because estrogen stimulates endometrial proliferation.
  • Adding progesterone to estrogen therapy provides endometrial protection by inducing secretory changes, reducing proliferation, and promoting shedding of the endometrial lining, which lowers cancer risk. 
  • This combined regimen is standard for postmenopausal hormone replacement in women with a uterus.
  • Estrogen-only therapy is reserved for women who have undergone hysterectomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phytoestrogens: Incorrect. Plant-derived estrogens have weak estrogenic activity and do not provide reliable endometrial protection in women on HRT. Their effect is inconsistent and insufficient to mitigate estrogen-induced proliferation.

 

Option C. Tibolone: Incorrect. Tibolone is a synthetic steroid with estrogenic, progestogenic, and androgenic effects. While it may help menopausal symptoms, it is not as well-established as combined estrogen-progesterone therapy for endometrial protection in women on standard estrogen replacement.

 

Option D. Selective estrogen receptor modulator: Incorrect. SERMs have tissue-specific agonist/antagonist activity, but agents like tamoxifen may act as estrogen agonists in the uterus and can actually increase the risk of endometrial cancer. They are not used to protect the endometrium during systemic estrogen therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In postmenopausal women with an intact uterus, adding progesterone to estrogen therapy prevents unopposed estrogen stimulation of the endometrium, thereby reducing the risk of endometrial hyperplasia and carcinoma.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with severe pain and swelling in his great toe. He has a history of high-purine diet and intermittent flares of similar symptoms. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gout

 

 

  • Gout is caused by the deposition of uric acid crystals in a joint, which triggers a severe inflammatory response. 
  • The classic presentation is a sudden, excruciatingly painful attack in the great toe, known as podagra. 
  • A diet high in purines (found in red meat, seafood, and alcohol) can elevate uric acid levels and trigger these flares.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rheumatoid arthritis (RA):

 

  • RA is a chronic autoimmune disease that typically affects multiple joints symmetrically, starting with smaller joints in the hands and feet. 
  • It's not usually limited to a single joint like the great toe and doesn't have a direct link to diet.

 

Option B. Osteoarthritis (OA): 

 

  • OA is a degenerative joint disease caused by the breakdown of cartilage over time. 
  • While it can affect the great toe and cause pain and swelling, it doesn't present with acute, severe flares linked to diet and is more gradual in onset.

 

Option C. Septic arthritis: 

 

  • Septic arthritis is a serious bacterial infection in a joint. 
  • While it can cause an acutely hot, swollen, and painful joint, it is usually accompanied by a fever and systemic signs of infection. 
  • It doesn't have a history of recurrent flares related to diet.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a middle-aged male with recurrent, acute monoarthritis of the great toe and dietary risk factors, gout is the most likely diagnosis. Early recognition can prevent complications and reduce recurrence with lifestyle and pharmacologic interventions.

questions.text: A 15-year-old adolescent has experienced prolonged, irregular menstrual bleeding for over a year. The bleeding episodes last more than a week, with irregular gaps between them. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anovulation

 

  • In the first few years after menarche, irregular and heavy menstrual bleeding is most often due to anovulatory cycles. 
  • This occurs because the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis is still maturing, leading to irregular and inadequate luteinizing hormone (LH) surges.
  • Without ovulation, the corpus luteum does not form, and progesterone is not produced in the luteal phase.
  • In the absence of progesterone, the endometrium continues to proliferate under unopposed estrogen stimulation. 
  • This unstable, overgrown endometrium eventually sheds in an unpredictable and sometimes prolonged manner, causing irregular, heavy bleeding.
  • This patient’s presentation — prolonged bleeding (>7 days), irregular cycles, onset soon after menarche, no pelvic pain, normal exam, and normal imaging — is classic for anovulatory bleeding due to hormonal immaturity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endometriosis: Incorrect. Endometriosis presents with chronic pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, and possibly infertility. It is not a common cause of painless, prolonged bleeding in early adolescence. This patient’s normal exam and absence of pain make endometriosis unlikely.

 

Option B. Uterine malignancy: Incorrect. Uterine cancer is rare in adolescents and typically presents in older women with risk factors such as obesity, chronic unopposed estrogen, or hereditary cancer syndromes. Normal imaging and the patient’s age make this highly improbable.

 

Option D. Bleeding disorder: Incorrect. While conditions like von Willebrand disease can present at menarche with heavy bleeding, they usually have other features such as easy bruising, mucosal bleeding, or prolonged bleeding after injury. This patient’s presentation is better explained by hormonal immaturity and anovulatory cycles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In adolescents within the first few years after menarche, anovulatory cycles due to immaturity of the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis are the most common cause of irregular and heavy menstrual bleeding.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with ischemic cardiomyopathy post-anterior MI in 2009 presents with NYHA class III heart failure symptoms, including dyspnea on mild exertion and rare orthopnea. His heart rate is 60/min, blood pressure 90/60 mmHg, with no JVD, normal heart sounds, clear lungs, and no edema. Medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, furosemide, metoprolol, lisinopril, and spironolactone. ECG is shown and TTE shows LVEF 25%. Which intervention will reduce his mortality risk?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) CRT-D

 

  • The patient has HFrEF (LVEF 25%) with NYHA class III symptoms and LBBB. 
  • CRT improves symptoms and survival in HFrEF with electrical dyssynchrony.
  • ICD reduces sudden cardiac death risk in HFrEF (LVEF ≤35%, NYHA II-III).
  • CRT-D (combined CRT and ICD) is ideal for this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CRT: Improves heart failure but does not address sudden cardiac death risk.

 

Option B. Dual-chamber pacemaker: Does not provide resynchronization or prevent arrhythmias.

 

Option C. ICD: Reduces arrhythmia risk but not heart failure symptoms in LBBB.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • CRT-D reduces mortality in HFrEF with LBBB (QRS >150 ms).
  • CRT improves dyssynchrony; ICD prevents sudden death.
  • NYHA class II-III and LVEF ≤35% guide device therapy.

choices.text: To gain attention, sympathy, or approval from doctors and others.
Desire for financial gain through medical interventions.
Genuine anxiety and overprotectiveness due to parental inexperience.
Delusional thinking, which cause the caregiver to genuinely believe that the child is sick, even when no medical evidence supports the claims.

questions.text: What is the most likely underlying cause of mother’s behaviour in Munchausen Syndrome by Proxy (MSBP)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) To gain attention, sympathy, or approval from doctors and others.

 

  • In Munchausen Syndrome by Proxy (MSBP), the caregiver deliberately fabricates or induces illness in the child primarily to assume the sick role by proxy. 
  • The motivation is psychological—seeking attention, sympathy, or validation from medical staff and others—not material gain or genuine belief.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Desire for financial gain through medical interventions: Financial gain is usually not the primary motive; MSBP is driven by psychological needs rather than monetary benefits.

 

Option C. Genuine anxiety and overprotectiveness due to parental inexperience: Genuine anxiety/overprotectiveness may be present superficially but do not explain the deliberate and deceptive actions seen in MSBP.

 

Option D. Delusional thinking, which cause the caregiver to genuinely believe that the child is sick, even when no medical evidence supports the claims: The caregiver knows the child is not truly sick; it is intentional fabrication, not a false belief or delusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Munchausen Syndrome by Proxy is a form of child abuse characterized by intentional fabrication or induction of illness in a child by a caregiver for psychological benefit, most notably attention and sympathy. 
  • Prompt identification is critical to protect the victim.

choices.text: Using palm on the lower third of sternum
Using two fingers on the middle third of sternum
Using the two thumbs on the lower third of sternum
Using three fingers on the lower third of sternum

questions.text: A term newborn suddenly develops apnea and bradycardia in the delivery room. The team initiates resuscitation, and chest compressions are required. Which technique is considered the most effective for delivering compressions in neonates?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Using the two thumbs on the lower third of sternum

 

  • The two-thumb encircling technique is the preferred method for chest compressions in neonates. 
  • Both thumbs are placed on the lower third of the sternum while the fingers encircle and support the infant’s back. 
  • This method generates higher coronary perfusion pressure and is less tiring for the rescuer, making it the most effective approach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Using palm on the lower third of sternum: This is incorrect because the palm technique is used in adult CPR, not in neonates. Applying a palm on a newborn’s sternum would exert excessive force and risk rib or sternal injury.

 

Option B. Using two fingers on the middle third of sternum: The two-finger technique can be used when a single rescuer is providing compressions, but it is less effective than the two-thumb technique. Also, compressions must be placed on the lower third, not the middle third, to avoid injury to the upper sternum.

 

Option D. Using three fingers on the lower third of sternum: Using three fingers is not a standard technique in neonatal resuscitation. It increases the chance of excessive pressure and instability compared to the recommended two-finger or two-thumb method.

 

Educational Objective:


In neonatal resuscitation, chest compressions should be performed on the lower third of the sternum, with the two-thumb encircling technique being the most effective and recommended method.

questions.text: During sleep cycle analysis with EEG, a sudden large-amplitude waveform called a K-complex is noted. In which stage of sleep is this finding most characteristic?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stage 2 NREM sleep

 

  • Stage 2 NREM sleep constitutes nearly 45% of total sleep time and is characterized by sleep spindles (sudden bursts of high-frequency activity) and K-complexes (sharp, high-amplitude waveforms). 
  • K-complexes play a role in memory consolidation and act as a protective mechanism against arousals from external stimuli.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. REM sleep: REM sleep is associated with beta-like sawtooth waves, rapid eye movements, muscle atonia, and dreaming. K-complexes are not a feature of REM sleep.

 

Option B. Stage 1 NREM sleep: Stage 1 is light sleep and shows theta wave activity (4–7 Hz). It is the transition stage from wakefulness to sleep and does not include K-complexes.

 

Option D. Stage 3 NREM sleep: Stage 3 (deep sleep or slow-wave sleep) is characterized by delta waves (low frequency, high amplitude) and is associated with parasomnias like night terrors and sleepwalking, not K-complexes.

 

Educational Objective:


K-complexes, along with sleep spindles, are the hallmark EEG findings of Stage 2 NREM sleep, the stage that occupies the largest portion of normal sleep.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with untreated hepatitis C presents to the ER with malaise, joint pain, and tea-colored urine for one week. She has ankle swelling, bibasilar lung crackles and the following rash as shown. Her blood pressure is 164/98 mmHg, creatinine is 2.4 mg/dL (baseline 1.2 mg/dL), and C3/C4 levels are decreased. Urinalysis shows 2+ blood and 1+ protein. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cryoglobulinemic glomerulonephritis

 

  • The presentation suggests cryoglobulinemic glomerulonephritis, a complication of chronic hepatitis C.
  • Malaise, joint pain, purpura, and low complement (C3/C4) indicate immune complex deposition.
  • Tea-colored urine and renal impairment (elevated creatinine) reflect glomerulonephritis.
  • Treatment targets hepatitis C and may include immunosuppression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Henoch-Schönlein purpura: Common in children, presents with purpura and normal complement, not linked to hepatitis C.

 

Option C. Hepatorenal syndrome: Occurs in cirrhosis with ascites and jaundice, not present here.

 

Option D. Postrenal AKI: Caused by obstruction, not associated with purpura or low complement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cryoglobulinemic glomerulonephritis is linked to hepatitis C, causing purpura and renal impairment.
  • Low complement levels (C3/C4) suggest immune complex disease.
  • Treating underlying hepatitis C is critical for management.

questions.text: A 55‑year‑old diabetic woman presents with chronic toenail thickening and discoloration. You decide to start topical therapy to avoid systemic drug interactions. Which agent is most appropriate as a nail lacquer in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ciclopirox olamine

 

  • Drugs available for nail lacquer 
    • C – Ciclopirox 
    • E – Efinoconazole 
    • A – Amorophyine 
    • T – Tavaborole 
  • Ciclopirox olamine is a hydroxypyridone antifungal formulated as a nail lacquer for onychomycosis. 
  • Its mechanism involves chelation of polyvalent cations (Fe³⁺, Al³⁺) that are essential for fungal enzyme function, disrupting membrane integrity and fungal metabolism. 
  • The lacquer vehicle allows sustained drug delivery into the nail plate and bed, achieving effective local concentrations without systemic exposure—ideal for patients at risk of drug–drug interactions or with hepatic comorbidities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Caspofungin: It is a systemic drug used for candidiasis and aspergillosis and is not suitable for fungal nail infections.

 

Option C. Fluconazole suspension: Fluconazole is available only in oral formulations (tablet, suspension) for dermatophytosis and candidiasis. No topical or lacquer preparations exist, so it cannot be used directly on the nail.

 

Option D. Itraconazole solution: Itraconazole likewise is only available orally (capsule, solution) for systemic therapy. There is no topical or nail‑lacquer form of itraconazole approved for onychomycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For onychomycosis in patients needing to avoid systemic antifungals, ciclopirox olamine lacquer is the treatment of choice—other formulations either lack nail‑penetrating ability or are oral only.

questions.text: Which phenotypic microbial typing method determines bacterial strain identity based on susceptibility to specific bacteriophages?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bacteriophage typing

 

  • Bacteriophage typing is a phenotypic method of microbial typing based on the principle that bacteriophages (viruses that infect bacteria) have a narrow host range.
  • Specific phages will only infect and lyse particular strains within a bacterial species.
  • A panel of phages is applied to a bacterial isolate, and the pattern of susceptibility (lysis) is recorded to create a phage type profile.
  • It has been historically used in Staphylococcus aureus (especially MRSA surveillance) and Salmonella Typhi outbreak investigations.
  • This method helps track epidemiological links between isolates and is valuable in outbreak investigations despite being slower and less discriminative than genotypic methods.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biotyping:

 

  • Relies on biochemical reactions of the organism (e.g., sugar fermentation, enzyme activity).
  • Example: Corynebacterium diphtheriae (gravis, intermedius, mitis biotypes).
  • Does not involve bacteriophages.

 

Option C. Bacteriocin typing:

 

  • Uses bacterial proteins (bacteriocins/toxins) that inhibit growth of specific (closely-related) strains.
  • Example: Colicin typing for E. coli, pyocin typing for Pseudomonas.
  • Different mechanism than bacteriophage-mediated lysis.

 

Option D. Ribotyping:

 

  • A genotypic method (not phenotypic) involving restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) analysis of ribosomal RNA genes.
  • Requires molecular techniques, not used in classical phenotypic phage testing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Phenotypic → Bacteriophage typing, Bacteriocin typing, Biotyping, Antibiogram typing.
  • Genotypic → Ribotyping, PFGE, PCR-RFLP, AFLP, sequencing, microarrays.
  • Phage typing remains historically important for epidemiology but is increasingly supplemented or replaced by genotypic methods in modern laboratories.

choices.text: Shorter and more horizontal Eustachian tube in infants

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic with a history of repeated ear infections over the past year. The otitis media episodes are attributed to structural differences in the auditory tube compared with adults. Which anatomical feature of the Eustachian tube in young children predisposes them to such infections?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Shorter and more horizontal Eustachian tube in infants

 

  • In infants, the Eustachian tube is anatomically shorter, wider, and more horizontal compared to adults. 
  • These features allow pathogens from the nasopharynx to travel more easily into the middle ear, increasing the risk of otitis media. 
  • The horizontal orientation reduces the efficiency of drainage from the middle ear to the nasopharynx, contributing to fluid accumulation and infection.
  • In contrast, the adult Eustachian tube is longer, narrower, and angled downward, which aids in better drainage and reduces the risk of infections spreading to the middle ear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Narrower lumen in infants: The lumen of the Eustachian tube is narrower in adults, not infants. In infants, the tube is relatively wider, which paradoxically makes it easier for pathogens to spread from the nasopharynx to the middle ear.

 

Option B. Greater length in infants: The Eustachian tube is shorter in infants, not longer. A shorter tube facilitates the rapid spread of infections to the middle ear.

 

Option C. More rigid cartilage in infants: The cartilage of the Eustachian tube is less rigid in infants, which can contribute to functional immaturity. However, this is not the primary factor increasing the risk of otitis media compared to the structural differences in tube length and orientation.

 

Educational Objective:    

 

Infants are at an increased risk for otitis media due to their shorter, more horizontal Eustachian tubes, which facilitate the spread of infections from the nasopharynx to the middle ear.

 

Note: Difference between Eustachian tube Adult Vs Infant

choices.text: A single broad peak spanning from Tuesday to Saturday
Three distinct peaks with the highest peak after Friday's exposure
Three distinct peaks of similar height if the same number of people ate chicken each day
Continuous cases throughout the week without distinct peaks

questions.text: A factory cafeteria served contaminated chicken at lunch on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday of the same week. If the pathogen has an incubation period of 12-24 hours, the epidemic curve would show:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Three distinct peaks of similar height if the same number of people ate chicken each day

 

  • With contaminated chicken served on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday at lunch (approximately 12:00 PM), and an incubation period of 12-24 hours, cases would appear as follows:
    • Monday exposure → Cases appear Tuesday (12 PM Monday + 12-24 hours = Tuesday 12 AM to 12 PM)
    • Wednesday exposure → Cases appear Thursday (similarly timed)
    • Friday exposure → Cases appear Saturday (similarly timed)
  • This creates three distinct peaks on the epidemic curve. 
  • The crucial point is that these peaks would be of similar height only if approximately the same number of people consumed the contaminated chicken each day. 
  • This assumes:
    • Similar cafeteria attendance each day
    • Similar proportion choosing chicken as their meal
    • Same level of contamination in each batch

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Single broad peak spanning from Tuesday to Saturday:

 

  • This would occur if the exposures were so close together that the cases overlapped significantly
  • With 48-hour gaps between exposures (Monday to Wednesday, Wednesday to Friday) and only a 12-24 hour incubation period, the peaks would be distinctly separated, not merged
  • Each cluster of cases would resolve before the next begins

 

Option B. Three distinct peaks with the highest peak after Friday's exposure:

 

  • There's no epidemiological reason why the Friday peak would be highest unless: 
    • More people ate chicken on Friday (perhaps payday or special menu)
    • The contamination level was higher on Friday
    • More susceptible individuals were present on Friday
  • The question doesn't provide any such information, making this assumption unwarranted

 

Option D - Continuous cases throughout the week without distinct peaks:

 

  • This pattern would suggest either: 
    • A continuous common source (contamination available every day)
    • A propagated epidemic with person-to-person transmission
    • An extremely variable incubation period
  • With discrete exposures (Monday, Wednesday, Friday only) and a relatively narrow incubation period (12-24 hours), distinct clustering is expected

 

Educational Objective:

 

In outbreaks with intermittent point-source exposure and short incubation periods, such as foodborne illnesses from cafeteria meals, the epidemic curve typically shows distinct peaks corresponding to each exposure, appearing after the pathogen’s incubation time.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with rectal bleeding and is diagnosed with carcinoma of the colon. He undergoes an extended right hemicolectomy. During surgery, the surgeon uses the instrument shown in the image for tissue dissection and coagulation. Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Monopolar cautery

 

  • Monopolar cautery uses electric current delivered through a single active electrode to cut tissue or achieve hemostasis by coagulation.
  • The current passes from the electrode through the patient’s body and exits via a grounding pad, making it effective for dissection and coagulation during major surgeries such as colectomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ligasure vessel sealing system: Ligasure is a bipolar energy device that permanently fuses vessels and tissue bundles up to 7 mm in diameter. Unlike monopolar cautery, it seals vessels without significant lateral thermal spread, making it particularly useful in vascular pedicle control.

 

 

Option C. Harmonic scalpel: The harmonic scalpel works via ultrasonic vibration (55,000 Hz) to simultaneously cut and coagulate tissues. It generates less heat compared to monopolar cautery, reducing collateral tissue damage. However, the device shown in the image is not a harmonic scalpel.

 

 

Option D. Hyfrecator: A hyfrecator is a low-power electrosurgical device used mainly in dermatology for minor skin lesion removal, warts, and small hemostatic procedures. It is not designed for major intra-abdominal surgeries.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Monopolar cautery is a commonly used electrosurgical instrument in major operations for cutting and coagulation, distinguished from bipolar sealing devices, ultrasonic scalpels, and dermatology-based hyfrecators.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of methotrexate in the treatment of osteosarcoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Competitive inhibitor of dihydrofolate reductase

 

  • The patient’s presentation of a malignant bone tumor in adolescence is consistent with osteosarcoma, for which methotrexate is often part of multi-agent chemotherapy.
  • Methotrexate is a folate analogue that competitively inhibits dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR).
  • DHFR catalyzes the reduction of dihydrofolate (DHF) to tetrahydrofolate (THF), a cofactor required for thymidylate synthase to convert deoxyuridine monophosphate (dUMP) to deoxythymidine monophosphate (dTMP).
  • Inhibiting DHFR leads to decreased THF, blocking the synthesis of thymidylate (pyrimidines) and purines, ultimately inhibiting DNA synthesis.
  • This effect is particularly pronounced in rapidly dividing cells, such as cancer cells, but also accounts for methotrexate’s toxic effects on normal rapidly dividing tissues (e.g., bone marrow, gastrointestinal mucosa).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blocks pyrimidine synthesis: This is a downstream effect of DHFR inhibition (due to reduced thymidylate synthesis), but it is not the primary direct mechanism.

 

Option C. Analog of uridine monophosphate (UMP): Incorrect; UMP analogues include drugs like 5-fluorouracil, which inhibit thymidylate synthase directly, not DHFR.

 

Option D. Blocks purine synthesis: Also occurs secondarily because THF is needed for purine ring formation, but again, the direct target of methotrexate is DHFR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate is a folate analogue that competitively inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, preventing the formation of tetrahydrofolate and thereby impairing thymidylate and purine synthesis, leading to inhibition of DNA replication in rapidly dividing cells.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with progressive enlargement of her hands and feet, coarse facial features, and deepening of the voice. Laboratory testing shows elevated IGF-1 levels, and MRI demonstrates a pituitary macroadenoma. A diagnosis of acromegaly is made. She is planned to start therapy with a long-acting somatostatin analogue administered once monthly to suppress growth hormone secretion. Which of the following drugs is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lanreotide

 

  • This patient has acromegaly from a pituitary macroadenoma, confirmed by elevated IGF-1 and MRI.
  • When surgery is not possible immediately or as adjunctive therapy after surgery, long-acting somatostatin analogues are the preferred medical treatment.
  • Lanreotide is a synthetic somatostatin analogue with high affinity for somatostatin receptor subtype 2, which predominates on pituitary somatotroph cells.
  • By binding these receptors, lanreotide suppresses growth hormone (GH) secretion, which in turn lowers IGF-1 levels, alleviates symptoms, and may shrink tumor size.
  • Lanreotide is formulated for deep subcutaneous or intramuscular injection every 4 weeks, allowing convenient, sustained therapy for acromegaly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Octreotide: Also a long-acting somatostatin analogue and very effective in acromegaly; however, in this scenario lanreotide is chosen. Both share similar mechanisms, but lanreotide may be preferred in certain patients based on formulation, administration route (deep subcutaneous vs intramuscular), or tolerability.

 

Option C. Bromocriptine: A dopamine agonist that can inhibit GH secretion in some pituitary adenomas but is less effective than somatostatin analogues. Generally reserved for adjunctive therapy or when other agents are not tolerated.

 

Option D. Pegvisomant: A GH receptor antagonist that blocks GH action at target tissues, lowering IGF-1 levels without reducing GH or tumor size. Used when somatostatin analogues are inadequate or contraindicated, not typically first-line.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lanreotide is a long-acting somatostatin analogue used in acromegaly to suppress GH secretion, reduce IGF-1 production, and improve clinical symptoms. It is given by deep subcutaneous or intramuscular injection every 4 weeks and is an effective alternative to octreotide LAR.

questions.text:
A 65‑year‑old man with recurrent ventricular tachycardia is being considered for drug therapy. His cardiologist asks you to rank the following agents by their elimination half‑life, from shortest to longest: 

 

  1. Amiodarone
  2. Adenosine
  3. Esmolol
  4. Omeprazole

 

Which of the following sequences is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 → 3 → 4 → 1

 

  • 2. Adenosine has an ultra–short half‑life (< 10 seconds) due to rapid uptake by erythrocytes and endothelial cells, making it the fastest‑onset and offset antiarrhythmic.
  • 3. Esmolol is metabolized by red blood cell esterases, giving it a half‑life of ~9 minutes, ideal for rapid titration in emergencies.
  • 4. Omeprazole has a half‑life around 30 minutes, but its irreversible proton‑pump inhibition produces effects lasting up to 24 hours.
  • 1. Amiodarone is highly lipophilic, accumulates in tissues, and has a half‑life of > 3 weeks (up to 100 days), making it the longest‑acting agent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Compare elimination half‑lives of antiarrhythmics and other cardiovascular drugs -

 

  • Adenosine: Half‑life < 10 s (ultra‑short).
  • Esmolol: Half‑life ~9 min (esterase metabolism).
  • Omeprazole: Half‑life ~30 minutes (irreversible effect).
  • Amiodarone: Half‑life > 3 weeks  (extensive tissue accumulation).

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with chronic kidney failure has been dependent on thrice-weekly hemodialysis for more than a decade. Over the past year, he has developed progressive shoulder stiffness, wrist pain, and numbness in both hands. Physical examination reveals decreased grip strength bilaterally. Imaging of the wrists demonstrates bony cystic lesions, and a biopsy of peri-articular tissue shows amyloid deposits on Congo red staining. Which of the following amyloid types is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Amyloid β₂-microglobulin (Aβ₂M)

 

  • This patient has dialysis-related amyloidosis (DRA), a complication of long-term hemodialysis (commonly after 5–7 years, but risk increases with >10 years of treatment). 
  • The underlying mechanism involves insufficient clearance of β₂-microglobulin, a component of MHC class I molecules that is normally filtered by the kidneys. 
  • In patients with end-stage renal disease, β₂-microglobulin accumulates in the plasma.
  • Conventional dialysis membranes do not effectively remove β₂-microglobulin, allowing it to deposit as amyloid fibrils in osteoarticular structures. 
  • These deposits cause:
    • Chronic arthropathy (shoulder, hip, and knee pain)
    • Carpal tunnel syndrome (median nerve compression)
    • Bone cysts and destructive joint changes
  • Histology shows Congo red–positive deposits with apple-green birefringence under polarized light.
  • The amyloid type here is Aβ₂M, not related to systemic plasma cell dyscrasias or chronic inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amyloid transthyretin (ATTR): In its wild-type form, ATTR causes senile systemic amyloidosis, typically involving the heart (restrictive cardiomyopathy) in elderly patients without chronic dialysis exposure. Hereditary ATTR can also cause neuropathy and cardiomyopathy, but is unrelated to dialysis-associated bone/joint manifestations.

 

Option C. Amyloid associated protein (AA): AA amyloidosis occurs in chronic inflammatory conditions (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, chronic infections, inflammatory bowel disease). It predominantly affects the kidneys (proteinuria, nephrotic syndrome) rather than causing periarticular cysts and carpal tunnel syndrome in dialysis patients.

 

Option D. Amyloid light chain (AL): AL amyloidosis is seen in plasma cell dyscrasias such as multiple myeloma. It causes multisystem involvement (renal, cardiac, neuropathic, gastrointestinal). It is not the cause of amyloid arthropathy in patients with long-term hemodialysis unless they also have a concurrent plasma cell disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dialysis-related amyloidosis is caused by deposition of β₂-microglobulin, a protein that accumulates in end-stage renal disease and is poorly cleared by conventional dialysis membranes. 
  • It typically manifests after years of hemodialysis with chronic arthropathy, carpal tunnel syndrome, and bone cyst formation.

choices.text: Chloroquine is given daily for 3 days, followed by primaquine for 14 days.
Primaquine at 0.25 mg/kg daily for 14 days eradicates the hepatic hypnozoites.
The combined blood and liver‑stage therapy is completed in 14 days.
In regions with chloroquine resistance (like Assam), an ACT replaces chloroquine, but the primaquine regimen is unchanged.

questions.text: A 25‑year‑old man returns from a business trip in Assam. He is diagnosed with uncomplicated Plasmodium vivax malaria. Which of the following is false regarding treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chloroquine is given daily for 3 days, followed by primaquine for 14 days.

 

  • Chloroquine is given daily for 3 days, followed by primaquine for 14 days. Incorrect. Because primaquine is not given after finishing chloroquine, but started concurrently from day 1.
  • Treatment of vivax malaria requires two components:
    1. Blood schizonticidal therapy – To clear parasites from blood. Traditionally, chloroquine is given for 3 days (unless chloroquine resistance, where ACT is used).
    2. Anti-relapse therapy (radical cure) – To eradicate dormant liver hypnozoites and prevent relapse. This is done with primaquine at 0.25 mg/kg daily for 14 days.
  • Important: Primaquine is started from day 1 along with chloroquine (or ACT) and continued daily for 14 days.
  • Thus, the entire course is completed in 14 days, not sequentially in 17 days.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Primaquine at 0.25 mg/kg daily for 14 days eradicates the hepatic hypnozoites: True. This is the standard radical cure regimen recommended by WHO and India.

 

Option C. The combined blood and liver stage therapy is completed in 14 days: True. Chloroquine ends in 3 days, primaquine continues up to day 14 → total = 14 days.

 

Option D. In regions with chloroquine resistance (like Assam), an ACT replaces chloroquine, but the primaquine regimen is unchanged: True. The blood schizonticide is changed, but primaquine (liver stage therapy) remains same.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In chloroquine-resistant P. vivax regions such as Assam, ACT is used for blood-stage clearance, and primaquine 0.25 mg/kg daily for 14 days is added for hypnozoite eradication. Chloroquine is avoided in resistant areas.

questions.text: Which of the following mechanoreceptors, located in glabrous (non-hairy) skin, are encapsulated, rapidly adapting, and specialized for detecting low-frequency vibration and fine touch?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Meissner's corpuscles

 

  • Meissner’s corpuscles are encapsulated; rapidly adapting mechanoreceptors found in glabrous skin such as fingertips, lips, and palms.
  • They detect light touch and low-frequency vibrations, providing fine tactile discrimination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pacinian corpuscles: These are also encapsulated and rapidly adapting, but they respond to high-frequency vibration and deep pressure, not low-frequency vibration. They are located deeper in the dermis and subcutaneous tissue.

 

Option C. Merkel’s disks: Merkel’s cells are slowly adapting receptors with small receptive fields. They are responsible for sensing sustained pressure and fine touch, not vibration.

 

Option D. Ruffini’s endings: These are slowly adapting receptors with large receptive fields, responding to sustained pressure, stretch, and skin deformation, rather than vibration.

 

Educational Objective:


Meissner’s corpuscles, located in glabrous skin, are encapsulated, rapidly adapting receptors that detect low-frequency vibration and fine touch, distinguishing them from Pacinian (high-frequency vibration), Merkel (pressure), and Ruffini (stretch).

questions.text: A national task force is developing guidelines for long-term rehabilitation after a pandemic. Because the experts are widely dispersed, the process involves multiple rounds of structured questionnaires, with feedback provided anonymously after each round until consensus is reached. Which of the following study or decision-making methods best fits this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Delphi Method

 

  • Delphi Method is a structured communication technique often used for policy-making and guideline development.
  • Features:
    • Involves experts geographically separated.
    • Uses iterative rounds of anonymous feedback.
    • Reduces influence of dominant personalities (anonymity).
    • Repeats until consensus is reached.
  • Ideal in public health, forecasting, and policy consensus, especially when face-to-face discussion is impractical.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nominal Group Technique: Experts meet face-to-face, ideas are listed, discussed, and ranked. Not anonymous, and less practical for dispersed groups.

 

Option B. Cross-sectional expert interview: Single-round interviews without iteration or consensus building. Does not allow structured refinement.

 

Option D. Cohort consensus method: Not a standard methodology — distractor option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Delphi Method is the best approach when geographically dispersed experts need to reach consensus through multiple anonymous, iterative rounds. 
  • In contrast, Nominal Group Technique is face-to-face, and cross-sectional interviews lack iterative consensus.

questions.text: A 15-year-old adolescent is evaluated for absence of menstruation since puberty onset. She has a normal female body habitus, no breast development, and pubic hair is absent. Laboratory studies reveal markedly elevated follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH) levels. Karyotype analysis shows 46, XX. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gonadal dysgenesis

 

  • Gonadal dysgenesis in a 46, XX individual refers to nonfunctional streak gonads that fail to produce sufficient estrogen. 
  • This leads to absent breast development (absent thelarche) and primary amenorrhea despite normal female external genitalia and normal stature.
  • The elevated FSH and LH indicate hypergonadotropic hypogonadism — the pituitary increases gonadotropin secretion due to lack of negative feedback from estrogen.
  • In 46, XX gonadal dysgenesis, pubic and axillary hair are present because adrenal androgens still stimulate hair growth.
  • Key features in this case:
    • Primary amenorrhea
    • Normal stature
    • Absent breast development
    • Present pubic hair
    • High FSH/LH (hypergonadotropic)
    • 46, XX karyotype

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Testicular feminization syndrome (Androgen insensitivity syndrome): Incorrect. Patients are 46, XY with androgen receptor defects, have normal breast development due to peripheral aromatization of androgens to estrogens, but absent or sparse pubic/axillary hair; not consistent with this patient’s 46, XX karyotype and present pubic hair.

 

Option C. Turner syndrome: Incorrect. Turner syndrome presents with 45, X karyotype, short stature, webbed neck, streak ovaries, and typically coarctation of the aorta. This patient has normal stature and 46, XX karyotype.

 

Option D. Kallmann syndrome: Incorrect. This is hypogonadotropic hypogonadism due to GnRH deficiency, associated with anosmia. Laboratory profile shows low or normal FSH and LH, not elevated values as in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

46, XX gonadal dysgenesis presents with primary amenorrhea, absent breast development, normal stature, present pubic hair, and elevated FSH/LH due to nonfunctional ovaries (hypergonadotropic hypogonadism).

choices.text: Typically arises in adolescents and young adults of both sexes
Frequently linked to chronic hepatitis B virus infection
Generally associated with a more favourable survival rate than conventional HCC
Characteristically presents as a firm, fibrous liver mass on gross examination

questions.text: Which of the following features is least likely to be associated with the fibrolamellar subtype of hepatocellular carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Frequently linked to chronic hepatitis B virus infection

 

  • The fibrolamellar variant of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is a rare subtype that differs from conventional HCC in both epidemiology and prognosis.
  • It typically affects young males and females without underlying liver disease or cirrhosis.
  • A key distinguishing feature is that it is not associated with hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection or other chronic viral hepatitis. 
  • Therefore, the statement “frequently linked to chronic hepatitis B virus infection” is incorrect and represents the least likely association.
  • Patients often have a better prognosis compared to conventional HCC, partly because of the absence of significant underlying liver disease and the tumor’s tendency to remain localized for longer.
  • On gross pathology, fibrolamellar carcinoma is a hard, scirrhous tumor with fibrous lamellae surrounding tumor cells.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Typically arises in adolescents and young adults of both sexes: This is correct for fibrolamellar HCC. Unlike conventional HCC, which usually occurs in older adults with cirrhosis, this variant affects younger patients without significant liver disease.

 

Option C. Generally associated with a more favorable survival rate than conventional HCC: True. Prognosis is better, often because surgical resection is more feasible due to lack of background cirrhosis and later onset of metastasis.

 

Option D. Characteristically presents as a firm, fibrous liver mass on gross examination: Correct. The tumor has abundant fibrous stroma arranged in parallel lamellae, giving it a firm, scirrhous consistency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fibrolamellar HCC occurs in young adults without chronic hepatitis or cirrhosis, has a better prognosis than typical HCC, and is not associated with hepatitis B virus infection.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presents with progressive abdominal distension, pedal edema, and exertional dyspnea. He emigrated from India 10 years ago. Chest CT is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Constrictive pericarditis

 

  • The CT image shows dense pericardial calcification surrounding the heart — a hallmark of chronic constrictive pericarditis. 
  • In TB-endemic areas, healed tuberculous pericarditis is a common cause. This rigid pericardium limits diastolic filling and causes signs of right heart failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Restrictive cardiomyopathy: Restrictive cardiomyopathy has normal pericardium on imaging; pathology is myocardial.

 

Option C. Pericardial effusion: Pericardial effusion appears as fluid collection without calcification.

 

Option D. Dilated cardiomyopathy: Dilated cardiomyopathy shows enlarged ventricular chambers, not a calcified pericardium.

 

Educational Objective:


Dense pericardial calcification on CT is diagnostic of chronic constrictive pericarditis in the right clinical setting.

questions.text: Based on the LPCB mount image as shown below, identify the microorganism:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fusarium spp.

 

  • Fusarium spp. are saprophytic fungi that can cause opportunistic infections, especially in immunocompromised individuals.
  • Key identifying features on Lactophenol Cotton Blue (LPCB) mount:
    • Hyaline (non-pigmented) septate hyphae
    • Sickle-shaped (canoe-shaped) macroconidia — multi-septate, characteristic for Fusarium
    • Chlamydospores — thick-walled, round resting spores seen along the hyphae

 

 

  • Clinical significance:
    • In immunocompetent individuals → keratitis in contact lens wearers, onychomycosis.
    • In immunocompromised (especially neutropenic) → angioinvasive disease with pulmonary, sinus, or disseminated infection.
  • Treatment: Liposomal amphotericin B, voriconazole, or posaconazole

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candida albicans: Appears as budding yeast with pseudohyphae, not septate hyphae with sickle-shaped macroconidia. LPCB mount not used for yeast identification; germ tube test is more specific for C. albicans.

 

Option B. Aspergillus fumigates: Shows uniform septate hyphae branching at acute angles (~45°) and conidial heads, not sickle-shaped macroconidia.

 

Option D. Trichophyton rubrum: A dermatophyte producing pencil-shaped macroconidia and numerous microconidia along with hyphae, but not fusiform sickle-shaped macroconidia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In mycology, morphology under LPCB mount is critical for genus-level identification.
  • Fusarium → hyaline septate hyphae + sickle-shaped macroconidia + chlamydospores is diagnostic. 
  • Misidentification can delay antifungal therapy in high-risk immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman has her blood sampled on day 20 of her menstrual cycle for hormone analysis. The clinician wants to confirm whether she has had an ovulatory cycle. Which hormone level is the most reliable indicator?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Progesterone

 

  • Serum progesterone is the most reliable marker of ovulation. 
  • After ovulation, the corpus luteum forms and secretes progesterone, which rises in the luteal phase and peaks around day 20–22 of the cycle. 
  • High progesterone levels confirm that ovulation has occurred.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FSH: Follicle-stimulating hormone rises in the early follicular phase and helps in follicular recruitment, but its level cannot reliably confirm ovulation.

 

Option B. LH: Luteinizing hormone shows a surge about 24–36 hours before ovulation, triggering follicular rupture. However, by day 20, LH levels have already fallen, making it an unreliable marker for confirming ovulation retrospectively.

 

Option C. Estradiol: Estradiol levels rise during the follicular phase and peak just before ovulation, but they decline afterward. Hence, estradiol cannot confirm ovulation at day 20.

 

Educational Objective:


Serum progesterone measurement in the mid-luteal phase (around day 20–22) is the best laboratory marker to confirm that ovulation has occurred in a menstrual cycle.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman reports irregular menstrual cycles and progressive coarse hair growth on her chin and upper lip. Pelvic ultrasound shows bilaterally enlarged ovaries with multiple peripheral cysts. Which of the following laboratory patterns is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) LH > FSH

 

  • This patient’s presentation — irregular menses, hirsutism, and ultrasound evidence of bilateral enlarged ovaries with multiple small cysts — is characteristic of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).
  • In PCOS, there is increased luteinizing hormone (LH) secretion relative to follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), often with an LH:FSH ratio ≥ 2:1. (normal FSH:LH = 3:1)
  • Elevated LH stimulates ovarian theca cells to produce excess androgens, contributing to hirsutism. The relative deficiency of FSH impairs follicular development, leading to anovulation and irregular cycles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Both FSH and LH decreased: Incorrect. This pattern is seen in hypothalamic or pituitary suppression (e.g., functional hypothalamic amenorrhea), not in PCOS.

 

Option C. Both FSH and LH elevated: Incorrect. This suggests primary ovarian insufficiency (hypergonadotropic hypogonadism), which presents with menopausal symptoms in women <40 years old, not with hirsutism and cystic ovaries.

 

Option D. FSH > LH: Incorrect. This is not typical for PCOS and may be seen in conditions such as ovarian failure or perimenopause. In PCOS, LH is higher than FSH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Polycystic ovary syndrome is characterized by increased LH relative to FSH, leading to hyperandrogenism, menstrual irregularity, and polycystic ovarian morphology.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after suddenly developing difficulty walking and weakness on the right side of his body. Examination reveals impaired proprioception on the right and tongue deviation toward the left. Which of the following arteries is most likely occluded?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anterior spinal artery

 

  • The anterior spinal artery supplies the medial medulla, including the corticospinal tract, medial lemniscus, and hypoglossal nerve fibers. 
  • An infarct here produces medial medullary syndrome, characterized by:
    • Contralateral weakness (due to corticospinal tract involvement)
    • Contralateral loss of proprioception and vibration sense (due to medial lemniscus involvement)
    • Ipsilateral tongue weakness with deviation toward the lesion (due to hypoglossal nerve involvement)
  • In this patient, right-sided weakness and loss of proprioception indicate contralateral tract involvement, while tongue deviation to the left suggests ipsilateral hypoglossal nerve damage — a classic presentation of anterior spinal artery occlusion affecting the left medulla.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior spinal artery: Supplies the dorsal columns of the spinal cord. Infarction here causes ipsilateral loss of proprioception, vibration, and fine touch below the lesion level, but does not involve the hypoglossal nerve or cause contralateral motor weakness, making it inconsistent with this case.

 

Option C. Basilar artery: Occlusion often produces “locked-in” syndrome due to pontine infarction, with quadriplegia and preserved consciousness, rather than isolated medial medullary findings. Tongue deviation and selective contralateral sensory/motor loss are not characteristic.

 

Option D. Posterior inferior cerebellar artery: Supplies the lateral medulla and inferior cerebellum. Infarction results in lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome, which features loss of pain/temperature sensation, dysphagia, hoarseness, and vertigo, but not medial lemniscus or hypoglossal nerve involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anterior spinal artery occlusion affecting the medulla causes medial medullary syndrome with contralateral weakness, contralateral loss of proprioception, and ipsilateral tongue deviation toward the lesion.

questions.text: Match the following population pyramid shapes with their corresponding demographic interpretations:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-B, 2-A, 3-D, 4-C

 

  • 1. Broad base, narrow top → B (High fertility, low life expectancy):
    Characteristic of expansive pyramids, typical of developing countries with high birth rates and shorter lifespan.
  • 2. Spindle-shaped, bulge in the middle → A (Developed country with balanced age structure):
    Reflects more adults, typical of industrialized nations where birth and death rates are both low.
  • 3. Taller span → D (High life expectancy):
    A taller pyramid means more people survive to older ages, indicating better healthcare and longevity.
  • 4. Asymmetric left-right structure → C (Skewed sex ratio):
    Symmetric pyramids suggest a balanced sex ratio; asymmetry signals gender imbalance, often from selective practices or conflict.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Population pyramid shapes convey demographic meaning: broad bases signal high fertility; tall spans indicate high life expectancy; symmetry reflects sex ratio; and bulges in the middle are typical of adult-heavy, stable populations.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with sudden-onset left flank pain radiating to the groin, associated with nausea and hematuria. Physical examination reveals left costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis confirms microscopic hematuria. You suspect a small renal calculus. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for confirming the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Low dose non-enhanced CT

 

  • For suspected renal calculi, non-contrast CT of the kidneys, ureters, and bladder (CT KUB) is the gold standard. 
  • It has nearly 100% sensitivity and specificity for detecting stones of all compositions (except very rare matrix or indinavir stones).
  • Low-dose protocols significantly reduce radiation exposure while maintaining high diagnostic accuracy, making low dose non-enhanced CT the preferred choice, especially for small stones.
  • Contrast is avoided because it can obscure stones and interfere with density measurement.
  • High-dose protocols are unnecessary unless image quality is poor or in obese patients where standard low dose may not be sufficient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B.  High dose non-enhanced CT: Accurate, but higher radiation dose without benefit in most patients.

 

Option C. Low dose enhanced CT:  Contrast may obscure stones, so enhancement is not used for initial diagnosis.

 

Option D. High dose enhanced CT:  Combines unnecessary high radiation and contrast, not recommended for primary stone detection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Low dose non-contrast CT KUB is the investigation of choice for suspected renal calculi, offering high accuracy with minimal radiation exposure.

 

Note – Low Dose non-enhanced CT (LDCT) also used for Screening of Ca Lung

choices.text: Low PEEP and high tidal volume
High PEEP and low tidal volume
High tidal volume with prolonged expiratory pause

questions.text: A patient with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) has a PaO₂/FiO₂ ratio of less than 100, indicating severe ARDS. What is the next appropriate ventilatory strategy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) High PEEP and low tidal volume

 

  • In severe ARDS, the cornerstone is lung-protective ventilation. 
  • This involves low tidal volume (≈6 mL/kg predicted body weight) to minimize volutrauma and higher PEEP to prevent alveolar collapse and improve oxygenation.
  • This strategy improves survival and reduces ventilator-induced lung injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low PEEP and high tidal volume: Contraindicated, as high tidal volumes worsen barotrauma and volutrauma.

 

Option C. High tidal volume with prolonged expiratory pause: High tidal volume is harmful in ARDS. Prolonged expiratory pause is not a standard ARDS strategy.

 

Option D. Immediate prone positioning: Proning is helpful as an adjunct in severe ARDS, but the primary ventilatory strategy remains low tidal volume with high PEEP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of severe ARDS requires lung-protective ventilation with low tidal volumes and high PEEP to improve oxygenation and minimize ventilator-induced lung injury.

 

Note – A. Criteria for Lung-Protective Ventilation (ARDSnet protocol):

choices.text: Stop Ramipril and monitor blood pressure

questions.text: A 32-year-old obese woman with well-controlled hypertension on ramipril presents for an annual visit, planning to conceive. In addition to prescribing a prenatal folate, what is the most appropriate antihypertensive adjustment?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Substitute labetalol for Ramipril

 

  • Ramipril (ACE inhibitor) is contraindicated in pregnancy due to risks of fetal malformations and renal failure.
  • Labetalol is a first-line antihypertensive in pregnancy, safe and effective.
  • Blood pressure may rise later in pregnancy, necessitating active management.
  • Other safe options include methyldopa and nifedipine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stop Ramipril and monitor blood pressure: Uncontrolled hypertension risks preeclampsia; a safe antihypertensive is needed.

 

Option B. Substitute hydrochlorothiazide for lisinopril: Not first-line in pregnancy due to volume depletion risks.

 

Option D. Substitute spironolactone for Ramipril: Contraindicated due to anti-androgenic effects on the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • ACE inhibitors are contraindicated in pregnancy due to teratogenicity.
  • Labetalol is the preferred antihypertensive for pregnant women.
  • Monitor blood pressure closely during pregnancy to prevent complications.

choices.text: Deposition of environmental particles in the basal alveoli
Greater perfusion and accumulation of neutrophil-derived proteases in the lung bases
Reduced surfactant synthesis in dependent alveoli
Preferential alveolar wall injury from high oxygen tension in apical segments

questions.text: A 29-year-old non-smoking man presents with progressive dyspnea over the past year. Pulmonary examination reveals decreased breath sounds and prolonged expiration. High-resolution CT scan of the chest shows diffuse destruction of the alveoli involving the entire acinus, most prominent in the lower lung zones. Which of the following best explains the anatomic distribution of this patient’s pulmonary findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Greater perfusion and accumulation of neutrophil-derived proteases in the lung bases

 

  • This patient’s presentation — young age, nonsmoker, progressive dyspnea, family history of liver disease, and lower lobe–predominant panacinar emphysema on CT — is classic for α1-antitrypsin (A1AT) deficiency.
  • A1AT is a serine protease inhibitor (SERPIN) that normally neutralizes neutrophil elastase, preventing elastin degradation in alveolar walls.
  • In A1AT deficiency, lack of protease inhibition results in unopposed elastase activity, destroying the entire acinus (panacinar emphysema).
  • The lower lobes are more affected because gravity-dependent perfusion is greater at the lung bases, which means more neutrophils are delivered to these areas. 
  • Increased neutrophil activity leads to higher local protease concentration, causing more elastin degradation and thus lower lobe–predominant emphysema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Deposition of environmental particles in the basal alveoli: Incorrect. Occupational dusts (eg, coal, silica) usually deposit in the upper lobes due to regional ventilation patterns, not the lower lobes. This does not explain lower lobe predominance in A1AT deficiency.

 

Option C. Reduced surfactant synthesis in dependent alveoli: Incorrect. Surfactant is produced by type II pneumocytes throughout the lung and is not selectively reduced in dependent regions. This is unrelated to A1AT deficiency emphysema.

 

Option D. Preferential alveolar wall injury from high oxygen tension in apical segments: Incorrect. High oxygen tension is found in apical alveoli, and when combined with smoking, it explains upper lobe–predominant centriacinar emphysema, not lower lobe panacinar emphysema seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In α1-antitrypsin deficiency, lower lobe–predominant panacinar emphysema occurs due to greater perfusion at the lung bases, which increases delivery of neutrophils and proteolytic enzymes; without A1AT, elastase activity destroys alveolar elastin.

questions.text:
In the aftermath of a coordinated bioterrorism event, emergency responders must rapidly triage exposed individuals based on risk of secondary transmission and public health threat. The following patients present to the triage zone:

  • Patient 1: A 25-year-old school teacher with fever, malaise, and a generalized vesicular rash in different stages of healing.
  • Patient 2: A traveler with high fever, severe headache, back pain, and vomiting and generalized pustular rash where all lesions are at the same stage of development.
  • Patient 3: A middle-aged woman with blurred vision, ptosis, and descending paralysis after eating canned beans.
  • Patient 4: A farmer with acute encephalitis, seizures, and respiratory distress following exposure to sick livestock; one of his close household contacts is also febrile.

Which two patients require the highest level of isolation and containment measures due to secondary transmission potential?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Patients 2 and 4

 

  • Patient 2. A traveler with high fever, severe headache, back pain, and vomiting and generalized pustular rash where all lesions are at the same stage of development (Smallpox): A Category A bioterrorism agent with high person-to-person transmissibility via respiratory droplets and fomites. Requires airborne and contact precautions, negative-pressure room isolation, and immediate public health notification.
  • Patient 4. A farmer with acute encephalitis, seizures, and respiratory distress following exposure to sick livestock; one of his close household contacts is also febrile (Nipah virus): A Category C agent but with documented human-to-human transmission, especially in healthcare settings. Nipah has a high case fatality rate, potential for clusters, and no approved vaccine — making it a critical threat in outbreaks. Strict isolation and containment are essential.
  • Both conditions are severe, contagious, and capable of causing widespread outbreaks, thus prioritized for maximum isolation.

 

Incorrect statement:

 

Patient 1. Patient 1: A 25-year-old school teacher with fever, malaise, and a generalized vesicular rash in different stages of healing (varicella): Incorrect. Vesicular rash in different healing stages. Contagious but relatively mild compared to smallpox.

 

Patient 3. A middle-aged woman with blurred vision, ptosis, and descending paralysis after eating canned beans (Botulism): Incorrect. Not contagious. Caused by pre-formed neurotoxin, not by infection. Requires supportive care, not containment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In bioterrorism events, prioritize isolation for agents capable of person-to-person transmission, especially smallpox (Category A) and Nipah virus (Category C, emerging but transmissible).
  • Agents like anthrax and botulinum toxin, while deadly, do not spread between individuals.

 

Categories of Bio-terrorism Agents:

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about recommended energy needs is correct according to the latest ICMR guidelines? 

 

  1. Adult female doing sedentary work requires 1660 kcal/day.
  2. Additional energy requirement in pregnancy is 520 kcal/day.
  3. Lactating mother in first 6 months requires 600 kcal above baseline.
  4. An adult male doing sedentary work requires 2710 kcal/day.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 and 3 only

 

Statement 1. Adult female doing sedentary work requires 1660 kcal/day: Adult sedentary female = 1660 kcal/day.

 

Statement 3. Lactating mother in first 6 months requires 600 kcal above baseline: Lactating mother (0–6 months) requires +600 kcal/day above baseline 

 

Incorrect statements:

 

Statement 2. Additional energy requirement in pregnancy is 520 kcal/day: Incorrect. Pregnancy requires +350 kcal/day, not 520.

 

Statement 4. An adult male doing sedentary work requires 2710 kcal/day: Incorrect. Adult sedentary male requires 2100 kcal/day, not 2710 (that is for a moderate worker).

 

Educational Objective:

 

From ICMR 2021 RDA guidelines:

 

 

  • Pregnancy: +350 kcal/day
  • Lactation (0–6 m): +600 kcal/day; (6–12 m): +520 kcal/day

questions.text: Identify this instrument used to treat a common endocrinologic problem in children?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Insulin syringe

 

  • An insulin syringe is a 1 mL syringe calibrated in insulin units, typically marked up to 40, 50, or 100 units depending on the type of insulin preparation. 
  • It allows accurate dosing of insulin, which is essential for children with type 1 diabetes to prevent hypoglycemia and maintain metabolic control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tuberculin syringe: A tuberculin syringe is also 1 mL but is calibrated in milliliters, not insulin units. It is primarily used for intradermal tests such as the Mantoux test for tuberculosis, not for insulin administration.

 

Option C. Glucometer: A glucometer is a handheld device used to measure blood glucose levels from a finger-prick sample. While crucial in diabetes management, it does not deliver insulin.

 

Option D. Infusion pump: An infusion pump (such as an insulin pump) delivers continuous subcutaneous insulin infusion. It is an alternative to insulin syringes but is more expensive and typically used in patients requiring intensive glucose control.

 

Educational Objective:


An insulin syringe is a calibrated device specifically designed for accurate insulin administration, essential in managing type 1 diabetes mellitus in children.

choices.text: Tunga penetrans – gravid female burrows into skin
Sarcoptes scabiei – mite burrows into skin
Leishmania braziliensis – transmitted by sandfly bite
Dracunculus medinensis – released from blister into water

questions.text: A 32-year-old traveller returns from rural Brazil with painful, itchy ulcers on the soles of his feet. On examination, there are small, raised nodules with central black dots. Which of the following best describes the causative organism and mode of infestation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tunga penetrans – gravid female burrows into skin

 

  • Tungiasis is caused by Tunga penetrans, the smallest known flea (~1 mm in size).

 

 

  • Gravid females penetrate the epidermis, usually on the feet, where they feed, enlarge, and lay eggs.
  • The resulting lesions are pruritic and can ulcerate, sometimes complicated by bacterial infection.

 

 

  • Endemic in Latin America (especially Brazil) and Sub-Saharan Africa; often seen in travelers returning from these regions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sarcoptes scabiei– mite burrows into skin: Causes scabies, characterized by white burrows in interdigital spaces, wrists, and genital areas; lesions are thin, wavy lines, scaly and itchy not localized ulcerated nodules with central black dots.

 

 

 

Option C. Leishmania braziliensis – transmitted by sandfly bite:  Causes cutaneous leishmaniasis via sandfly bites; presents as painless ulcers with indurated borders, not flea-induced nodules.

 

 

Option D. Dracunculus medinensis – released from blister into water: Guinea worm present in cyclops fish; presents with painful blister on lower limb, releasing larvae when submerged in water, not via flea burrowing.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tunga penetrans infestation (tungiasis) occurs when gravid female fleas burrow into the skin—commonly on the feet—causing pruritic nodules with central black dots. 
  • Endemic in rural Latin America and Sub-Saharan Africa, often linked to walking barefoot in infested areas.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman reports absence of menstruation for 6 months after undergoing dilation and curettage for heavy bleeding following a miscarriage. Her physical examination is normal. Laboratory testing shows an FSH level of 6 mIU/mL. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Uterine synechiae

 

  • This patient most likely has Asherman syndrome, characterized by uterine synechiae (intrauterine adhesions) that develop after procedures involving uterine instrumentation, such as dilation and curettage (D&C), particularly when performed after pregnancy events like spontaneous abortion or postpartum hemorrhage.
  • Intrauterine adhesions replace healthy endometrium with scar tissue, leading to partial or complete obliteration of the uterine cavity. 
  • This prevents normal cyclic endometrial growth and shedding, resulting in secondary amenorrhea.
  • Her normal FSH level (6 mIU/mL) indicates preserved ovarian function and intact hypothalamic-pituitary signaling, which helps differentiate uterine causes of amenorrhea from ovarian failure or pituitary disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pituitary adenoma: Incorrect. Pituitary adenomas can cause amenorrhea through hormonal changes (e.g., hyperprolactinemia or gonadotropin deficiency) and are often associated with abnormal FSH levels, galactorrhea, headaches, or visual field loss. This patient’s labs and history point to a uterine, not pituitary, cause.

 

Option B. Ovarian failure: Incorrect. Premature ovarian insufficiency results in estrogen deficiency and elevated FSH due to lack of ovarian feedback. This patient’s normal FSH level rules this out.

 

Option D. Hypothyroidism: Incorrect. Hypothyroidism can cause menstrual irregularities via altered prolactin and gonadotropin levels, but patients often present with systemic symptoms such as fatigue, weight gain, constipation, or cold intolerance. This patient’s isolated amenorrhea with normal FSH and history of uterine instrumentation points instead to uterine synechiae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Uterine synechiae (intrauterine adhesions) from prior uterine instrumentation, such as dilation and curettage, can cause secondary amenorrhea with normal FSH levels due to preserved ovarian function.
