questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic with complaints of scalp itching and hair thinning for the past three weeks. Physical examination of scalp surface is as shown below. No pus discharge or regional lymph node enlargement is noted. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Griseofulvin

 

  • Tinea capitis is a common fungal infection of the scalp caused by dermatophytes, mainly Trichophyton and Microsporum species. 
  • It is most common in children, especially in prepubertal age groups, and can present with scaly patches, hair loss, and sometimes inflammatory pustular lesions (kerion formation).
  • Griseofulvin is the first-line treatment for tinea capitis in children due to its fungistatic activity and effectiveness in penetrating the keratinized tissues where dermatophytes reside.
  • Treatment duration is typically 6-8 weeks.
  • Alternative treatments include oral terbinafine, fluconazole, and itraconazole, but griseofulvin remains the preferred choice in pediatric cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Topical corticosteroids: These help reduce inflammation but do not treat the underlying fungal infection.

 

Option C. Fluconazole: Can be used as an alternative but is not the first-line therapy for pediatric tinea capitis.

 

Option D. Selenium sulphide shampoo: Helps in reducing fungal shedding and transmission but does not provide adequate systemic treatment for scalp dermatophyte infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tinea capitis is a superficial fungal infection of the scalp, commonly seen in children. 
  • Griseofulvin is the drug of choice due to its ability to target dermatophytes in hair shafts, with oral terbinafine as an alternative.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child, who has achieved normal motor milestones, presents with delayed speech development. Parents report that he avoids social interaction, struggles with communication, and does not engage in play with peers. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Autism

 

  • Autism spectrum disorder is characterized by impaired social interaction, communication difficulties, and restricted/repetitive behaviors.
  • In this case, the child has delayed speech, difficulty in making friends, and impaired concentration, which are hallmark features of autism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ADHD: Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder primarily presents with inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity. While concentration difficulty is a feature, ADHD does not typically cause social withdrawal, speech delay, or lack of peer interaction as described here.

 

Option C. Mental retardation: Intellectual disability is marked by global developmental delay including motor, language, and adaptive skills. Since this child has normal motor milestones and only selective deficits in speech and social interaction, intellectual disability is less likely.

 

Option D. Specific learning disability: This condition manifests in school-age children who have normal intelligence but specific difficulties in reading, writing, or arithmetic. It is diagnosed later in childhood, not at 3 years of age, and does not present with impaired social interaction.

 

Educational Objective:


Autism spectrum disorder in young children presents with delayed speech, impaired social interaction, and communication difficulties, while motor milestones may remain normal.

questions.text:
Protein synthesis in eukaryotic cells can be inhibited by toxins from certain bacteria. Which of the following toxins exert this effect?

 

  1. Pertussis toxin
  2. Cholera toxin
  3. Pseudomonas aeruginosa exotoxin A
  4. Diphtheria toxin
  5. Shiga toxin
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3, 4 and 5

 

Option 3. Pseudomonas aeruginosa exotoxin A: ADP-ribosylates elongation factor-2 (EF-2), halting protein synthesis in host cells.

 

Option 4. Diphtheria toxin: Also inhibits EF-2 through ADP-ribosylation, leading to cell death.

 

Option 5. Shiga toxin: Produced by Shigella dysenteriae (and Shiga-like toxin from enterohemorrhagic E. coli); inactivates the 60S ribosomal subunit by cleaving a specific adenine from 28S rRNA, blocking protein synthesis.

 

Incorrect Option:

 

Option 1. Pertussis toxin: Incorrect. ADP-ribosylates Gi protein → increases cAMP; mechanism targets signal transduction, not protein synthesis.

 

Option 2. Cholera toxin: Incorrect. ADP-ribosylates Gs protein → increases intracellular cAMP, and cause persistent activation of adenylate cyclase; causes watery diarrhea, not inhibition of protein synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Intubate immediately with an endotracheal tube

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with a history of peanut ingestion presents with sudden unresponsiveness. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Start chest compressions

 

  • A previously responsive child with foreign body aspiration who suddenly becomes unresponsive is presumed to be in cardiac arrest.
  • The priority is to start CPR with chest compressions immediately to restore circulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start back blows: Appropriate for conscious infants with airway obstruction, not for unresponsive children.

 

Option B. Intubate immediately with an endotracheal tube: Airway management comes after starting CPR; immediate compressions take precedence.

 

Option C. Give abdominal thrusts: Not recommended in infants and not appropriate once the child is unresponsive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In an unresponsive child with foreign body aspiration and cardiac arrest, CPR with chest compressions is the immediate next step.

 

Note – Flowchart for managing a complete foreign body (FB) Obstruction

 

Is the person responsive?

 

Yes → Responsive


1. Age < 1 year: Perform 5 chest compressions followed by 5 back blows.

 

 

2. Age ≥ 1 year: Perform the Heimlich maneuver.

 

 

No → Not Responsive

 

1. Start CPR (Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation).

choices.text: Attempt to manually reposition the cord above the presenting part
Continue monitoring and await spontaneous vaginal delivery
Elevate the presenting part and proceed with emergency cesarean section
Perform an amniotomy to confirm the finding

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman in active labor is found to have a cervix dilated to 3 cm and 70% effaced. On vaginal examination, a soft, pulsatile structure is palpated ahead of the presenting fetal part. Fetal heart tracing shows recurrent decelerations. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Elevate the presenting part and proceed with emergency cesarean section

 

  • The scenario describes umbilical cord prolapse, in which the cord descends through the cervix ahead of the presenting fetal part. 
  • The “soft, pulsatile” mass on vaginal examination corresponds to the umbilical cord, and recurrent fetal heart rate decelerations suggest cord compression and compromised fetal oxygenation.
  • The immediate priority is to relieve pressure on the cord and restore fetal oxygen delivery while preparing for definitive delivery. 
  • The most effective intervention is to elevate the presenting part manually (to reduce compression) and proceed with an emergency cesarean section, which is the recommended definitive management in most cases of cord prolapse during labor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Attempt to manually reposition the cord above the presenting part: Incorrect. Repositioning the cord is not recommended because it wastes valuable time and risks worsening cord compression or injury. Manual elevation of the presenting part is safer and faster until cesarean delivery is initiated.

 

Option B. Continue monitoring and await spontaneous vaginal delivery: Incorrect. Expectant management is inappropriate in cord prolapse with evidence of fetal compromise (recurrent decelerations). Delaying delivery risks severe hypoxia and fetal death.

 

Option D. Perform an amniotomy to confirm the finding: Incorrect. Artificial rupture of membranes in suspected cord prolapse is dangerous and unnecessary because the diagnosis is clinical, made by palpation of the cord on vaginal exam. Amniotomy can worsen cord compression and fetal hypoxia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In umbilical cord prolapse with fetal compromise, the next step is to manually elevate the presenting part to relieve cord compression and proceed with an emergency cesarean section for definitive delivery.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with infertility presents with acute-onset urinary retention, history of 6 weeks of amenorrhea and a positive pregnancy test. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her current symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Retroverted uterus

 

  • A retroverted gravid uterus can become impacted in the pelvis during early pregnancy (around 6-12 weeks of gestation), especially in women with pre-existing retroversion. 
  • As the uterus enlarges in early pregnancy, it may be trapped beneath the sacral promontory, compressing the bladder and urethra, resulting in acute urinary retention.
  • The patient’s infertility history, 6 weeks of amenorrhea (suggestive of early pregnancy), and acute urinary retention point strongly toward this diagnosis. 
  • On examination, a retroverted uterus will feel enlarged and tilted backward toward the sacrum. 
  • Prompt recognition is important to prevent complications such as miscarriage or bladder damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pelvic hematocoele: Incorrect. A hematocoele usually results from ruptured ectopic pregnancy or pelvic trauma and presents with pelvic pain and signs of internal bleeding rather than isolated urinary retention.

 

Option C. Carcinoma cervix: Incorrect. Cervical cancer may cause pelvic mass effect or bleeding, but urinary retention in this context is more often a late feature due to advanced local invasion, and it would not present with acute retention and 6 weeks amenorrhea in a reproductive-age woman.

 

Option D. Impacted cervical fibroid: Incorrect. A large cervical fibroid can obstruct the bladder outlet and cause retention, but it is unrelated to early pregnancy status and would present as a firm pelvic mass not associated with recent amenorrhea suggestive of conception.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In early pregnancy, a retroverted uterus can become impacted in the pelvis, compressing the bladder neck and urethra, leading to acute urinary retention.

choices.text: The most common site of occurrence is the posterior triangle of the neck
The lesion is filled with blood
The lesion is due sequestration of lymphatics
It may be associated with Turner’s syndrome

questions.text: A newborn is delivered with a large cystic swelling in the neck that caused difficulty during labor. Regarding this type of swelling, which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The lesion is filled with blood

 

  • Cystic hygroma is a congenital lymphatic malformation filled with serous fluid, may be lymphatic fluid, not blood.
  • It arises due to sequestration of jugular lymph sacs during embryonic development.
  • Thus, describing it as “filled with blood” is false.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The most common site of occurrence is the posterior triangle of the neck: This is correct, as the posterior cervical triangle is the most frequent location, followed by the axilla and other less common sites such as the retroperitoneum and mediastinum. The posterior location often leads to airway compromise in neonates.

 

Option C. The lesion is due sequestration of lymphatics: This is correct because cystic hygroma (cavernous lymphangioma) is composed of multiple cystic spaces filled with clear lymphatic fluid due to lymphatic sequestration. This explains why the swelling is brilliantly transilluminant on examination.

 

Option D. It may be associated with Turner’s syndrome: This is correct, as cystic hygroma has a well-recognized association with chromosomal anomalies such as Turner’s syndrome. In such cases, the swelling may be identified prenatally during ultrasound screening.

 

Educational Objective:


Cystic hygroma is a congenital lymphatic malformation, most commonly located in the posterior triangle of the neck, filled with serous fluid & lymph (not blood), and may be associated with Turner’s syndrome.

questions.text: A 68‑year‑old man with metastatic cancer is maintained on high‑dose morphine but develops refractory opioid‑induced constipation and ileus. You wish to reverse his peripheral gastrointestinal side effects without compromising his central analgesia. Which agent is the most appropriate choice?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Methylnaltrexone

 

  • This patient is having opioid induced constipation
  • Methylnaltrexone is a quaternary ammonium derivative of naltrexone that does not cross the blood–brain barrier.
  • It selectively antagonizes peripheral μ‑opioid receptors in the gastrointestinal tract, restoring normal gut motility and secretion.
  • Because it remains excluded from the CNS, it preserves central opioid analgesia while relieving constipation and ileus.
  • Another drug is Alvimopan

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Naloxone: Readily crosses into the CNS and would reverse both peripheral and central opioid effects, precipitating acute withdrawal and loss of analgesia.

 

Option B. Naltrexone: An oral, long‑acting antagonist that also penetrates the CNS, obliterating analgesia and risking withdrawal; not suitable for targeted peripheral reversal.

 

Option D. Nalmefene: A parenteral antagonist with a longer duration than naloxone, but like naloxone crosses centrally and would negate pain control and provoke withdrawal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When treating opioid‑induced constipation in patients who require ongoing central analgesia, choose a peripherally restricted μ‑antagonist (e.g., methylnaltrexone, naloxegol, naldemedine) to relieve GI side effects without reversing analgesia.

choices.text: Prevents detection bias and expectation effects

questions.text: A clinical trial uses a blinded design to compare two antihypertensives. Which of the following is the primary advantage of this approach in the context of Evidence based medicine?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prevents detection bias and expectation effects

 

  • Blinding is a key methodological tool in clinical trials to reduce bias, particularly detection bias and performance bias. 
  • When both patients and investigators are unaware of the treatment assignment (i.e., double-blinded), the risk of outcomes being influenced by preconceived notions or expectations is minimized. 
  • This helps ensure that differences in outcomes are attributable to the intervention itself, not to biased assessment or differential behavior.
  • In the context of Evidence-Based Medicine, minimizing bias is essential for generating reliable and valid data to guide clinical decisions. 
  • Blinding directly improves internal validity by preventing subjective influence on outcome measurement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Improves statistical power: Statistical power is primarily influenced by sample size and effect size, not by the use of blinding.

 

Option B. Eliminates the need for randomization: Randomization and blinding serve different purposes. Randomization prevents selection bias, while blinding reduces observation and expectation biases. One does not substitute for the other.

 

Option D. Guarantees external validity: External validity (generalizability) depends on how representative the sample and setting are of the real-world population. Blinding does not impact generalizability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blinding in clinical trials minimizes bias by preventing participants and investigators from being influenced by knowledge of treatment assignment, thereby improving internal validity of the study.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical situations most likely indicates the use of this instrument?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Postpartum hemorrhage

 

  • The instrument in the image is an intrauterine balloon tamponade device (e.g., Bakri balloon).
  • It is used to control postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) when initial measures such as uterine massage and uterotonic drugs (oxytocin, misoprostol, carboprost, methylergonovine) are unsuccessful.
  • The balloon is inserted into the uterine cavity and inflated with sterile saline to apply direct pressure to the endometrium, compress bleeding vessels, and promote clot formation. 
  • This is an effective, minimally invasive intervention that can avoid the need for more invasive surgical procedures such as hysterectomy.
  • The most common cause of PPH is uterine atony, but the indication for this device is persistent postpartum hemorrhage regardless of the cause, after initial conservative management has failed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterine inversion: Incorrect. Uterine inversion is treated by manual replacement of the uterus followed by uterotonics; balloon tamponade is not used before correcting the inversion.

 

Option B. Retained placenta: Incorrect. Retained placental tissue must be manually removed or evacuated with curettage; tamponade will not be effective unless the retained tissue is removed first.

 

Option D. Uterine atony: Incorrect as a standalone choice here. While uterine atony is the most common cause of postpartum hemorrhage, the device is indicated for hemorrhage management after atony has failed to respond to uterotonics, so the correct overarching indication remains postpartum hemorrhage.


Educational Objective:

 

A uterine balloon tamponade is used for the control of postpartum hemorrhage unresponsive to uterotonics and massage, by exerting direct pressure inside the uterine cavity to stop bleeding.

choices.text: Ibuprofen 325 mg taken 30 minutes before niacin
Acetaminophen 650 mg taken 30 minutes before niacin

questions.text: A 58‑year‑old woman with mixed hyperlipidemia is started on extended‑release niacin. Despite a low initial dose, she reports intense facial flushing and itching that interfere with her daily activities. Which premedication strategy is most effective in reducing niacin‑induced flushing?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ibuprofen 325 mg taken 30 minutes before niacin 

 

  • Ibuprofen (or low‑dose aspirin) given 30–60 minutes prior to niacin blocks cyclooxygenase in dermal Langerhans cells, preventing the release of prostaglandin D₂ and E₂ that mediate the characteristic vasodilatory flushing and pruritus. 
  • This simple NSAID pre‑treatment is the most reliable method to minimize niacin’s flushing without diminishing its lipid‑lowering benefits.
  • Can give another PG D₂ antagonist which is Laropiprant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acetaminophen 650 mg taken 30 minutes before niacin:
Has minimal peripheral anti‑prostaglandin activity and does not effectively prevent niacin‑induced flushing.

 

Option C. Montelukast 10 mg daily: A leukotriene receptor antagonist; leukotrienes are not the primary mediators of niacin flushing, so montelukast is ineffective.

 

Option D. Ranitidine 150 mg nightly: An H₂‑receptor blocker; histamine is not the main driver of niacin flushing, and H₂ antagonism does not reduce this side effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To improve niacin tolerability, advise patients to take a non‑selective NSAID (e.g., ibuprofen) or aspirin about 30 minutes before niacin to block prostaglandin release and markedly reduce flushing.

choices.text: Heart rate divided by systolic blood pressure
Systolic blood pressure divided by heart rate
Heart rate divided by mean arterial pressure
Heart rate divided by diastolic blood pressure

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the Modified Shock Index (MSI)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Heart rate divided by mean arterial pressure

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • SI is simple and widely used in emergency settings especially for trauma, hemorrhage, and sepsis.
  • MSI incorporates diastolic pressure, making it more reflective of vascular tone and organ perfusion.
  • Studies show MSI may outperform SI in predicting ICU mortality, especially in septic and cardiogenic shock.

choices.text: Regular clinical examination every 3 months during the first year, along with yearly mammogram
MRI and liver function testing every 6 months

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman previously treated with lumpectomy, axillary node dissection, adjuvant chemotherapy, and radiation therapy for estrogen receptor–positive breast carcinoma (tumor size 1.5 cm, with one positive axillary node) is currently on tamoxifen therapy. She presents for routine follow-up care. Which of the following is the most appropriate surveillance strategy for her?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Regular clinical examination every 3 months during the first year, along with yearly mammogram

 

  • Routine follow-up after breast conservation therapy emphasizes careful history and physical examination every 3–6 months during the first 3 years, with the interval gradually extended thereafter.
  • An annual mammogram is recommended, beginning at least 6 months after completion of radiation.
  • This approach allows early detection of recurrence or new primary disease while avoiding unnecessary investigations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Annual bone scan: Bone scans are not recommended for routine surveillance in asymptomatic patients because they have a low yield and can generate false positives. They are reserved for patients with symptoms suggestive of bone metastasis.

 

Option B. Tumor marker assessment every 6 months: Markers such as CA 15-3 or CEA are not advised in routine follow-up because they lack specificity and sensitivity for early recurrence. Their use often results in anxiety and unnecessary investigations without proven benefit in survival.

 

Option D. MRI and LFTs every 6 months: While clinical exams are appropriate, MRI and liver function tests are not recommended as part of routine surveillance. They should only be performed if clinical suspicion arises, such as symptoms suggestive of hepatic metastasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In breast cancer follow-up, the cornerstone of surveillance is periodic clinical examination and annual mammography, while routine use of imaging, laboratory tests, and tumor markers is not recommended unless clinically indicated.

choices.text: Water Reabsorption in the kidney is mediated through V1 receptors
Release of von Willebrand factor (vWF) is mediated via V1 receptors

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding arginine vasopressin is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It produces vasoconstriction

 

  • Vasopressin acts on V1a receptors located in vascular smooth muscle, producing potent vasoconstriction.
  • This mechanism is clinically relevant in conditions such as septic shock, where vasopressin analogs are used to restore vascular tone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Water Reabsorption in the kidney is mediated through V1 receptors: This is incorrect. The major renal action of vasopressin—water reabsorption in the collecting ducts—is mediated through V2 receptors, not V1.

 

Option C. Release of von Willebrand factor is mediated via V1 receptors: This is false. The release of vWF and factor VIII from endothelial cells is mediated by V2 receptors, not V1.

 

Option D. It causes vasodilation: This is incorrect because vasopressin causes vasoconstriction via V1a receptor activation. Vasodilation is not a typical effect of ADH.

 

Educational Objective:


Arginine vasopressin acts via V1 receptors to cause vasoconstriction and via V2 receptors to promote renal water reabsorption and endothelial release of vWF and factor VIII.

choices.text: It fluctuates between –65 mV and –40 mV
It is initiated by zymogen cells
Pacemaker cells are located in the proximal stomach

questions.text: Regarding the basic electrical rhythm (BER) of the gastrointestinal tract, which of the following statements is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It fluctuates between –65 mV and –40 mV

 

  • The gastrointestinal smooth muscle exhibits spontaneous rhythmic fluctuations in membrane potential, known as the basic electrical rhythm (BER).
  • These oscillations range between approximately –65 mV and –45 mV (sometimes simplified as –65 to –40 mV). 
  • BER does not directly cause contraction but provides the electrical baseline upon which spike potentials can trigger smooth muscle contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It is initiated by zymogen cells: This is incorrect. BER is generated by the interstitial cells of Cajal, which act as pacemakers of the gut. Zymogen cells are secretory cells of the gastric glands that release pepsinogen, not involved in rhythm generation.

 

Option C. Pacemaker cells are located in the proximal stomach: This is incorrect because pacemaker cells are absent in the esophagus and proximal stomach. They are located in the distal stomach and small intestine (outer circular muscle near the myenteric plexus), and in the colon at the submucosal border of the circular muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The basic electrical rhythm (BER) of the gastrointestinal tract represents rhythmic membrane potential oscillations between –65 mV and –45 mV, generated by interstitial cells of Cajal, which serve as the pacemakers of gut motility.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with recurrent respiratory infections, failure to thrive, and a loud fixed split second heart sound. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Atrial septal defect (ASD)

 

The clinical features described—recurrent respiratory infections, failure to thrive, and a loud fixed split second heart sound—are classic for Atrial Septal Defect (ASD).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD): VSDs often cause murmurs and can lead to failure to thrive, but recurrent respiratory infections are less typical in VSD unless there's significant pulmonary over circulation. The heart sounds associated with VSD do not typically feature a loud fixed split second heart sound.

 

Option C. Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA): PDA usually presents with a continuous "machinery-like" murmur and can cause respiratory infections and failure to thrive. However, a fixed split second heart sound is not a typical finding for PDA. It’s more likely to cause a continuous murmur heard best at the left infraclavicular area, rather than a specific heart sound alteration like ASD.

 

Option D. Tetralogy of Fallot: Tetralogy of Fallot usually presents with cyanosis (blue skin and mucous membranes) due to right-to-left shunting of blood. This patient, however, does not have the hallmark of cyanosis, which is a feature of Tetralogy of Fallot. The heart sound features also differ: Tetralogy of Fallot is typically associated with a systolic ejection murmur, not a fixed split second heart sound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atrial Septal Defect (ASD) is the most likely diagnosis in this case, especially with the presence of a loud fixed split second heart sound, recurrent respiratory infections, and failure to thrive.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman is evaluated for increasing abdominal distension. Imaging reveals a large ovarian mass with ascites and omental nodularity. Ultrasound shows mixed echogenicity with solid areas, and serum CA-125 is markedly elevated at 990 U/mL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Serous cystadenocarcinoma

 

  • Serous cystadenocarcinoma is the most common malignant epithelial ovarian tumor, particularly in postmenopausal women. 
  • It often presents with ascites, omental caking (metastatic peritoneal spread), and elevated CA-125. 
  • Imaging findings such as solid components within the ovarian mass are suspicious for malignancy.
  • These tumors are known for their aggressive nature and tendency for transcoelomic spread within the peritoneal cavity. 
  • In this patient, the combination of postmenopausal status, large adnexal mass, ascites, omental nodularity, and very high CA-125 strongly supports the diagnosis of serous cystadenocarcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endometrioid tumor: Incorrect. These are less common epithelial ovarian tumors, often associated with endometriosis, and typically present without such extensive peritoneal involvement and extreme CA-125 elevation.

 

Option C. Granulosa cell tumor: Incorrect. These are sex cord-stromal tumors that often secrete estrogen, leading to abnormal uterine bleeding. They are not typically associated with omental caking or markedly elevated CA-125, rather it is associated with raised inhibin marker. The patient presents with post-menopausal bleeding and a solid ovarian mass. 

 

Option D. Mucinous cystadenocarcinoma: Incorrect. While mucinous tumors can be malignant, they are less common than serous types in postmenopausal women. They may present with large masses but are less frequently associated with widespread peritoneal carcinomatosis compared to serous tumors. The markers used are CEA and CA19-9.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a postmenopausal woman with an ovarian mass, ascites, omental caking, and markedly elevated CA-125, the most likely diagnosis is serous cystadenocarcinoma, the most common malignant epithelial ovarian tumor.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with Parkinson’s disease reports that over the past few months, he has been experiencing sudden, uncontrollable flailing and twisting movements of his arms and head a few hours after taking his scheduled levodopa-carbidopa doses. His neurologic exam shows choreiform movements but no significant rigidity or resting tremor during the episode. Which of the following medications would be most effective in controlling these abnormal movements?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Amantadine

 

  • The patient’s presentation—delayed, involuntary choreiform movements occurring after levodopa intake—is consistent with levodopa-induced dyskinesia, a common long-term complication of dopaminergic therapy for Parkinson’s disease. 
  • These movements result from excessive dopaminergic stimulation and altered basal ganglia neurotransmission.
  • Amantadine is effective for levodopa-induced dyskinesia due to:
    • NMDA receptor antagonism, which reduces excitatory glutamate transmission.
    • Modest dopaminergic effects via dopamine release promotion and reuptake inhibition.
  • Extended-release amantadine is specifically approved for levodopa-induced dyskinesia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Safinamide: A selective MAO-B inhibitor that enhances and prolongs levodopa’s effect; may worsen dyskinesia rather than treat it.

 

Option C. Selegiline: Another MAO-B inhibitor with similar effects as safinamide; not used for dyskinesia management.

 

Option D. Valproate: An antiepileptic/mood stabilizer; has no role in managing Parkinson’s dyskinesia and may exacerbate motor symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amantadine is the preferred pharmacologic treatment for levodopa-induced dyskinesia in Parkinson’s disease due to its NMDA antagonism and dopaminergic modulation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old postoperative patient is prescribed a maintenance diet where accurate assessment of protein quality is crucial. The nutritionist considers various protein scoring methods. Which of the following is least appropriate for evaluating protein quality in this context, even though it is commonly used in product labeling?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Protein Energy Ratio (PER)

 

  • The Protein Energy Ratio (PE Ratio) is used to determine the proportion of dietary energy derived from protein (protein quantity).
  • It is calculated as:

 

 

  • This measure is critical for assessing whether a diet provides sufficient protein relative to total caloric intake, especially in postoperative or catabolic states where protein demands are high. 
  • According to this, recommended PE ratios range from ~8% in adult men to ~11.7% in adolescent girls. 
  • If the PE ratio is too low (e.g., <4%), patients may not be able to meet protein needs even if total calorie intake is adequate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Digestible Indispensable Amino Acid Score (DIAAS): Recommended by FAO/WHO; considers digestibility of individual indispensable amino acids at the end of the ileum. It is currently regarded as the most accurate modern method.

 

Option C. Biological Value (BV): Measures proportion of absorbed protein that is retained in the body. Useful in humans, especially for clinical nutrition.

 

Option D. Net Protein Utilization (NPU): Combines digestibility and biological value, estimating percentage of dietary protein actually utilized by the body. Reliable in adult nutrition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Protein Energy Ratio (PE Ratio) is the most clinically relevant tool for assessing whether a patient's diet provides adequate protein relative to total caloric intake. It helps guide nutritional interventions, particularly in hospitalized or nutritionally vulnerable patients.
  • DIAAS, BV, and NPU are more reliable metrics for evaluating dietary protein in clinical or maintenance diets.

 

Note – Protein quality is assessed by – 

 

  • DIASS (Best method)
  • PDCAAS (2nd best)
  • NPU (3rd best)
  • BV
  • AAS
  • Protein efficiency ratio

questions.text: A patient requires a transfusion for clotting factor replacement. Among the available blood components, which product is specifically selected for its high concentration of clotting factors and carries minimal risk of ABO incompatibility?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cryoprecipitate

 

  • Cryoprecipitate is a blood component derived from plasma that contains concentrated clotting factors, particularly fibrinogen, factor VIII, factor XIII, von Willebrand factor, and fibronectin. 
  • It is primarily used for patients with hypofibrinogenemia, von Willebrand disease (when other therapies are not available), and certain bleeding disorders.
  • Importantly, cryoprecipitate contains minimal plasma volume and very little to no red blood cells, which significantly reduces the likelihood of ABO incompatibility reactions. 
  • Since its transfusion is based on the presence of clotting factors rather than red blood cell antigens, matching for ABO is less critical compared to other blood products.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Platelet-rich plasma: Contains a substantial amount of plasma, which carries ABO antigens. Transfusing platelets that are ABO incompatible can cause hemolysis or reduced platelet survival.

 

Option C. Fresh frozen plasma (FFP): Contains the full complement of clotting factors, but also a significant amount of plasma proteins, including ABO antigens. FFP must be ABO-compatible to avoid hemolytic reactions.

 

Option D. Single donor platelets: Like platelet-rich plasma, single donor platelets contain plasma, so ABO compatibility should be considered to avoid transfusion reactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cryoprecipitate is rich in clotting factors but contains minimal plasma volume and red blood cell antigens, making ABO compatibility less critical compared to plasma-containing products like FFP or platelet concentrates.

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to cause fetal bradycardia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Maternal fever

 

  • Fetal bradycardia is defined as a baseline fetal heart rate <110 beats per minute for ≥10 minutes. 
  • Common causes include:
    • Uteroplacental insufficiency (e.g., placental abruption)
    • Umbilical cord compression
    • Fetal head compression (especially during labor)
    • Fetal congenital heart disease
    • Prolonged maternal hypoxia or hypotension
  • Maternal fever typically causes fetal tachycardia (baseline >160 bpm) due to increased fetal metabolic rate and sympathetic activity, not bradycardia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abruption: Placental abruption reduces oxygen delivery to the fetus, leading to hypoxia and possible bradycardia.

 

Option B. Fetal head compression: Head compression during contractions can stimulate the vagus nerve, causing transient bradycardia.

 

Option C. Congenital heart disease: Structural or conduction abnormalities in the fetal heart can directly result in persistent bradycardia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fetal bradycardia is most often due to hypoxia-related causes, vagal stimulation, or intrinsic heart disease. 
  • Maternal fever instead causes fetal tachycardia.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with white hair, gaze-evoked nystagmus, and photophobia. On examination, his irides appear pink, and fundoscopy reveals a pale, almost white fundus. He also has a history of recurrent bacterial infections. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chediak–Higashi syndrome

 

  • This rare autosomal recessive disorder combines oculocutaneous albinism (pale irides, hypopigmented fundi, white hair), neurologic features such as nystagmus, and a profound immunodeficiency due to impaired lysosomal trafficking in neutrophils and other phagocytes.

 

 

  • The resulting defect in intracellular killing leads to recurrent pyogenic infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Waardenburg syndrome: Presents with patchy white forelock hair and heterochromia iridis but without immunodeficiency or pale fundi. Patients have normal infection susceptibility.

 

 

Option C. Hermansky–Pudlak syndrome: Features oculocutaneous albinism and a bleeding diathesis (platelet storage pool deficiency), sometimes pulmonary fibrosis, not recurrent bacterial infections.

 

Option D. Oculocutaneous albinism: Involves uniformly reduced melanin in skin, hair, and eyes with photophobia and nystagmus, but lacks the immunodeficiency characteristic of Chediak–Higashi syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chediak–Higashi syndrome uniquely combines albinism (hypopigmentation of hair, iris, and fundus), neurologic signs (nystagmus), and life-threatening immunodeficiency due to defective lysosomal trafficking.

choices.text: Defer measles vaccination until 9 months of age
Administer vitamin A supplementation along with vaccine to improve absorption
Administer measles vaccine now and schedule the routine 9-month dose
Avoid vaccination due to risk of reduced efficacy in malnourished children

questions.text: A 7-month-old male infant is brought to the pediatric clinic in a rural community during a measles outbreak. He is malnourished, with weight-for-age <3rd percentile, and has not yet received any vaccinations. The physician is considering measles vaccination. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Administer measles vaccine now and schedule the routine 9-month dose

 

  • Standard schedule: Measles vaccine is routinely given at 9 months under immunization programs.
  • Special circumstances (epidemics, malnutrition, outbreaks): The vaccine can be administered as early as 6 months to reduce mortality and complications.
  • Infants vaccinated early must still receive the routine 9-month dose, because maternal antibodies may interfere with the immune response to the early dose.
  • Malnutrition is not a contraindication; rather, measles vaccination is especially critical in these children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Defer measles vaccination until 9 months of age: Incorrect. In epidemics or high-risk settings, waiting until 9 months would leave the child unprotected and highly vulnerable.

 

Option B. Administer vitamin A supplementation along with vaccine to improve absorption: Vitamin A is used during treatment of measles to reduce severity and complications, not for improving vaccine absorption.

 

Option D. Avoid vaccination due to risk of reduced efficacy in malnourished children: Malnutrition does not reduce efficacy to the point of contraindication. In fact, measles vaccine is lifesaving in malnourished children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In epidemics/outbreaks or malnourished infants, measles vaccine can be given as early as 6 months of age, followed by the routine 9-month dose for durable protection.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with breast cancer. Genetic testing shows no mutation in BRCA1 or BRCA2 genes, but her tumor cells exhibit silencing of tumor suppressor genes due to hypermethylation of promoter regions. The oncologist explains that this mechanism alters gene expression without changing the underlying DNA sequence. Which of the following best describes this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Epigenetics

 

  • Epigenetics refers to heritable changes in gene function that occur without a change in the DNA sequence. 
  • These changes typically affect gene expression and can involve mechanisms such as:
    • DNA methylation (especially of promoter regions)
    • Histone modification
    • Chromatin remodeling
    • Non-coding RNAs
  • In cancer, hypermethylation of promoter regions of tumor suppressor genes (e.g., p16, MLH1, BRCA1) leads to gene silencing, contributing to tumorigenesis. 
  • This is a well-recognized epigenetic mechanism in various malignancies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mutation: Refers to a permanent change in the DNA sequence (e.g., point mutation, insertion, deletion). In this case, no DNA sequence change was observed, so this is incorrect.

 

Option C. Translocation: Structural chromosomal rearrangement where genetic material is exchanged between chromosomes. Common in some leukemias (e.g., t(9;22) in CML), not relevant here.

 

Option D. Inversion: A chromosomal segment is reversed end to end. Not a common mechanism for gene silencing in breast cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mutation → permanent change in DNA sequence (e.g., point mutation, deletion, insertion).
  • Translocation → structural chromosomal abnormality (e.g., t(9;22) in CML).
  • Inversion → segment of chromosome reversed end to end.
  • Epigenetics → heritable changes in gene expression without altering the DNA sequence, mediated by:
    • DNA methylation → silences gene expression.
    • Histone acetylation/deacetylation → regulates chromatin compaction and transcriptional activity.

questions.text: A 35-year-old landscaper working under direct sun presents with headache, malaise, and dizziness. He has been sweating profusely without replacing electrolytes. On examination his rectal temperature is 38.5°C, pulse 140 bpm, and skin is moist. He is mildly confused. Laboratory studies reveal a serum sodium of 130 mEq/L. Which of the following heat‐related conditions does he most likely have?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Heat exhaustion

 

  • Heat exhaustion arises after prolonged strenuous activity in a hot environment with inadequate salt and water replacement. 
  • Key features include:
    • Moderate hyperthermia (rectal temperature 37.8–40°C)
    • Profuse sweating with moist, cool skin
    • Cardiovascular changes: tachycardia (often >150% of baseline) and hypotension
    • CNS symptoms: headache, dizziness, mild confusion or anxiety
    • Electrolyte disturbances, especially hyponatremia, due to isotonic fluid and sodium loss
  • In this case, the combination of a temperature of 38.5 °C, persistent sweating, tachycardia, mild confusion, and a serum sodium of 130 mEq/L is characteristic of heat exhaustion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heat cramps: Characterized by severe painful muscle spasms following heavy sweating and water-only replacement. Core temperature is usually normal or only slightly elevated, and confusion is not typical. Low sodium can be seen

 

Option C. Heat stroke: Defined by core temperature ≥ 40°C, central nervous system dysfunction (e.g., delirium, seizures, coma), and anhidrosis (dry skin). This patient’s temperature is below 40°C and he continues to sweat. Low sodium can be seen

 

Option D. Heat syncope (prostration): Presents with sudden fainting or collapse, weak pulse, cool, moist skin, and normal core temperature. It is due to vasodilation and dehydration, but without the significant hyperthermia or electrolyte disturbance seen here. Low sodium can be seen

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a hot, exertional setting, persistent sweating and inadequate salt replacement can lead to heat exhaustion—distinguished from heat cramps by CNS symptoms and from heat stroke by a lower core temperature and continued sweating.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with recurrent abdominal pain and visible proglottids in his stool. Stool microscopy confirms Hymenolepis diminuta infection. Which of the following arthropods most likely serves as an intermediate host in the lifecycle of this parasite?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Xenopsylla cheopis (Rat flea)

 

  • Hymenolepis diminuta is a zoonotic tapeworm that infects humans incidentally.
  • Intermediate hosts: arthropods (mainly grain beetles and rat fleas such as Xenopsylla cheopis).
  • Humans acquire infection by accidentally ingesting these infected insects (e.g., in contaminated cereals).
  • In the arthropod, the cysticercoid larval stage develops, which is infective to humans.
  • Thus, rat flea (Xenopsylla cheopis) is the correct intermediate host.

 

Life cycle of Hymenolepis 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Musca domestica (Housefly): Mechanical vector for diarrheal pathogens, not an intermediate host for H. diminuta.

 

Option B. Aedes aegypti (Mosquito): Transmits arboviruses (dengue, chikungunya, yellow fever, Zika), not tapeworms.

 

Option D. Glossina palpalis (Tsetse fly): Vector of Trypanosoma brucei (African sleeping sickness), unrelated to cestodes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hymenolepis diminuta infection occurs when humans ingest infected arthropods (especially rat fleas or grain beetles) containing cysticercoid larvae. 
  • Always differentiate mechanical vectors (e.g., housefly) from true intermediate hosts (rat flea, beetles).

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl presents with recurrent episodes of transient right-sided weakness over the past year. MRI shows multiple old infarcts in the anterior and middle cerebral artery territories. Cerebral angiography showing the “puff of smoke” appearance. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Moyamoya disease

 

  • Moyamoya disease is a rare, progressive cerebrovascular disorder characterized by bilateral stenosis or occlusion of the distal internal carotid arteries and their proximal branches (middle and anterior cerebral arteries). 
  • The narrowing stimulates the development of fragile collateral vessels at the base of the brain, which appear as a hazy network on angiography — classically described as a "puff of smoke" (Japanese: moyamoya).
  • Children often present with recurrent transient ischemic attacks (TIAs) or ischemic strokes. 
  • Adults may present with either ischemic or hemorrhagic strokes due to rupture of fragile collaterals. 
  • MRI/MRA findings confirm ischemic changes, while digital subtraction angiography is the gold standard for diagnosis.
  • The pathophysiology involves chronic, progressive narrowing, often idiopathic, but secondary forms can be associated with conditions such as Down syndrome, neurofibromatosis type 1, sickle cell anemia, and prior cranial irradiation. 
  • Treatment focuses on revascularization surgery to restore cerebral blood flow.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior cerebral artery (ACA) aneurysm: ACA aneurysms typically present with subarachnoid hemorrhage (sudden severe headache, vomiting, nuchal rigidity) and are identified as focal saccular dilations on angiography, not with a diffuse “puff of smoke” appearance.

 

Option B. Cavernous sinus thrombosis:  This is a rare complication of infections of the face or sinuses. It presents with headache, fever, periorbital swelling, and ophthalmoplegia due to cranial nerve involvement. MRI with venography shows thrombus in the cavernous sinus, not abnormal cerebral arterial collaterals.

 

Option D. Vein of Galen malformation:  This is a rare congenital arteriovenous malformation presenting in neonates or infants with high-output heart failure, macrocephaly, and prominent scalp veins. MRI/MRA shows a dilated midline vein, not the stenosis and fine collaterals seen in moyamoya.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The “puff of smoke” appearance on cerebral angiography is pathognomonic for moyamoya disease, caused by progressive stenosis of the distal internal carotid arteries and proximal branches, leading to the formation of fragile collateral vessels.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman at 18 weeks’ gestation presents after experiencing sudden, painless expulsion of the fetus at home. She reports that a similar event occurred at 20 weeks in her previous pregnancy. Examination today shows a soft, dilated cervix without uterine contractions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cervical insufficiency

 

  • Cervical insufficiency is characterized by painless cervical dilation leading to recurrent mid-trimester pregnancy loss, typically without labor contractions or other warning signs. 
  • The condition results from a structural weakness of the cervix, which can be congenital or acquired (e.g., due to cervical trauma, surgical procedures like conization).
  • Diagnosis is based on history (≥2 consecutive painless second-trimester losses), ultrasound findings (shortened cervical length), and physical examination. 
  • Management in subsequent pregnancies often involves cerclage placement and close monitoring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Preterm labor: Incorrect. Preterm labor involves painful, regular contractions with cervical change, usually after 20 weeks; this patient’s losses occurred earlier and without pain.

 

Option C. Placental abruption: Incorrect. This presents with painful vaginal bleeding and a tender, firm uterus due to premature placental separation.

 

Option D. Incompetent internal os from infection: Incorrect. Infection can cause preterm rupture of membranes and loss, but here the presentation is recurrent, painless, and typical of cervical insufficiency, not an acute infectious event.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cervical insufficiency is a structural weakness of the cervix leading to painless dilation and recurrent second-trimester pregnancy losses; prevention in future pregnancies may involve cerclage placement.

choices.text: Loss of sensation over medial leg and foot

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is recovering from a high-speed motor vehicle collision with pelvic fracture that resulted in femoral nerve injury. On neurological examination, his knee jerk reflex is absent on the right side. Which additional finding would most strongly support the suspected diagnosis of this injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Loss of sensation over medial leg and foot

 

  • The femoral nerve arises from the lumbar plexus (L2–L4) and provides both motor and sensory innervation. 
  • Motor functions include extension of the knee via the quadriceps and partial contribution to hip flexion. 
  • Sensory supply is to the anterior thigh and the medial leg and foot via the saphenous nerve branch.
  • Injury to the femoral nerve — often due to pelvic trauma, retroperitoneal hematoma, or surgical procedures — results in loss of the patellar reflex, weakness of knee extension, and sensory loss in its cutaneous distribution.
  • The medial leg and foot are supplied by the saphenous nerve, making sensory loss in this region a highly specific finding for femoral nerve injury in the setting of absent knee reflex after pelvic fracture.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atrophy of tensor fasciae latae: The tensor fasciae latae is innervated by the superior gluteal nerve (L4–S1). Dysfunction leads to impaired hip abduction and pelvic stabilization, but it does not cause loss of knee reflex or sensory deficits over the medial leg and foot. Thus, this finding is unrelated to femoral nerve injury.

 

Option C. Weakness of ankle dorsiflexion: Ankle dorsiflexion is primarily controlled by the tibialis anterior, which is innervated by the deep peroneal nerve (branch of the common peroneal nerve). Weakness in this movement produces foot drop but is not associated with femoral nerve injury.

 

Option D. Loss of thigh adduction: Thigh adduction is mediated primarily by the obturator nerve (L2–L4), which innervates the adductor muscles. While the femoral and obturator nerves share overlapping root origins, loss of thigh adduction suggests obturator nerve injury rather than femoral nerve injury, and thus it is not the most specific finding for confirming this diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Femoral nerve injury causes absent knee jerk reflex, weakness of knee extension, and sensory loss over the anterior thigh and medial leg/foot via the saphenous nerve. 
  • Sensory loss over the medial leg and foot is a key confirming feature in this setting.

choices.text: TDS 480 mg/L, Fluoride 0.7 ppm, Nitrate 38 mg/L

questions.text: A rural community undergoes water quality testing as part of a public health program. The following combinations of parameters are observed. Which one fully conforms to WHO recommended drinking water standards?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) TDS 480 mg/L, Fluoride 0.7 ppm, Nitrate 38 mg/L

 

  • TDS (Total Dissolved Solids): Acceptable < 500 mg/L. (480 mg/L is within range).
  • Fluoride: Safe range 0.5–1.5 ppm. (0.7 ppm is safe).
  • Nitrate: Safe limit < 45 mg/L. (38 mg/L is safe).
  • Hence, all parameters in option B are within WHO standards.

 

Educational Objective:

 

WHO Drinking Water Standards:

 

  • Turbidity: < 5 NTU
  • TDS: < 500 mg/L
  • Hardness: < 300 mg/L
  • Nitrate: < 45 mg/L
  • Fluoride: 1-2 ppm (0.5 – 0.8 ppm is optimum level of uptake)
  • pH: 6.5–8.5

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient undergoes laparoscopic cholecystectomy. During the procedure, a structure is identified that connects the greater sac to the lesser sac of the peritoneal cavity. Which of the following is not part of its posterior boundary?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) First part of the duodenum

 

  • The epiploic (Winslow’s) foramen connects the greater sac and the lesser sac of the peritoneal cavity. 
  • Its boundaries are as follows:
    • Posterior boundary: Inferior vena cava (IVC) and the right crus of the diaphragm at the level of the T12 vertebra.
    • Anterior boundary: Hepatoduodenal ligament containing the portal triad (portal vein, hepatic artery proper, and common bile duct).
    • Superior boundary: Caudate lobe of the liver.
    • Inferior boundary: First part of the duodenum.
  • The first part of the duodenum is not part of the posterior boundary; instead, it forms the inferior boundary of the foramen. 
  • Because the question specifically asks for a structure not part of the posterior boundary, the correct choice is the first part of the duodenum.

 

Epiploic (Omental) Foramen – Boundaries 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inferior vena cava (IVC): The IVC lies behind the epiploic foramen and, along with the right crus of the diaphragm, forms the posterior boundary.

 

Option C. Suprarenal gland: While the suprarenal gland is not part of the inferior or anterior boundaries, it lies superior to the kidney and close to the posterior aspect, so in this context it is not the answer because the question focuses on boundaries and the duodenum is the defining incorrect posterior-boundary choice.

 

Option D. T12 vertebra: The posterior boundary of the epiploic foramen is defined in part by the right crus of the diaphragm, which attaches to the T12 vertebra, making it part of the posterior limit.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The posterior boundary of the epiploic foramen is formed by the inferior vena cava and the right crus of the diaphragm at T12; the first part of the duodenum forms its inferior boundary, not the posterior.

choices.text: Failure of pro-B cells to mature into pre-B cells
Inability of pre-T cells to undergo positive selection in the thymus
Defective V(D)J recombination in developing lymphocytes

questions.text: A 4-month-old boy has absent lymphoid tissue on physical exam and agammaglobulinemia on labs. Genetic analysis confirms a defect in Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK). Which of the following best explains the mechanism of his immune deficiency?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Failure of pro-B cells to mature into pre-B cells

 

  • Bruton X-linked agammaglobulinemia is caused by mutations in the BTK gene, which is essential for B-cell development. 
  • The absence of BTK function halts maturation at the pro-B cell to pre-B cell transition in the bone marrow. 
  • This leads to absent mature B cells in the peripheral blood and almost no antibody production. 
  • Clinically, it presents in male infants after maternal IgG protection wanes (~6 months) with recurrent bacterial infections and absent lymphoid tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inability of pre-T cells to undergo positive selection in the thymus: Seen in T-cell maturation defects like DiGeorge syndrome, not in BTK mutation.

 

Option C. Defective V(D)J recombination in developing lymphocytes: Found in RAG gene mutations, causing SCID, affecting both B and T cells.

 

Option D. Impaired class switching of immunoglobulins: Caused by CD40 ligand or CD40 defects (Hyper-IgM syndrome), not BTK mutations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • BTK gene mutations cause X-linked agammaglobulinemia, characterized by failure of B-cell maturation, absence of peripheral B cells, pan-hypogammaglobulinemia, and recurrent bacterial infections after 6 months of age.
  • This is a B-cell lineage defect, not a T-cell defect.

questions.text: A 45-year-old postoperative patient develops erythema and mild discharge from his surgical incision site. The surgeon decides to document the wound status using a standardized scoring system specifically designed for grading surgical wound infections. Which of the following systems is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Southampton score

 

  • The Southampton wound scoring system is used for grading surgical wound infections.
  • It categorizes wounds based on appearance, ranging from normal healing (grade 0) to erythema, discharge, pus, and deep wound infection (grade V).
  • It provides an objective framework for clinical assessment of postoperative wound healing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ASA score: The American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) score is used to classify preoperative physical status and anesthetic risk, not wound infections. It grades patients from ASA I (healthy) to ASA V (moribund).

 

Option C. SIRS score: The Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome (SIRS) criteria are used to identify patients with sepsis or systemic inflammatory responses. It involves parameters such as temperature, heart rate, respiratory rate, and WBC count—not local wound infections.

 

Option D. Glasgow score: The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is designed to assess the level of consciousness in patients with head injury or altered sensorium. It evaluates eye, motor, and verbal responses and is unrelated to wound infection grading.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Southampton wound scoring system is specifically used to grade surgical wound infections, whereas ASA, SIRS, and Glasgow scores assess unrelated aspects of patient status.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is undergoing surgery for an ectopic pregnancy. Which of the following surgical procedures is shown in the image below for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Salpingectomy

 

  • The image and description show the incision of the mesosalpinx — the fold of the broad ligament that encloses the fallopian tube and contains its blood supply. 
  • This step is performed when removing the entire fallopian tube, such as for an ectopic pregnancy when conservative management is not possible or when the tube is severely damaged.
  • Salpingectomy is the complete surgical removal of the fallopian tube. It differs from salpingostomy, which is an incision made into the fallopian tube to remove ectopic tissue while leaving the tube intact.
  • In salpingectomy, the surgeon opens the mesosalpinx to isolate and ligate the vascular supply before excising the tube.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Salpingostomy: Incorrect. Salpingostomy involves making a linear incision on the fallopian tube to remove ectopic tissue without removing the tube. It does not require complete mobilization of the mesosalpinx.

 

Option B. Ovarian cystectomy: Incorrect. Ovarian cystectomy is removal of a cyst from the ovary, leaving the ovary itself in place. It involves dissecting ovarian tissue, not the mesosalpinx.

 

Option D. Ovariectomy: Incorrect. Ovariectomy (oophorectomy) is removal of the ovary. This procedure requires ligation of the infundibulopelvic ligament containing the ovarian vessels, not the mesosalpinx of the fallopian tube.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Salpingectomy for ectopic pregnancy involves incising the mesosalpinx to access and ligate the fallopian tube’s blood supply before removal

questions.text: A patient presents with the oral lesion shown in the image. Which of the following best describes the microscopic characteristic of the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gram-positive budding yeast with pseudohyphae

 

  • Oropharyngeal candidiasis (oral thrush) is most often caused by Candida albicans. 
  • On Gram staining, Candida appears as Gram-positive oval budding yeast cells with characteristic pseudohyphae. 
  • Pseudohyphae formation and germ tube production are important virulence factors aiding mucosal invasion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gram-negative diplococci: Seen in Neisseria species (e.g., N. meningitidis, N. gonorrhoeae), not associated with oral thrush.

 

Option C. Acid-fast bacilli: Suggestive of Mycobacterium or Nocardia  species, identified by Ziehl-Neelsen stain, not Gram stain.

 

Option D. Gram-positive cocci in clusters: Seen in Staphylococcus species, unrelated to the presentation of oral candidiasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Oropharyngeal candidiasis is characterized by white plaques that can be scraped off, revealing an erythematous base. 
  • It is common in immunocompromised states (HIV/AIDS, chemotherapy, steroid use) and after broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy. 
  • Gram staining and KOH preparation confirm the presence of Candida, aiding in early diagnosis and treatment.

choices.text: Drainage of 1500 mL of blood after insertion of an intercostal tube
Persistent chest tube output >200 mL/hour for 3 consecutive hours

questions.text: A 32-year-old man sustains multiple chest injuries following a motor vehicle accident. A chest tube is placed, and large quantity of blood is immediately drained. The patient remains hemodynamically unstable, and further evaluation is being considered for surgical intervention. Which of the following is not an indication for thoracotomy in such a patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rib fracture

 

  • Rib fractures alone, even if multiple, are not an indication for thoracotomy.
  • They are managed conservatively with pain control, oxygenation, and supportive care unless associated with severe vascular or pulmonary injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Drainage of 1500 mL of blood after intercostal tube insertion: This is a valid indication for thoracotomy. Immediate large-volume drainage following chest tube placement signifies major vascular injury requiring surgical exploration.

 

Option B. Persistent chest tube output >200 mL/hour for 3 consecutive hours: Ongoing bleeding at this rate indicates significant intrathoracic hemorrhage that will not resolve with conservative measures, thus necessitating thoracotomy.

 

Option C. Presence of cardiac tamponade: This is a surgical emergency. Tamponade following chest trauma often results from great vessel or cardiac injury and requires immediate thoracotomy to relieve pressure and repair the defect.

 

Educational Objective:


Indications for thoracotomy after chest trauma include massive (>1500 cc) or persistent hemothorax, cardiac tamponade, great vessel injury, and bronchial/esophageal injuries, whereas isolated rib fractures do not warrant thoracotomy.

choices.text: It can be used for effective ventilation up to 6 hours
It is used to measure central venous pressure
It should be followed by tracheostomy
Work of breathing will be more than face mask ventilation

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the procedure shown in the image is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It should be followed by tracheostomy

 

  • Needle cricothyrotomy is an emergency, temporary airway performed when intubation fails.
  • It provides oxygenation but not adequate long-term ventilation. 
  • Therefore, it must be converted to a definitive airway (tracheostomy or surgical cricothyrotomy) within hours.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It can be used for effective ventilation up to 6 hours: False, it is only a temporizing measure for a short duration.

 

Option B. It is used to measure central venous pressure: CVP is measured via venous access, not through cricothyrotomy.

 

Option D. Work of breathing will be more than face mask ventilation: Incorrect; this is not a feature of cricothyrotomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Needle cricothyrotomy is a temporary life-saving airway that must be followed by a definitive airway such as tracheostomy.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman with a 3 cm ER-/PR-/HER2+ breast cancer, confirmed by biopsy, undergoes lumpectomy and negative sentinel lymph node biopsy. What is the most appropriate adjuvant therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Docetaxel, cyclophosphamide, trastuzumab, pertuzumab

 

  • HER2-positive breast cancer requires targeted therapy.
  • Trastuzumab and pertuzumab are standard HER2-targeted agents for adjuvant therapy.
  • Docetaxel and cyclophosphamide provide chemotherapy for early-stage, high-risk disease.
  • This regimen reduces recurrence and improves survival.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Letrozole plus ribociclib: Used for ER-positive, HER2-negative breast cancer, not HER2-positive.

 

Option C. Neratinib: Extended adjuvant therapy post-trastuzumab, not first-line.

 

Option D. Trastuzumab emtansine: Used for metastatic or residual disease, not first-line adjuvant therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • HER2-positive breast cancer requires trastuzumab and pertuzumab with chemotherapy.
  • Adjuvant therapy reduces recurrence in early-stage disease.
  • Hormone therapies are ineffective for ER/PR-negative cancers.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with complaints of progressive imbalance and decreased hearing in his left ear. MRI of the brain demonstrates a lesion occupying the internal auditory canal. If the mass is situated in the anterosuperior quadrant of the canal, which structure would most likely be involved?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Facial nerve

 

  • The internal auditory canal (IAC) contains four key nerves, which are organized anatomically as follows:
    1. Anterosuperior quadrant: Facial nerve.
    2. Anteroinferior quadrant: Cochlear nerve.
    3. Posterosuperior quadrant: Superior vestibular nerve.
    4. Posteroinferior quadrant: Inferior vestibular nerve.
  • If the mass is located in the anterosuperior part of the IAC, the facial nerve is most likely to be affected, leading to facial weakness, twitching, or other motor symptoms related to the facial nerve. 
  • Although vertigo and hearing loss may be present due to the involvement of neighbouring structures, the anterosuperior location directly implicates the facial nerve.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior vestibular nerve: The superior vestibular nerve is found in the posterosuperior quadrant of the IAC. It transmits signals related to balance from the superior semicircular canal but is not affected by a mass in the anterosuperior quadrant.

 

Option B. Inferior vestibular nerve: The inferior vestibular nerve occupies the posteroinferior quadrant of the IAC. It also transmits balance information but is not located in the anterosuperior quadrant.

 

Option C. Cochlear nerve: The cochlear nerve is located in the anteroinferior quadrant of the IAC. While this nerve mediates hearing, it is not located in the anterosuperior part of the IAC, where the facial nerve lies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The facial nerve occupies the anterosuperior quadrant of the internal auditory canal (IAC). 
  • A mass in this region is most likely to affect the facial nerve, potentially causing facial motor symptoms.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with severe headache, nausea, and vomiting for the past 2 days. Her blood pressure is 200/160 mmHg. Laboratory tests reveal a serum creatinine of 3.8 mg/dL. A renal biopsy of this patient is shown below. Which of the following underlying conditions is most likely responsible for her presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diffuse scleroderma      

 

  • The renal biopsy shows onion-skinning—concentric, laminated thickening of small arteriolar walls due to proliferation of smooth muscle cells and reduplication of basement membranes. 
  • This finding is characteristic of hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis, which develops in malignant hypertension.
  • In patients with diffuse scleroderma, sudden onset severe hypertension can occur due to scleroderma renal crisis. 
  • This crisis is mediated by narrowing of renal arterioles and activation of the renin-angiotensin system, leading to malignant hypertension, acute kidney injury, and histologic evidence of onion-skinning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polyarteritis nodosa: A necrotizing vasculitis affecting medium-sized arteries, sparing the lungs. Histology shows segmental transmural inflammation with fibrinoid necrosis, not onion-skin concentric thickening. It does not typically present with scleroderma features or malignant hypertension of this pattern.

 

Option C. Takayasu arteritis: A large-vessel granulomatous vasculitis involving the aorta and its branches. Presents with absent pulses in the upper extremities (“pulseless disease”) and constitutional symptoms. It does not cause onion-skin arteriolosclerosis on renal biopsy.

 

Option D. Malignant pheochromocytoma: A catecholamine-secreting adrenal tumor can cause paroxysmal or sustained hypertension, but renal biopsy changes would be secondary and not typically diagnostic for onion-skin hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis in the context of scleroderma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scleroderma renal crisis is a life-threatening complication of diffuse scleroderma that presents with acute malignant hypertension, acute kidney injury, and renal biopsy showing onion-skin hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis due to severe arteriolar narrowing.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the outpatient department complaining of dull pain in her left ear for the past 10 days. She denies discharge, trauma, or hearing difficulty. On examination, the external ear and tympanic membrane are normal. She also mentions persistent throat pain and painful swallowing. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for her ear pain?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tonsillitis

 

  • The patient presents with referred otalgia (ear pain) and throat symptoms. Since there are no positive findings in the ear (normal tympanic membrane and external auditory canal), the ear pain is likely referred. 
  • Referred otalgia can occur due to shared nerve supply. 
  • The glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX), via its tympanic branch (Jacobson's nerve), supplies both the throat and the middle ear, explaining the referred pain to the ear. 
  • The patient's sore throat and difficulty swallowing suggest tonsillitis, where the inflamed tonsils irritate the glossopharyngeal nerve, leading to referred ear pain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute otitis media: Acute otitis media presents with ear pain accompanied by otoscopic findings, such as a bulging tympanic membrane, erythema, or fluid behind the eardrum. This patient's ear exam was normal, making this diagnosis unlikely.

 

Option B. Temporomandibular joint (TMJ) disorder: TMJ disorders can cause referred pain to the ear, but they are typically associated with jaw pain, clicking sounds, or restricted jaw movement, none of which are mentioned in this case.

 

Option D. Trigeminal neuralgia: Trigeminal neuralgia typically causes severe, stabbing pain along the distribution of the trigeminal nerve (face, jaw, or forehead). It does not cause sore throat or swallowing difficulties and is not associated with referred otalgia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Referred otalgia in the absence of positive ear findings may result from irritation of the glossopharyngeal nerve, as seen in conditions like tonsillitis.

questions.text: In which of the following cells does isotype switching occur?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Activated B cells

 

  • In germinal centers, activated B cells undergo isotype (class) switching, a process in which the constant (Fc) region of the antibody heavy chain changes, producing a different immunoglobulin class (eg, IgM → IgG, IgA, or IgE) without altering antigen specificity. 
  • This adaptation is crucial for tailoring the immune response to the nature of the pathogen.
  •  The process requires:
    • CD40 on B cells binding to CD40 ligand (CD40L) on activated CD4+ helper T cells
    • Cytokines secreted by helper T cells (eg, IL-4, IL-5, IFN-γ), which determine the isotype produced

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Helper T cells: Provide the CD40L and cytokines required for class switching, but the switching occurs within B cells themselves.

 

Option C. Cytotoxic T cells: Kill infected or malignant cells through perforin and granzyme release; not involved in antibody class switching.

 

Option D. Naïve B cells: Initially produce only IgM and IgD; they must first be activated by antigen and T cell help before undergoing isotype switching.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isotype switching occurs in activated B cells in germinal centers, requiring CD40–CD40L interaction and helper T cell cytokines, allowing antibodies to change class without changing antigen specificity.

questions.text:
All of the following statements about abducens (VI) nerve palsy are true except?

 

  1. It is the most common congenital paralytic squint.
  2. Primary deviation is less than secondary deviation.
  3. It can be diagnosed with the forced duction test.
  4. It presents with ipsilateral esotropia.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 only

 

Statement 1. It is the most common congenital paralytic squint: False. Congenital abducens palsy is rare; the oculomotor and trochlear palsies are more commonly seen congenitally, and the most common congenital squint overall is congenital esotropia, not specifically a paralytic form.

 

Correct Statements:

 

Statement 2. Primary deviation is less than secondary deviation: True. In paralytic squints, secondary deviation (when the affected eye fixes) is typically greater than the primary deviation (when the normal eye fixes) due to Hering’s law of equal innervation.

 

 

Statement 3. It can be diagnosed with the forced duction test: True. In abducens nerve palsy, the lateral rectus muscle is weak or paralyzed. The forced duction test—where the examiner passively moves the eye—will show a free passive abduction, confirming a nerve (neurogenic) cause rather than a mechanical restriction.

 

Statement 4. It presents with ipsilateral esotropia: True. Abducens palsy causes esotropia, the affected eye turns inward (esotropia) on the side of the lesion—this is indeed ipsilateral. The more precise statement would be “the affected eye is esotropic.”

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Abducens palsy weakens lateral rectus function, causing the affected eye to deviate inward. 
  • The forced duction test is negative (free movement), confirming a neurogenic palsy rather than a restrictive lesion. 

 

Note – 

 

Hirschberg Test: Demonstrates varying degrees of esotropia (15, 30, 45, and >45 degrees) based on the observed inward turn of the eye, by noting the displacement of the corneal light reflex. 

 

 

Interpretation of Results (as illustrated in the image):

 

  • Centered reflex: Indicates no deviation (0 degrees).
  • Reflex at the pupil border: Approximately 15 degrees of deviation.
  • Reflex at the surface: Approximately 30 degrees of deviation.
  • Reflex at the limbus (corneoscleral junction): Approximately 45 degrees of deviation.
  • Reflex beyond the limbus: Indicates a deviation greater than 45 degrees.

questions.text: A city health department installs a device that draws air through a filter paper. Over time, the paper darkens due to trapped particles, and the degree of discoloration is quantified using a photoelectric meter. This method is most commonly used to measure which index of air pollution?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Soiling index

 

  • The Soiling Index (also called the Black Smoke index) is an indirect measure of particulate matter in ambient air.
  • Air is passed through white filter paper, which becomes progressively blackened by soot and particulate deposits.
  • A photoelectric meter then quantifies the degree of blackening.
  • This method is historically used in urban air quality monitoring to assess pollution due to industrial smoke and vehicular emissions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sulphur dioxide concentration: Measured by colorimetric or instrumental chemical analysis (e.g., pararosaniline method), not by filter paper darkening.

 

Option B. Particulate matter deposition: Although related, particulate deposition is assessed by gravimetric methods (weight measurement of particles collected), not by optical blackening.

 

Option D. Indoor humidity index: Humidity is measured by hygrometers or psychrometers, not by particulate-staining filter papers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Soiling Index uses filter paper darkening and photoelectric measurement to quantify airborne particulate matter pollution. 
  • It is a classic environmental health tool in urban pollution control.

questions.text: “Doughnut granulomas” on histopathology are most characteristic of which infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Q fever

 

  • Coxiella burnetii, the causative agent of Q fever, can produce fibrin ring granulomas (also called “doughnut granulomas”) in the liver.
  • These granulomas have a central lipid vacuole surrounded by fibrin, giving the appearance of a ring or “doughnut” under the microscope.

 

 

  • Though not entirely pathognomonic, this finding is classically associated with Q fever.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF): Caused by Rickettsia rickettsii; histology shows vasculitis with endothelial swelling and perivascular inflammatory infiltrates, not doughnut granulomas.

 

Option C. Lyme disease: Caused by Borrelia burgdorferi; shows lymphocytic infiltrates, arthritis changes, and erythema migrans clinically; no doughnut granulomas.

 

Option D. Ehrlichiosis: Caused by Ehrlichia chaffeensis; histology may show intracytoplasmic inclusions (morulae) in monocytes, not fibrin ring granulomas.

 

Educational Objective:
