Doughnut (fibrin ring) granulomas are a histologic finding with a central lipid vacuole surrounded by fibrin, most commonly associated with Q fever caused by Coxiella burnetii.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the pediatric clinic by her parents who report recurrent episodes of hypoglycemia, particularly during overnight fasting and mild illnesses. Physical examination reveals significant hepatomegaly extending 6 cm below the right costal margin, but the spleen is not palpable. Laboratory studies show fasting hypoglycemia (glucose: 40 mg/dL), and elevated liver enzymes. A liver biopsy demonstrates massive hepatocyte enlargement with cytoplasmic accumulation of abnormally structured glycogen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cori's disease 

 

  • Child with fasting hypoglycemia + hepatomegaly + abnormal glycogen structure → points to Cori’s disease (debranching enzyme deficiency).

 

Cori’s disease (Type III):

 

  • Deficiency of debranching enzyme (α-1,6-glucosidase).
  • Features:
    • Mild to moderate hypoglycemia (not as severe as Von Gierke).
    • Hepatomegaly due to accumulation of limit dextrins (abnormally structured glycogen).
    • Elevated liver enzymes may be present.
    • Growth retardation possible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Von Gierke’s disease (Type I):

 

  • Deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase
  • Presents with severe fasting hypoglycemia, hepatorenomegaly, lactic acidosis, hyperlipidemia, hyperuricemia.
  • Usually more severe, with doll-like facies and not just hepatomegaly.

 

Option C. Her’s disease (Type VI):

 

  • Deficiency of liver glycogen phosphorylase.
  • Hepatomegaly + hypoglycemia, but glycogen structure remains normal (unlike Cori’s disease).

 

Option D. McArdle’s disease (Type V):

 

  • Deficiency of muscle glycogen phosphorylase.
  • Presents with exercise intolerance, muscle cramps, and myoglobinuria, but no hepatomegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cori's disease (Type III glycogen storage disease) is caused by debranching enzyme deficiency, leading to mild hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, and accumulation of abnormally structured glycogen (limit dextrins) in the liver.

questions.text: During a prenatal diagnostic workup, a woman is found to have elevated amniotic fluid markers. Neural tube defects are suspected. Which of the following markers would not be elevated in cases of neural tube defects?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) βhCG

 

  • In neural tube defects (NTDs), amniotic fluid analysis shows elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and acetylcholinesterase (AchE) due to leakage of fetal proteins into the amniotic cavity.
  • However, βhCG is not elevated in NTDs, and its rise is instead associated with conditions like molar pregnancy, multiple gestation, and Down syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acetylcholinesterase: Acetylcholinesterase is elevated in NTDs because the open neural tube communicates with the amniotic cavity, allowing leakage of this enzyme. It is an important confirmatory marker when AFP is elevated.

 

Option C. Alpha-fetoprotein: AFP, produced by the fetal yolk sac and liver, is elevated in both neural tube defects and abdominal wall defects. Elevated AFP is the primary screening marker for NTDs during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:


Neural tube defects are diagnosed prenatally by elevated AFP and acetylcholinesterase in amniotic fluid, while βhCG is not elevated.

choices.text: Oedema and cystic changes in the stria vascularis
Vasoconstriction of small vessels in the cochlea

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman being treated for pulmonary edema is administered high doses of intravenous furosemide. Two days later, she complains of ringing in the ears followed by decreased hearing. Which underlying pathological change is most responsible for this ototoxicity?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oedema and cystic changes in the stria vascularis

 

  • Furosemide is a loop diuretic and is known for its ototoxicity, especially when used chronically or in high doses. 
  • It disrupts the function of the stria vascularis, a structure in the cochlea responsible for the production of endolymph. 
  • The mechanism involves the development of edema and cystic changes in the stria vascularis, impairing the ion gradient required for normal cochlear function, particularly the potassium differential. 
  • This results in a disruption of the endocochlear potential and leads to hearing impairment.
  • Other loop diuretics, such as bumetanide and ethacrynic acid, are also associated with ototoxicity, especially when administered intravenously or with other ototoxic agents.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Damage to the cochlear nerve: Direct damage to the cochlear nerve is not a known mechanism of furosemide-induced ototoxicity. Cochlear nerve damage is more commonly associated with conditions such as acoustic neuroma or other neurotoxic agents.

 

Option C. Vasoconstriction of small vessels in the cochlea: While ischemia can contribute to hearing loss in certain conditions, it is not the primary mechanism of ototoxicity with furosemide. Furosemide acts on the stria vascularis rather than affecting cochlear blood vessels directly.

 

Option D. Disruption of the basilar membrane: The basilar membrane plays a critical role in sound wave transmission, but furosemide does not directly disrupt this structure. Hearing loss in this case is due to ionic imbalance caused by stria vascularis dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Furosemide causes hearing loss by inducing edema and cystic changes in the stria vascularis, which impairs endolymph production and disrupts the ionic gradient necessary for normal cochlear function.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presents with a painless swelling of the left scrotum for the past 8 months. The swelling is dull in character and has not changed with position. There are no constitutional symptoms. Scrotal ultrasound finding is shown below. Which of the following is the characteristic ultrasound finding in a hydrocele?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anechoic collection in scrotal sac

 

  • A hydrocele is a collection of serous fluid within the tunica vaginalis surrounding the testis.
  • On ultrasound, hydrocele fluid is typically:
    • Anechoic (appears completely black) because it is simple, clear fluid with no internal echoes.
    • Well-defined and surrounds the testis without internal septations (unless complicated).
    • Posterior acoustic enhancement may be seen due to fluid.
  • In chronic or infected hydroceles, internal echoes may appear due to protein, debris, or infection — but in uncomplicated hydroceles, anechoic fluid is the hallmark.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isoechoic collection in scrotal sac: Same echogenicity as surrounding tissue; would not allow fluid distinction.

 

Option B. Hypoechoic collection in scrotal sac: Fluid may be slightly hypoechoic if debris is present, but typical hydrocele fluid is completely anechoic.

 

Option D. Hyperechoic collection in scrotal sac: Suggests solid structures (e.g., tumors, calcifications) and is not a feature of hydrocele.

 

Educational Objective:

 

On ultrasound, a simple hydrocele appears as a well-defined, anechoic fluid collection surrounding the testis within the tunica vaginalis.

questions.text: Match each health legislation in Column A with its correct year of enactment in Column B.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1→D, 2→B, 3→A, 4→C

 

1. The Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act → 1971 (D):

  • Enacted on August 10, 1971, this was one of India's pioneering health legislations
  • Made India one of the first countries to legalize abortion under specific conditions
  • Aimed to reduce maternal mortality from unsafe abortions and provide women with reproductive rights
  • Recently amended in 2021 to extend the gestation limit from 20 to 24 weeks for special categories

 

2. The Transplantation of Human Organs Act → 1994 (B):

  • Enacted on July 8, 1994 (came into force February 4, 1995)
  • First legislation in India to legally recognize brain-stem death
  • Established framework for organ donation and transplantation
  • Prohibited commercial trading of human organs
  • Amended in 2011 to become "Transplantation of Human Organs and Tissues Act" (THOTA)

 

3. NREGA (National Rural Employment Guarantee Act) → 2005 (A):

  • Enacted on August 25, 2005 (notified September 7, 2005)
  • Later renamed as Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act (MGNREGA) in 2009
  • Though primarily a social security measure, it has significant health implications
  • Improves health outcomes through poverty reduction, food security, and infrastructure development
  • Guarantees 100 days of wage employment, reducing malnutrition and improving healthcare access

 

4. The Biomedical Waste (Management and Handling) Rules → 1998 (C):

  • First notified on July 20, 1998 under the Environment Protection Act, 1986
  • Established protocols for segregation, treatment, and disposal of biomedical waste
  • Introduced color-coded categorization system for different types of medical waste
  • Superseded by new Biomedical Waste Management Rules in 2016 with stricter provisions
  • Critical for preventing nosocomial infections and environmental contamination

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Remember:

 

  • The Employees State Insurance (ESI) Act, 1948
  • The Factories Act, 1948
  • The Indian Medical Council (Prof. Conduct and Ethics) Act, 1956
  • The Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act, 1971
  • The Environmental Protection Act (EPA), 1986
  • The Pre-conception and Pre-natal Diagnostic Techniques (Prohibition of Sex Selection) [PCPNDT] Act, 1994
  • The Transplantation of Human Organs Act, 1994
  • The Biomedical Waste (Management and Handling) Rules, 1998
  • The National Rural Employment Guarantee Act (NREGA), 2005
  • The Food Standards and Safety Act, 2006
  • The Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act, 2012

choices.text: Symmetrical (Normal), Symmetrical with outliers, Negatively skewed
Symmetrical with outliers, Negatively skewed, Positively skewed

questions.text: The box plot shown displays three different datasets. Based on their distribution characteristics, identify the correct classification for Dataset 1, Dataset 2, and Dataset 3, respectively.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Symmetrical (Normal), Symmetrical with outliers, Negatively skewed

 

  • Dataset 1: Median is approximately centered in the box, and whiskers are nearly equal in length → indicates symmetrical (normal-like) distribution.
  • Dataset 2: Median is centered, whiskers are balanced, but multiple points lie beyond the whiskers → outliers present.
  • Dataset 3: The median is shifted upward (closer to Q3), and the lower whisker is much longer. The data is more spread out on the lower side → indicates typical of a negatively skewed (left-skewed) distribution.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Symmetrical with outliers, Negatively skewed, Positively skewed: Incorrect because Dataset 1 does not have visible outliers, and Dataset 2 is not negatively skewed.

 

Option C. Normal, Positively skewed, Negatively skewed: Incorrect because Dataset 2 is not positively skewed; it’s symmetrical with outliers.

 

Option D. Normal, Outliers, Negatively skewed: Incorrect because Dataset 3 shows positive, not negative, skewness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Box plots allow quick identification of symmetry, skewness, and presence of outliers in datasets:
    • Median position & whisker length → indicate skewness.
    • Outliers → plotted as points beyond the whiskers.
    • Symmetry → median centered and whiskers of similar length.

questions.text: A patient with chronic viral hepatitis has defective recognition of single-stranded RNA (ssRNA). Which pair of Toll-like receptors is most likely impaired?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) TLR-7 and TLR-8

 

  • Toll-like receptors (TLRs) are pattern recognition receptors that detect conserved microbial structures.
  • TLR-7 and TLR-8 are located in endosomal membranes and specialize in detecting single-stranded RNA (ssRNA), a hallmark of many RNA viruses such as hepatitis viruses, influenza, and HIV.
  • Upon recognition, they activate MyD88-dependent signaling, leading to the production of type I interferons and pro-inflammatory cytokines.
  • Defects in these receptors can lead to impaired antiviral innate immunity, making patients more susceptible to chronic viral infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TLR-2 and TLR-4: TLR-2 detects bacterial peptidoglycan and lipoteichoic acid from Gram-positive bacteria; TLR-4 detects lipopolysaccharide (LPS) from Gram-negative bacteria. They are unrelated to ssRNA detection.

 

Option B. TLR-5 and TLR-7: TLR-5 detects bacterial flagellin, while TLR-7 detects ssRNA. The pair is mismatched for the specific defect described.

 

Option D. TLR-3 and TLR-9: TLR-3 detects double-stranded RNA (dsRNA), and TLR-9 detects unmethylated CpG DNA from bacteria and DNA viruses. Neither is the main ssRNA sensor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • TLR-7 and TLR-8 are critical endosomal receptors for sensing viral ssRNA and initiating innate antiviral responses. 
  • Understanding the specificity of TLRs is important in immunodeficiency diagnostics and in designing antiviral immune therapies.
  • Toll-Like Receptors (TLRs):

choices.text: Primary staining with Carbolfuchsin → Decolorization with 1% sulfuric acid → Counterstaining with Methylene blue
Primary staining with Ziehl–Neelsen stain → Decolorization with 20% sulfuric acid → Counterstaining with Malachite green
Primary staining with Auramine–rhodamine → Decolorization with acid–alcohol → Counterstaining with Methylene blue
Primary staining with Crystal violet → Decolorization with acetone → Counterstaining with Safranin

questions.text: Which staining method and sequence is typically used for detecting Cryptosporidium oocysts in stool samples?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Primary staining with Carbolfuchsin → Decolorization with 1% sulfuric acid → Counterstaining with Methylene blue

 

  • Cryptosporidium oocysts are acid-fast and can be detected by modified acid-fast staining.
  • The method involves:
    • Primary stain – Carbolfuchsin, which stains oocysts red.
    • Decolorization – Mild acid treatment (1% sulfuric acid) rather than stronger acids used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining.
    • Counterstain – Methylene blue, which provides contrast, making the background blue and the oocysts stand out as red.
  • This technique is specifically adapted to highlight small oocysts (~4–6 μm) in stool microscopy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Primary staining with Ziehl–Neelsen stain → Decolorization with 20% sulfuric acid → Counterstaining with Malachite green:Decolorization with 20% sulfuric acid is done for Mycobacterium detection, not suitable for delicate protozoan oocysts like Cryptosporidium. Counterstaining with Malachite green is used in Albert stain.

 

Option C. Primary staining with Auramine–rhodamine → Decolorization with acid–alcohol → Counterstaining with Methylene blue:Auramine-rhodamine is a fluorochrome stain for mycobacteria, not routinely used for Cryptosporidium. Decolorization and counterstaining is not required with this stain.

 

Option D. Primary staining with Crystal violet → Decolorization with acetone → Counterstaining with Safranin: Part of Gram staining, not for acid-fast organisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The modified acid-fast stain for Cryptosporidium uses Carbolfuchsin → 1% sulfuric acid → Methylene blue to visualize oocysts as bright red against a blue background. 
  • This mild acid decolorization preserves staining in delicate protozoan structures.

questions.text: During neck surgery to remove a cervical mass, the surgeon inadvertently damages the ansa cervicalis. This neural structure is usually located within which fascial layer of the neck?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Carotid sheath

 

  • The ansa cervicalis is a loop of nerves derived from cervical spinal nerves (C1–C3) that innervates most of the infrahyoid muscles. 
  • It is typically embedded within the carotid sheath, a tubular fascial structure enclosing the common carotid artery, internal jugular vein, and vagus nerve. 
  • Because of its anatomical course, surgical procedures involving the carotid sheath region — such as carotid endarterectomy or removal of masses in this area — can risk damaging the ansa cervicalis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Buccopharyngeal fascia: Covers the pharyngeal constrictor muscles and is continuous with the pretracheal fascia. It is unrelated to the anatomical path of the ansa cervicalis.

 

Option B. Prevertebral fascia: Surrounds the vertebral column and deep neck muscles (longus colli, longus capitis, scalene muscles). The ansa cervicalis lies more superficially and is not contained here.

 

Option D. Investing fascia: The most superficial layer of the deep cervical fascia, enclosing the trapezius and sternocleidomastoid muscles. It does not contain the ansa cervicalis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ansa cervicalis is embedded within the carotid sheath, alongside the common carotid artery, internal jugular vein, and vagus nerve.

choices.text: Pleomorphic adenoma can occur in the submandibular gland
Warthin’s tumor may arise from the submandibular gland
Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common tumor of the parotid gland
Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor

questions.text: Regarding tumors of the salivary glands, which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Warthin’s tumor may arise from the submandibular gland

 

  • Warthin’s tumor (papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum) is a benign salivary gland tumor that occurs only in the parotid gland.
  • It does not arise in the submandibular, sublingual, or minor salivary glands, making this statement false.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pleomorphic adenoma can occur in the submandibular gland: This is true. Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common salivary gland tumor overall and can arise in the parotid, submandibular, and sublingual glands.

 

Option C. Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common tumor of the parotid gland: This is correct. Among tumors of the parotid gland, pleomorphic adenoma remains the most common benign neoplasm.

 

Option D. Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor: This is correct. Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most frequent malignant tumor of both major and minor salivary glands. Adenoid cystic carcinoma is also common, especially in minor salivary glands, but mucoepidermoid carcinoma ranks as the most frequent.

 

Educational Objective:


Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumor of salivary glands, while mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor; Warthin’s tumor is unique to the parotid gland.

choices.text: Encodes an altered PBP-2c with reduced β-lactam affinity
More common than mecA in clinical MRSA isolates
Causes resistance only to methicillin but not other β-lactams

questions.text: Regarding mecC gene in MRSA, which is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Encodes an altered PBP-2c with reduced β-lactam affinity

 

  • The mecC gene is a recently identified chromosomal gene found in certain MRSA strains.
  • It encodes PBP-2c, an altered penicillin-binding protein with low affinity for all β-lactam antibiotics, similar to PBP-2a in mecA-mediated resistance.
  • While mecC is important epidemiologically, it is far less common than mecA in clinical isolates.
  • It is not species-specific to S. epidermidis, and it does not confer resistance only to methicillin—it also affects other β-lactams.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. More common than mecA in clinical MRSA isolates: Incorrect. mecA is overwhelmingly the most common MRSA resistance gene in clinical settings.

 

Option C. Found exclusively in S. Epidermidis: Incorrect; mecC is found in S. aureus and other Staphylococcus species but is not exclusive to S. epidermidis.

 

Option D. Causes resistance only to methicillinbut not other β-lactams: Incorrect; mecC-mediated PBP-2c confers resistance to all β-lactams, not just methicillin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • mecC gene in MRSA encodes PBP-2c, an altered penicillin-binding protein with low β-lactam affinity, causing broad β-lactam resistance. 
  • It is rare compared to mecA and has epidemiological significance in surveillance of MRSA strains.

choices.text: The ATP-producing step catalyzed by phosphoglycerate kinase is bypassed
The enzyme involved is phosphoglycerate mutase
The production of 2,3-BPG increases hemoglobin’s oxygen affinity
This pathway functions in red blood cells of humans and other mammals

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Luebering–Rapoport pathway is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The production of 2,3-BPG increases hemoglobin’s oxygen affinity

 

  • The Luebering–Rapoport pathway is a side branch of glycolysis found exclusively in red blood cells of humans and many mammals. 
  • It allows 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate to be converted into 2,3-bisphosphoglycerate by bisphosphoglycerate mutase (a specialized form of phosphoglycerate mutase).
  • 2,3-BPG binds to the β chains of deoxyhemoglobin in the central cavity, stabilizing the low-affinity T (tense) state. 
  • This reduces hemoglobin’s affinity for oxygen, shifting the oxygen–hemoglobin dissociation curve to the right and facilitating oxygen unloading in peripheral tissues. 
  • Therefore, the idea that 2,3-BPG increases oxygen affinity is incorrect—the opposite is true.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The ATP-producing step catalyzed by phosphoglycerate kinase is bypassed: Correct. By diverting 1,3-BPG away from the phosphoglycerate kinase step, the pathway sacrifices ATP generation in favor of regulating oxygen delivery.

 

Option B. The enzyme involved is phosphoglycerate mutase: Correct. In red blood cells, a specialized bisphosphoglycerate mutase catalyzes the formation of 2,3-BPG from 1,3-BPG.

 

Option D. This pathway functions in red blood cells of humans and other mammals: Correct. The Luebering–Rapoport pathway is a well-established metabolic feature of mammalian erythrocytes, crucial for fine-tuning oxygen release.

 

Educational Objective:

 

2,3-BPG production in red blood cells decreases hemoglobin’s oxygen affinity, enhancing oxygen release to tissues; it is generated via the Luebering–Rapoport pathway, which bypasses an ATP-producing step in glycolysis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with alcohol dependence presents for relapse prevention therapy. He has abstained from alcohol for 2 weeks after detoxification. His past medical history is significant for alcohol-related liver disease. He is motivated to stay sober and asks about medications that can reduce his risk of relapse. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacological agent for relapse prevention in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acamprosate

 

  • Acamprosate is considered the drug of choice for preventing relapse in patients with alcohol use disorder who also have underlying liver disease.
  • Unlike naltrexone or disulfiram, it is not metabolized by the liver but is excreted unchanged by the kidneys. 
  • This property makes it safe in the presence of hepatic dysfunction, a crucial consideration in patients whose alcohol use has already resulted in liver impairment. 
  • Furthermore, acamprosate has been tested in multiple randomized controlled trials and systematic reviews, establishing strong evidence that it reduces the likelihood of relapse and supports long-term abstinence.
  • Because of both its safety profile in liver disease and its robust efficacy data, acamprosate is the most appropriate choice for this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Naltrexone: Is effective for relapse prevention in alcohol use disorder, but it is hepatically metabolized and carries the risk of hepatotoxicity. For this reason, it is contraindicated in patients who already have significant liver disease.

 

Option C. Disulfiram: Works as a deterrent by causing unpleasant reactions when alcohol is consumed, but it is also associated with hepatotoxicity. In patients with impaired liver function, its use is unsafe and therefore not recommended.

 

Option D. Baclofen: Has some supportive evidence for use in alcohol-dependent patients, particularly those with advanced cirrhosis, but the overall strength of evidence for efficacy is weaker compared to acamprosate. It is generally considered only when first-line agents cannot be used.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with alcohol dependence and liver disease, acamprosate is the preferred drug for relapse prevention because it is renally excreted and supported by strong evidence for efficacy in maintaining abstinence.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman with stricturing Crohn’s disease involving the ileum has undergone multiple ileal resections for bowel obstruction. What is she at increased risk for?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

  • Ileal Crohn’s disease and resections impair bile acid, fat-soluble vitamin, and calcium absorption.
  • Gallstones: Bile acid malabsorption increases cholesterol saturation in bile, promoting gallstone formation.
  • Kidney stones: Hyperoxaluria from fat malabsorption leads to calcium oxalate stones.
  • Osteoporosis: Vitamin D and calcium malabsorption reduce bone density, increasing fracture risk.
  • Monitoring and supplementation are critical in these patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ileal Crohn’s disease increases risks of gallstones, kidney stones, and osteoporosis.
  • Bile acid malabsorption drives gallstone and kidney stone formation.
  • Nutritional support and monitoring prevent complications post-resection.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman with multiple subcortical ischemic strokes over five years, despite no stroke risk factors, presents for evaluation. She has migraines with aura since adolescence, and her family history includes severe migraines in her sister and early strokes and cognitive impairment in her mother. Brain MRI shows subcortical strokes and white matter changes. Genetic testing is most likely to show abnormalities in which gene?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) NOTCH3

 

  • The presentation suggests CADASIL (Cerebral Autosomal Dominant Arteriopathy with Subcortical Infarcts and Leukoencephalopathy).
  • Recurrent subcortical strokes, migraines with aura, and family history of strokes/cognitive decline are characteristic.
  • NOTCH3 gene mutations impair vascular smooth muscle, causing small vessel disease.
  • MRI shows subcortical infarcts and white matter hyperintensities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. α-galactosidase A (GAL) gene: Associated with Fabry disease, causing strokes, pain crises, and skin findings, not subcortical strokes.

 

Option B. COLA1 mutation: Linked to Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, causing vascular issues but not recurrent subcortical strokes.

 

Option C. HtrA serine peptidase 1 (HTRA1) gene: Associated with brain aneurysms, not CADASIL’s stroke pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • CADASIL causes subcortical strokes and migraines, linked to NOTCH3 mutations.
  • MRI shows white matter changes and infarcts.
  • Genetic testing confirms diagnosis in young patients with recurrent strokes.

choices.text: Give an additional liter of normal saline

questions.text: A 75-year-old man with hypertension, atrial fibrillation, COPD, diabetes, and chronic kidney disease on hemodialysis presents with confusion and inability to get off the couch post-dialysis. EMS notes hypotension (78/33 mmHg). He receives 1 L normal saline en route. On arrival, his temperature is 35.6°C, heart rate 82/min, blood pressure 92/52 mmHg, respiratory rate 28/min, and SpO₂ 88%. He is somnolent, with clear lungs and a soft abdomen. Labs show WBC 11 × 10⁹/L, creatinine 4.9 mg/dL, and lactate 3.7 mmol/L. Blood cultures are pending. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Start broad-spectrum antibiotics

 

  • The presentation suggests sepsis, likely dialysis-related (e.g., catheter infection).
  • Confusion, hypotension, and elevated lactate (3.7 mmol/L) indicate septic shock.
  • WBC elevation suggests infection.
  • Broad-spectrum antibiotics (e.g., vancomycin, ceftazidime) are critical to target potential pathogens.
  • Fluid resuscitation continues alongside antibiotics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Give an additional liter of normal saline: Fluids are important, but antibiotics are the priority for suspected sepsis.

 

Option C. Start hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone: Used for adrenal insufficiency, not indicated without shock unresponsive to fluids.

 

Option D. Start Norepinephrine: Considered if hypotension persists after fluids and antibiotics, not first-line.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sepsis presents with confusion, hypotension, and elevated lactate.
  • Broad-spectrum antibiotics are the first step in suspected sepsis.
  • Dialysis patients are at risk for catheter-related infections.

choices.text: Comedo subtype of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS)

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman undergoes routine breast screening with mammography. Imaging reveals clustered microcalcifications. A core-needle biopsy is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Comedo subtype of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS)

 

  • The vignette specifies a 55-year-old woman, mammography performed for routine breast screening, and a finding of microcalcifications in a clustered pattern. 
  • Histology on the biopsy shown demonstrates ducts distended by high-grade pleomorphic cells with central “comedo-necrosis.” Necrotic debris commonly undergoes dystrophic calcification, explaining the microcalcifications on imaging. 
  • This constellation—microcalcifications plus central necrosis within ducts—is classic for the comedo subtype of DCIS, making it the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lobular carcinoma in situ: Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) is composed of dyscohesive cells (loss of E-cadherin) that expand lobules and is usually an incidental finding; it typically does not produce clustered microcalcifications on routine mammography, and the biopsy image (duct with central necrosis) is not consistent with LCIS.

 

 

Option C. Colloid (mucinous) carcinoma: An invasive carcinoma characterized by abundant extracellular mucin with tumor cells floating in mucin pools. It often presents as a soft mass, not as clustered microcalcifications on screening mammography; histology showing mucin lakes is absent in the biopsy shown.

 

 

Option D. Cribriform subtype of DCIS: Another in-situ pattern with uniform “cookie-cutter”/sieve-like spaces within ducts but without central comedonecrosis. The biopsy image highlights central necrosis rather than cribriform architecture, and the clustered microcalcifications in this case are better explained by necrosis-related calcification seen in comedo DCIS.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Comedo DCIS presents on mammography as clustered microcalcifications due to dystrophic calcification of central necrosis (“comedonecrosis”) within distended ducts containing high-grade pleomorphic cells.

questions.text: Which of the following phospholipids serve as a source of second messengers?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phosphatidylinositol

 

  • Phosphatidylinositol in the plasma membrane can be phosphorylated to phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PIP₂). 
  • Upon activation of certain G protein–coupled receptors (via Gq proteins), phospholipase C cleaves PIP₂ into two important second messengers:
    • Inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate (IP₃) – mobilizes calcium from the endoplasmic reticulum
    • Diacylglycerol (DAG) – activates protein kinase C
  • This signaling pathway is critical for functions such as smooth muscle contraction, secretion, and metabolism regulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phosphatidylserine: Incorrect. Phosphatidylserine is mainly located on the inner leaflet of the plasma membrane and plays a structural role; it is the marker of apoptosis.

 

Option C. Phosphatidylcholine: Incorrect. While phosphatidylcholine can be metabolized into other molecules (e.g., platelet-activating factor), it is not the classical source for IP₃ and DAG in second messenger systems.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PIP₂) is cleaved by phospholipase C to produce the second messengers IP₃ and DAG, which mediate calcium release and protein kinase C activation, respectively.

questions.text: A 60‑year‑old woman receiving high‑dose cisplatin for ovarian cancer is at risk for acute nephrotoxicity. Which diuretic is preferred to help protect her kidneys during cisplatin infusion?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mannitol

 

  • Cisplatin causes dose‑dependent acute tubular injury by concentrating in renal tubular cells. 
  • Mannitol, an osmotic diuretic, increases urine flow and renal tubular fluid volume, reducing tubular cisplatin concentration and thereby mitigating nephrotoxicity. 
  • By osmotically drawing water into the tubule, mannitol helps “flush” the nephron and protect against cisplatin‑induced injury.
  • Alternative options are - Saline loading or Amifostine

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acetazolamide: A carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that alkalinizes urine and decreases proximal bicarbonate reabsorption. It does not significantly increase overall urine flow or dilute nephrotoxic drug concentration in distal tubules, making it less effective for cisplatin protection.

 

Option C. Hydrochlorothiazide: A thiazide diuretic acts on the distal tubule to block sodium‑chloride reabsorption. Its modest diuretic effect and risk of volume depletion can worsen cisplatin nephrotoxicity rather than prevent it.

 

Option D. Furosemide: A loop diuretic that promotes diuresis but can cause electrolyte disturbances (e.g., hypokalemia, volume depletion) and does not provide the same osmotic flushing action; it is less favored for cisplatin renal protection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When administering cisplatin, osmotic diuresis with mannitol is the diuretic of choice to reduce tubular drug concentration and protect against acute nephrotoxicity.

choices.text: Increased PCO₂ decreases hemoglobin’s affinity for oxygen
It produces a leftward shift of the oxygen–hemoglobin dissociation curve
The effect is mediated by high hydrogen ions (H⁺)
All of the above are true

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding the Bohr effect in hemoglobin?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It produces a leftward shift of the oxygen–hemoglobin dissociation curve

 

  • The Bohr effect describes how an increase in CO₂ and H⁺ concentration reduces hemoglobin’s affinity for oxygen, causing the O₂–Hb dissociation curve to shift to the right, not to the left.
  • This facilitates oxygen unloading in metabolically active tissues where CO₂ and H⁺ levels are high.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased PCO₂ decreases hemoglobin’s affinity for oxygen: This is true. High CO₂ levels generate more H⁺ via carbonic acid dissociation, which stabilizes the taut form of Hb, promoting oxygen release.

 

Option C. The Effect is mediated by high hydrogen ions (H⁺): This is true. Hydrogen ions bind to the globin chains of Hb, altering its configuration and lowering O₂ affinity. Thus, the Bohr effect is essentially a pH-dependent shift.

 

Educational Objective:


The Bohr effect refers to the rightward shift of the O₂–Hb dissociation curve due to increased CO₂ and H⁺, enhancing O₂ unloading in tissues; a leftward shift is not part of this mechanism.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presented with recurrent pain abdomen, failure to thrive and iron deficiency anemia refractory to Iron therapy. His anti TTG anti-body titres were 300 U/L. An upper GI endoscopy was done and duodenal biopsy was taken which showed the following. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Celiac disease

 

  • Celiac disease is an autoimmune enteropathy triggered by gluten in genetically predisposed individuals.
  • Hallmark histologic findings include villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and increased intraepithelial lymphocytes, which lead to malabsorption. 
  • The elevated anti-tTG antibody levels and the biopsy changes confirm the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Crohn disease: Crohn disease typically shows transmural inflammation, non-caseating granulomas, and skip lesions, not villous atrophy. It also presents with abdominal pain, diarrhea, and perianal disease rather than refractory iron deficiency anemia.

 

Option B. Hirschsprung disease: This congenital condition results from absence of ganglion cells in the distal colon, leading to severe constipation, abdominal distension, and delayed meconium passage. It does not cause villous atrophy or malabsorption.

 

Option D. Congenital lactase deficiency: This rare condition leads to osmotic diarrhea due to inability to digest lactose, but histology is normal. It does not cause villous blunting or positive anti-tTG antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:


Celiac disease is diagnosed by serologic testing (anti-tTG antibodies) and confirmatory duodenal biopsy showing villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and intraepithelial lymphocytosis in children with malabsorption and refractory anemia.

choices.text: Watchful waiting due to absence of symptoms

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is undergoing a routine abdominal and pelvic evaluation for health check. Examination reveals a non-tender, enlarged uterus equivalent to a 14-week pregnancy. She denies heavy menstrual bleeding, pelvic pressure, urinary symptoms, or pain. An ultrasound confirms a 5cm intramural fibroid. What is the most appropriate next step in her management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Watchful waiting due to absence of symptoms

 

  • This patient has an incidentally discovered uterine fibroid (leiomyoma) that is asymptomatic. Fibroids are benign smooth muscle tumors of the myometrium that can vary in size and location.
  • Management depends primarily on:
    • Presence or absence of symptoms (e.g., heavy bleeding, pelvic pain, infertility, urinary frequency)
    • Rate of growth
    • Impact on quality of life
  • In asymptomatic patients, no immediate intervention is required regardless of fibroid size. 
  • Observation with periodic follow-up is recommended because treatment risks may outweigh benefits in the absence of symptoms.
  • This approach is often termed expectant management or watchful waiting.

     

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hysterectomy: Incorrect. Hysterectomy is reserved for women with severe symptoms who have completed childbearing or for fibroids unresponsive to medical therapy. It is not indicated in asymptomatic patients.

 

Option B. Initiate hormonal therapy: Incorrect. Hormonal therapy (e.g., combined oral contraceptives, progestins, GnRH analogs) is used to control symptoms such as heavy bleeding or pain. This patient has no such complaints, making hormonal therapy unnecessary.

 

Option D. Myomectomy: Incorrect. Myomectomy is indicated for symptomatic fibroids in women who wish to preserve fertility. It is not appropriate for asymptomatic cases, regardless of fibroid size, when there is no reproductive goal driving intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Asymptomatic uterine fibroids, even if large, are managed with watchful waiting and periodic monitoring rather than immediate intervention.

questions.text: During routine urine microscopy of a 45-year-old man with flank pain and renal colic, numerous crystals are observed in the urine analysis. Based on these findings, which type of crystal is most likely present?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Calcium oxalate dihydrate stone

 

  • Calcium oxalate crystals are typically seen in acidic or neutral urine and classically appear as envelope-shaped or bipyramidal forms under the microscope. 
  • They are among the most common types of urinary crystals and are strongly associated with calcium oxalate renal stones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ammonium phosphate stone: Ammonium magnesium phosphate (struvite) crystals are seen in alkaline urine and have a characteristic “coffin-lid” appearance. They are typically associated with urinary tract infections by urease-producing organisms, not the envelope-like morphology described here.

 

Option C. Uric acid: Uric acid crystals are usually yellow to reddish-brown and form rhomboid, rosette, or barrel-shaped crystals. They are commonly found in acidic urine and associated with gout or high purine intake, but their morphology differs from calcium oxalate.

 

Option D. Calcium oxalate monohydrate stone: Calcium oxalate monohydrate crystals are rare and usually appear as large, round, or dumbbell-shaped structures or figure of 8 shaped

 

Educational Objective:


Calcium oxalate dihydrate crystals appear as envelope-shaped structures on microscopy and are strongly associated with calcium oxalate renal stones.

questions.text:
A female infant born at 26 weeks gestation with a birth weight of 900 g remains in the neonatal ICU on supplemental oxygen. At 4 weeks of age, dilated retinal examination is performed. Arrange the following fundoscopic findings in the correct chronological order as they appear in the natural progression of the disease the child is suspected of developing.

 

  1. Partial retinal detachment
  2. Demarcation line
  3. Elevated ridge
  4. Total retinal detachment
  5. Extraretinal neovascularization extending into the vitreous
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 → 3 → 5 → 1 → 4

 

  • The stages of ROP correspond to progressive retinal vascular pathology and traction:
    • 2. Demarcation line (Stage 1): A thin white line appears at the junction between vascularized and avascular retina.
    • 3. Elevated ridge (Stage 2): The line thickens and elevates into a ridge.
    • 5. Extraretinal neovascularization extending into the vitreous (Stage 3): Pathologic new vessels proliferate beyond the ridge into the vitreous, risking traction.
    • 1. Partial (subtotal) retinal detachment (Stage 4): Fibrovascular proliferation contracts, producing localized traction and partial detachment.
    • 4. Total retinal detachment (Stage 5): Progressive traction leads to funnel‐shaped, total detachment of the retina.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • ROP progresses:

 

1. Demarcation line → 2. Elevated ridge → 3. Extraretinal neovascularization → 4. Partial retinal detachment → 5. Total retinal detachment.

 

  • Early detection at Stage 1–2 offers the best window for laser or anti-VEGF therapy to prevent vision loss.

 

Note – ROP Screening Guidelines:

questions.text: A 46-year-old man comes to the clinic after noticing a superficial vessel in the upper part of his right arm that becomes more visible when he lifts weights or performs strenuous activity. He has no pain, redness, swelling, or history of trauma. Examination reveals a prominent, non-pulsatile linear structure in the groove between the deltoid and pectoralis major muscles. Which of the following structures is most likely being observed?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cephalic vein

 

  • The deltopectoral groove is the surface landmark between the deltoid and pectoralis major muscles. 
  • The cephalic vein, a major superficial vein of the upper limb, runs through this groove before piercing the clavipectoral fascia to join the axillary vein.
  • It is non-pulsatile because it is a vein, not an artery.
  • It may be more prominent in lean individuals or during conditions that increase venous return, such as exercise or heavy lifting.
  • The absence of pain, swelling, or redness makes thrombosis or inflammation unlikely in this case.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Basilic vein: Runs along the medial side of the forearm and arm, eventually joining the brachial vein to form the axillary vein. It does not pass through the deltopectoral groove and would not appear in the location described.

 

Option C. Radial nerve: A deep nerve of the posterior compartment of the arm that is not visible superficially. Nerves are not observed as superficial, linear vascular structures.

 

Option D. Axillary artery: A deep, pulsatile artery located in the axilla, not in the superficial groove between the deltoid and pectoralis major muscles. It would not appear as a superficial vein-like structure and would have a palpable pulse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cephalic vein courses through the deltopectoral groove and is a superficial vein that becomes more visible with increased venous return, such as during exercise or in individuals with low subcutaneous fat.

choices.text: Check baseline ACTH and perform cosyntropin stimulation test
Refer for abdominal CT scan adrenal protocol

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman with hypothyroidism, managed with levothyroxine 100 µg daily and stable TSH, presents with extreme fatigue, barely able to get out of bed. She reports dizziness when standing, a craving for salty foods, and darker skin than usual. She denies recent illness, travel, or substance use. On exam, she appears ill, with blood pressure 85/60 mmHg, heart rate 110/min, temperature 37.6°C, and respiratory rate 15/min. Her abdomen is soft, and her skin is dry and tanned. In the ER, she receives IV hydrocortisone and 3 L normal saline, normalizing her potassium from 5.6 mmol/L to 4.0 mmol/L, and she feels better. What is the next appropriate step in her management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Check baseline ACTH and perform cosyntropin stimulation test

 

  • The presentation suggests Addison’s disease (primary adrenal insufficiency).
  • Fatigue, orthostatic hypotension, salt craving, and hyperpigmentation indicate adrenal failure.
  • Hyperkalemia (5.6 mmol/L) and response to hydrocortisone support the diagnosis.
  • Elevated ACTH and minimal cortisol response to cosyntropin confirm primary adrenal insufficiency.
  • This testing guides long-term glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid replacement. 
  • In India most common cause of adrenal insufficiency is TB.
  • In Western world most common cause of adrenal insufficiency is Autoimmune adrenalitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Check aldosterone and renin levels: Useful for primary hyperaldosteronism, not adrenal insufficiency, where ACTH and cosyntropin testing are diagnostic.

 

Option B. Check antiadrenal antibodies: Associated with autoimmune adrenalitis but not required for diagnosis in this clear clinical picture.

 

Option D. Refer for abdominal CT scan adrenal protocol: Helpful for identifying structural causes (e.g., tumors), but autoimmune adrenalitis is more likely here, and CT is not needed for diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Addison’s disease presents with fatigue, hypotension, hyperpigmentation, and hyperkalemia.
  • ACTH and cosyntropin stimulation tests confirm primary adrenal insufficiency.
  • Early hydrocortisone and saline stabilize acute adrenal crisis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male complains of persistent shoulder pain and weakness, especially when reaching overhead. He reports a history of frequent overhead activity as a swimmer. On physical exam, he has positive Neer's and Hawkin's signs. What is the most likely pathology?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rotator cuff impingement

 

 

  • The patient's history of frequent overhead activity (swimming) and his symptoms of persistent pain and weakness with overhead reaching are classic for impingement. 
  • The positive Neer's sign (pain with passive forward flexion of the shoulder) and Hawkin's sign (pain with internal rotation of the flexed shoulder) are specific physical exam maneuvers that compress the rotator cuff tendons under the acromion, reproducing the symptoms of impingement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biceps tendon rupture: 

 

  • A biceps tendon rupture is a less likely diagnosis. 
  • This injury typically presents with a sudden, sharp pain and a visible deformity, often described as a "Popeye" muscle, due to the biceps muscle balling up in the upper arm. 
  • While it can cause weakness, the primary signs are a sudden onset and a palpable or visible deformity, which are not mentioned in this case.

 

Option B. Glenohumeral instability: 

 

  • Glenohumeral instability usually results from a traumatic event, such as a dislocation. 
  • It is characterized by a feeling of the shoulder "giving out" or a "dead arm" sensation, especially during athletic maneuvers. 
  • While it can cause pain and weakness, the positive Neer's and Hawkin's signs are more specific to impingement rather than instability.

 

Option D. Acromioclavicular (AC) joint separation: 

 

  • An AC joint separation results from a direct fall onto the shoulder or a blow to the tip of the shoulder. 
  • This injury presents with localized pain and swelling directly over the AC joint, and a visible deformity or "step-off" may be present depending on the severity of the separation. 
  • Pain is not typically reproduced by Neer's or Hawkin's signs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rotator cuff impingement, also known as subacromial impingement syndrome, is a common cause of shoulder pain.
  • It occurs when the tendons of the rotator cuff (a group of muscles and tendons that surround the shoulder joint) become compressed or "pinched" in the space beneath the acromion (the bony top of the shoulder blade).

questions.text: Match each prenatal test (Column A) with its corresponding key characteristic (Column B):
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-C, 2-B, 3-D, 4-A

 

1-C: Cell-free DNA testing (cfDNA) → Non-invasive, ~99% sensitivity for Down syndrome; ideal for high-risk pregnancies:

 

  • Non-invasive prenatal screening (NIPS) that analyzes fetal DNA fragments in maternal blood.
  • Has ~99% sensitivity and specificity for Down syndrome.
  • Recommended for high-risk pregnancies (e.g., advanced maternal age, abnormal ultrasound findings, positive serum screen).

 

2-B: Chorionic villous sampling (CVS) → Invasive diagnostic test with miscarriage risk; provides definitive results:

 

  • Invasive procedure performed in the first trimester to obtain placental tissue for karyotyping or genetic testing.
  • Provides definitive diagnosis of chromosomal abnormalities.
  • Carries a risk of miscarriage, so it is not used as a first-line screening test.

 

3-D: Quadruple screening test → Second-trimester serum test; lower detection rate than cfDNA:

 

  • Performed in the second trimester (15:20 weeks).
  • Measures AFP, hCG, estriol, and inhibin A.
  • Has a lower detection rate for Down syndrome compared to cfDNA, but still used in low- to moderate-risk pregnancies.

 

4-A: Nuchal translucency scan → First-trimester ultrasound measurement; less accurate when used alone:

 

  • Ultrasound measurement of the fluid-filled space at the back of the fetal neck in the first trimester.
  • Increased thickness is associated with chromosomal abnormalities.
  • Less accurate when used alone; typically combined with serum markers for better detection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • cfDNA is the most accurate non-invasive prenatal screening test for Down syndrome, especially in high-risk pregnancies.
  • CVS provides definitive diagnosis but carries miscarriage risk.
  • Quadruple test is a second-trimester screen with lower detection accuracy.
  • Nuchal translucency is a first-trimester ultrasound marker and should be combined with serum tests for optimal accuracy.

questions.text: A 28-year-old software developer was found dead at home after neighbors reported a foul odor. He was naked, suspended by a rope tied to the ceiling fan, with a towel wrapped around the rope. The body was in a semi-seated position. Pornographic magazines were scattered on the floor, and a mirror was positioned directly in front of the body. Autopsy reveals findings consistent with hanging, and no signs of struggle or defensive wounds. What is the most likely manner of death?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Accidental

 

  • The scenario is characteristic of autoerotic asphyxiation, a practice in which individuals intentionally restrict oxygen during sexual activity to enhance sexual arousal. 
  • Key features supporting accidental death include:
    • Presence of pornographic materials and mirror → indicates sexual activity, not suicidal intent.
    • No signs of struggle or defensive wounds → rules out foul play.
    • Semi-seated suspension with towel → typical setup in autoerotic asphyxiation.
    • Death occurs unintentionally due to asphyxia (mechanism), not desire to die.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suicidal:

 

  • Suicide by hanging usually shows intent to die.
  • The sexual paraphernalia and mirror suggest pleasure-seeking, not self-harm.

 

Option C. Homicidal:

 

  • No defensive wounds, struggle marks, or evidence of third-party involvement.
  • Homicide is therefore unlikely.

 

Option D. Asphyxia:

 

  • This is the mechanism of death, not the manner of death.
  • Manner of death refers to intent (accidental, suicidal, homicidal, natural, undetermined).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In forensic medicine, the manner of death refers to the circumstances (e.g., natural, accidental, suicidal, homicidal) under which death occurred.
  • Autoerotic asphyxiation is a classic example of accidental death despite asphyxia being the mechanism.

choices.text: Eosinophilic infiltration in the ducts and glands
Lymphocytic infiltration in the salivary ducts and glands
Deposition of amyloid in exocrine glands causing dysfunction
Neutrophilic infiltration in the salivary ducts

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman presents with a 2-year history of progressive dry eyes and dry mouth. She also reports difficulty swallowing dry foods and occasional parotid gland swelling. Laboratory studies reveal the presence of anti-Ro (SSA) antibodies. A minor salivary gland biopsy is performed. Which of the following histopathologic findings is most likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lymphocytic infiltration in the salivary ducts and glands

 

  • This patient’s presentation — chronic dry eyes (keratoconjunctivitis sicca), dry mouth (xerostomia), and anti-Ro/SSA antibody positivity — is consistent with Sjögren syndrome, an autoimmune disorder targeting exocrine glands. 
  • The hallmark biopsy finding is focal lymphocytic sialadenitis — dense aggregates of CD4+ T lymphocytes and plasma cells infiltrating the salivary ducts and glands. 
  • This leads to glandular destruction, decreased secretions, and the classic sicca symptoms.
  • The disease may occur as a primary condition or secondary to other autoimmune diseases (eg, rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Eosinophilic infiltration in the ducts and glands: Suggestive of allergic or parasitic processes, not the lymphocyte-predominant infiltrate seen in Sjögren syndrome.

 

Option C. Deposition of amyloid in exocrine glands causing dysfunction: Seen in systemic amyloidosis, not in Sjögren syndrome. Amyloid deposition produces amorphous, eosinophilic material on biopsy and is Congo red–positive with apple-green birefringence.

 

Option D. Neutrophilic infiltration in the salivary ducts: This is characteristic of acute suppurative sialadenitis, usually due to bacterial infection, not chronic autoimmune disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sjögren syndrome is an autoimmune disorder of the exocrine glands characterized by anti-Ro/SSA antibodies and lymphocytic infiltration of salivary and lacrimal glands, leading to chronic dry eyes and mouth.

choices.text: A patient undergoing community-based diabetes screening
A patient in a low-prevalence population study
A patient with high pre-test probability where confirmation is essential
A newborn screening program for metabolic disorders

questions.text: At a higher cut-off of 7.2 mmol/L, the sensitivity falls significantly while specificity improves. Which of the following patients would benefit most from applying this cut-off in diagnostic decision-making?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A patient with high pre-test probability where confirmation is essential

 

  • Increasing the diagnostic cut-off → fewer false positives, more false negatives.
  • This favors specificity over sensitivity.
  • In patients with high pre-test probability (strong clinical suspicion, e.g., symptomatic adults with obesity, family history, etc.), the main goal is confirmation rather than screening.
  • A higher cut-off ensures that positive results are true positives, reducing the risk of unnecessary treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A patient undergoing community-based diabetes screening:

  • Screening requires high sensitivity to capture as many true positives as possible.
  • A low cut-off (not high) is preferred to minimize false negatives.

 

Option B. A patient in a low-prevalence population study:

  • In low prevalence, positive predictive value (PPV) falls.
  • Using a high cut-off here would miss many true cases (false negatives) — not desirable.

 

Option D. A newborn screening program for metabolic disorders:

  • Screening in newborns also requires maximal sensitivity.
  • Missing a case can be devastating. A lower cut-off is always used in screening, not higher.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • High cut-off → high specificity, low sensitivity → better for confirmation (rule in).
  • Low cut-off → high sensitivity, low specificity → better for screening (rule out).
  • Always align cut-off choice with clinical context (screening vs confirmation).

questions.text: A 40-year-old man has been brought to the psychiatry clinic by his employer. He believes his colleagues are constantly talking behind his back and conspiring to harm his reputation. He frequently misinterprets casual remarks as hidden insults and holds long-standing grudges. He refuses to confide in others due to fear that the information will be used against him. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Paranoid personality disorder

 

  • The patient's presentation — pervasive distrust and suspiciousness of others, misinterpreting benign remarks as hostile, bearing grudges, and reluctance to confide in others due to fear of exploitation — is characteristic of Paranoid Personality Disorder (PPD). 
  • These traits are long-standing and ego-syntonic, meaning the individual does not recognize them as problematic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Delusional disorder – persecutory type: This requires fixed, false delusions that are non-bizarre and persist for at least 1 month, often with well-systematized persecutory themes. However, this patient’s beliefs, though excessive, do not qualify as fixed delusions and are more personality-based.

 

Option C. Schizophrenia – paranoid type: Involves clear psychotic symptoms such as hallucinations, delusions, disorganized speech/behavior, and functional decline, none of which are described here.

 

Option D. Schizotypal personality disorder: Involves odd beliefs, magical thinking, and eccentric behavior, along with social anxiety and suspiciousness, but this patient does not exhibit thought distortions or eccentricity beyond suspiciousness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Paranoid Personality Disorder is characterized by excessive suspiciousness and pervasive distrust and suspicion of others, interpreting their motives as malevolent, even in the absence of objective evidence. 
  • They give excessive importance to themselves and believe in conspiracy theories. 
  • These patients may be excessively sensitive and may be quick to react angrily. 
  • Psychotherapy is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: Identify the stage of pressure sore from the image:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2

 

  • The picture shows partial-thickness skin loss involving the epidermis, which will be grade 2.
  • Grades (or stages) of pressure sores, also known as pressure ulcers or decubitus ulcers, are based on depth and tissue involvement. 
  • This classification is essential for wound assessment, documentation, and treatment planning:

 

 

Additional Categories:

 

  • Unstageable: Full-thickness tissue loss obscured by slough or eschar; depth cannot be determined until debrided.
  • Suspected Deep Tissue Injury (sDTI): Intact skin with persistent discoloration (purple/maroon), indicating damage to underlying soft tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Grading of pressure sore is based on amount of skin loss. In case of partial skin breach, it is designated grade 2. 
  • Grade I is reversible with pressure relief.
  • Grade IV often requires surgical intervention and carries high risk of complications.
  • Early identification and offloading are key to preventing progression.

choices.text: Initiate lifestyle modification, and if repeat office BP after 3 months remains ≥ 130/80 mmHg and 10y CV risk is ≥ 10%, start antihypertensive drug therapy.
Initiate pharmacological therapy now, aiming for a target systolic BP of 120–129 mmHg, regardless of risk score, using an “opt-out” approach.
Continue annual BP monitoring, and only start pharmacological therapy if BP rises to ≥ 150/90 mmHg.
Start combination therapy with an ACE inhibitor + thiazide-like diuretic immediately, since his office BP is already ≥ 130/80 mmHg.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man, active smoker with COPD and GERD, presents for an annual physical examination. His office BP has ranged 130–140 / 80–85 mmHg over the past 2 years, and today it is 135/85 mmHg. He has no diabetes, CKD, or established CVD. Laboratory results are unremarkable. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Initiate lifestyle modification, and if repeat office BP after 3 months remains ≥ 130/80 mmHg and his 10y CV risk is ≥ 10%, start antihypertensive drug therapy.

 

  • ESC 2024 introduces “elevated BP”: 120–139 / 70–89 mmHg.
  • Lifestyle measures (diet, exercise, smoking cessation, weight control, reduced alcohol/salt intake) are universally recommended.
  • Drug therapy threshold:
    • ≥ 140/90 mmHg → pharmacological therapy for all.
    • 130–139 / 80–89 mmHg → consider drug therapy only if the patient has high/very high CV risk (SCORE2 ≥ 10%), diabetes, CKD, or established CVD.
  • Target: Once therapy is started, aim for SBP 120–129 mmHg if tolerated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Initiate pharmacological therapy now, aiming for a target systolic BP of 120–129 mmHg, regardless of risk score, using an “opt-out” approach: Opt-out immediate therapy for all ≥ 130/80 is too aggressive; ESC recommends risk-based staging.

 

Option C. Continue annual BP monitoring, and only start pharmacological therapy if BP rises to ≥ 150/90 mmHg: Deferring until ≥ 150/90 ignores “elevated BP” and under-treats high-risk patients.

 

Option D. Start combination therapy with an ACE inhibitor + thiazide-like diuretic immediately, since his office BP is already ≥ 130/80 mmHg: Jumping straight to combination therapy at 135/85 without risk stratification is not guideline-based.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • ESC 2024 emphasizes risk-stratified, stepwise management: lifestyle for all, drug therapy for ≥ 140/90 or for ≥ 130/80 if SCORE2 ≥ 10% or other high-risk conditions.
  • Target BP on therapy: 120–129 mmHg systolic (as tolerated).

choices.text: Continue amyl nitrite and add sodium nitrite
Proceed directly to sodium thiosulfate infusion

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with suspected cyanide ingestion is treated with the 3-step antidote kit. After inhaling amyl nitrite, his blood pressure drops to 75 mmHg. Which is the best next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Discontinue nitrites and administer hydroxocobalamin

 

  • Amyl nitrite—and subsequently sodium nitrite—works by converting hemoglobin to methemoglobin, which competes with cytochrome oxidase for cyanide binding. 
  • However, nitrite-induced methemoglobinemia and accompanying vasodilation can significantly worsen hypotension. 
  • In patients whose systolic blood pressure falls below 80 mmHg, continuing nitrites risks cardiovascular collapse.
  • Hydroxocobalamin offers a safer alternative. It directly binds free cyanide to form cyanocobalamin without creating methemoglobin or causing vasodilation. 
  • Rapid complexation of cyanide by hydroxocobalamin restores mitochondrial respiration and is recommended when nitrite therapy is contraindicated by hypotension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Continue amyl nitrite and add sodium nitrite: Further nitrite administration would deepen methemoglobinemia and exacerbate hypotension, increasing the risk of shock.

 

Option C. Switch immediately to dicobalt edetate: Dicobalt edetate (Kelocyanor) also induces methemoglobin formation and carries a high risk of hypotension and adverse reactions; it is not preferred in a hypotensive patient. It is preferred only if no other antidote is available (as it is highly toxic).

 

Option D. Proceed directly to sodium thiosulfate infusion: Sodium thiosulfate acts by providing sulfate donors for rhodanese‐mediated conversion of cyanide to thiocyanate, but this process is slower. Without first rapidly sequestering cyanide, ongoing cytochrome oxidase inhibition persists, and hypotension is not directly addressed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cyanide‐poisoned patients with systolic blood pressure < 80 mmHg, nitrite‐based antidotes are contraindicated due to their vasodilatory and methemoglobin‐forming effects; hydroxocobalamin should be used to chelate cyanide without worsening hemodynamics.

questions.text: A histological section from a patient’s salivary gland biopsy is shown below. Based on this finding, which gland is most likely the source of the specimen?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sublingual

 

  • The sublingual gland is primarily composed of mucous acini with serous demilunes (crescent-shaped caps of serous cells) and only a small number of purely serous acini. 
  • These glands secrete predominantly mucous secretions that aid in lubrication during speech and swallowing.
  • Histologically, mucous acini have a pale, foamy cytoplasm due to mucin content, and the demilunes appear darker due to protein-rich serous secretions. 
  • The predominance of mucous acini with demilunes is a hallmark feature of the sublingual gland.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parotid: Composed almost entirely of serous acini with no significant mucous component. Histology shows dark-staining cells with basophilic cytoplasm due to abundant rough endoplasmic reticulum.

 

 

Option C. Submandibular: A mixed gland with both mucous and serous acini, but serous acini predominate. The ratio of serous to mucous acini is the reverse of the sublingual gland.

 

 

Option D. Minor labial salivary gland: Located in the submucosa of the lips and composed mostly of mucous acini without prominent serous demilunes. They are not a major salivary gland and have a different histologic pattern compared to sublingual glands.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sublingual gland is a major salivary gland composed predominantly of mucous acini with serous demilunes, a histologic pattern that distinguishes it from the parotid (serous) and submandibular (mixed but serous-dominant) glands.

choices.text: Pneumatic compression stocking to prevent DVT

questions.text: What is the purpose of this device?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pneumatic compression stocking to prevent DVT

 

  • Intermittent pneumatic compression (IPC) stockings are used to prevent deep vein thrombosis (DVT) by intermittently inflating, which increases venous return, reduces venous stasis, and promotes fibrinolysis.
  • They are particularly valuable in immobilized or postoperative patients at risk of thromboembolic events.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antishock garment: This is incorrect because antishock garments (also called pneumatic antishock trousers) are used in trauma patients to control hemorrhage and stabilize blood pressure in hypovolemic shock. They do not function by intermittently compressing the legs.

 

Option C. Skin warming system: This is incorrect because skin warming devices are used for maintaining normothermia during surgery or in hypothermic patients. They do not provide intermittent pressure and have no role in DVT prevention.

 

Option D. Massage device: This is incorrect because simple massage devices are used for comfort and muscle relaxation but lack the medical efficacy of IPC devices in preventing thrombus formation in deep veins.

 

Educational Objective:


Intermittent pneumatic compression stockings reduce venous stasis and are an effective prophylactic measure against deep vein thrombosis in high-risk, immobilized, or postoperative patients.

choices.text: Adoption and orphanages are reformative institutions aimed at juvenile delinquents.
Borstals focus on correction and skill development; remand homes provide observational care; foster homes focus on emotional support and family integration.
Foster homes are custodial only; remand homes are permanent; borstals are not rehabilitative.
Orphanages, borstals, and foster homes all provide identical educational and behavioral reformation services.

questions.text: Which of the following best reflects the different functional and reformative roles of juvenile care institutions in India?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Borstals focus on correction and skill development; remand homes provide observational care; foster homes focus on emotional support and family integration.

 

  • Borstals – Designed for juveniles (boys 16–21, girls 18–21) who are difficult to reform in ordinary institutions. They emphasize training, education, discipline, and moral reform, preventing contamination from adult prisons.
  • Remand homes – Temporary institutions for children awaiting trial or inquiry, focusing on observation, medical, psychological, and social assessment, not punishment.
  • Foster homes – Provide family-like nurturing, emotional support, and social integration, without custodial or punitive roles.
  • Thus, option B correctly distinguishes their reformative vs. custodial orientation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adoption and orphanages are reformative institutions aimed at juvenile delinquents: Wrong. Orphanages and adoption centers are custodial/social welfare institutions, not reformative, and not intended for delinquents.

 

Option C. Foster homes are custodial only; remand homes are permanent; borstals are not rehabilitative: Wrong. Foster homes are not custodial only, remand homes are short-term (not permanent), and borstals are specifically rehabilitative.

 

Option D. Orphanages, borstals, and foster homes all provide identical educational and behavioral reformation services: Wrong. Each institution has a unique role; they are not identical in scope.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Borstals → correctional & reformative training
  • Remand homes → short-term clinical & social observation
  • Foster homes → emotional support & integration into family environment
  • Institutions differ in focus: reformative vs. custodial vs. welfare, and should not be conflated.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency room after a fall while playing basketball. He reports hearing a “pop” in his knee and is unable to bear weight. On physical examination, the test shown in the image is positive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) tear

 

  • The mechanism of injury—twisting or hyperextension during a sport like basketball—is highly consistent with an ACL tear. 
  • The audible "pop" and immediate instability (inability to bear weight) are classic signs. 
  • The physical exam finding of excessive anterior tibial translation (as seen in a positive Lachman or anterior drawer test) directly confirms an ACL injury.
  • Lachman test is done in 20˚

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) rupture: 

 

  • A PCL injury is less common than an ACL tear and typically results from a direct blow to the front of the tibia, such as a dashboard injury in a car accident. 
  • A PCL tear is assessed with the posterior drawer test, which shows excessive backward movement of the tibia. 
  • While a "pop" can occur, the mechanism of injury and the specific test shown (which assesses anterior laxity) make this less likely.

 

Option C. Medial meniscus tear: 

 

  • A medial meniscus tear often occurs with a twisting injury, but it is typically associated with a "locking" or "catching" sensation in the knee, and swelling may develop more gradually. 
  • While a meniscus tear can cause pain and difficulty bearing weight, a positive Lachman or anterior drawer test specifically points to ligamentous instability, making a primary ACL tear a more precise diagnosis for the scenario described.

 

Option D. Patellar dislocation: 

 

  • Patellar dislocation involves the kneecap (patella) slipping out of its groove. 
  • The patient would present with visible deformity of the knee and intense pain. 
  • The patella would be displaced laterally, and the primary complaint would be the malposition of the kneecap. 
  • The physical exam would focus on relocating the patella, not on assessing for ligamentous laxity with tests like the Lachman test. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In an athlete with a twisting injury, a "pop" sound, inability to bear weight, and positive Lachman test, always suspect an ACL tear. It’s one of the most common knee injuries and requires early identification for optimal management and recovery.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man with type 2 diabetes, rheumatoid arthritis (RA), and gout presents with two days of right knee pain. He is seropositive for RF and anti-CCP, on methotrexate and infliximab, with well-controlled RA. He stopped allopurinol after a gout flare two years ago. Exam shows a swollen, erythematous knee with reduced motion. Labs show leukocytosis (13,500/µL) and GFR 35 mL/min. Knee X-ray is shown What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Arthrocentesis

 

  • The patient is immunosuppressed (methotrexate, infliximab), diabetic, and elderly → very high risk for septic arthritis.
  • Monoarticular flare + leukocytosis = infection must be excluded first.
  • Chondrocalcinosis:
    • Suggests possible CPPD (pseudogout), but this cannot be confirmed without joint fluid analysis.
  • Arthrocentesis:
    • Confirms/excludes septic arthritis (Gram stain, culture).
    • Identifies crystals (urate vs CPPD).
    • Guides therapy (antibiotics vs gout/pseudogout management).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blood cultures: Can support diagnosis but not definitive; septic arthritis requires synovial fluid analysis.

 

Option C. Start NSAIDs: Contraindicated due to CKD (GFR 35) and risk of worsening renal function. Also unsafe to empirically treat without excluding infection.

 

Option D. Corticosteroid injection: Intra-articular steroids are contraindicated if infection not excluded. Risk of worsening sepsis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In any patient with acute monoarthritis - especially with immunosuppression, arthrocentesis is the first and most important step to rule out septic arthritis before initiating therapy for gout or pseudogout.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the type of antigen presented by MHC class I molecules and the responding T cell subset?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Endogenous antigen; CD8+ T cells

 

  • MHC class I molecules present endogenous antigens, such as viral or cytosolic proteins synthesized within infected host cells.
  • These antigens are processed by the proteasome, transported to the endoplasmic reticulum, and loaded onto MHC I molecules.
  • MHC I presents antigens to CD8+ cytotoxic T cells, which can directly kill infected cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exogenous antigen; CD8+ T cells: Incorrect. CD8+ T cells respond to endogenous, not exogenous, antigens.

 

Option B. Endogenous antigen; CD4+ T cells: Incorrect. CD4+ T cells respond to exogenous antigens presented via MHC II.

 

Option D. Exogenous antigen; CD19+ B cells: Incorrect. CD19 is a B cell marker, not involved in MHC I/II presentation pathways directly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MHC class I present endogenous antigens (e.g., viral proteins) to CD8+ cytotoxic T cells, while MHC class II presents exogenous antigens to CD4+ helper T cells.

choices.text: Sorting is faster and focuses on survivors; sieving is done later
Sieving categorizes dead vs ambulatory; sorting assesses injury severity
Sieving is for hospital use; sorting is for field assessment
Sorting uses color codes; sieving does not involve color

questions.text: In a rural mass casualty incident, a healthcare worker begins triage sorting. Which of the following best differentiates triage sorting from triage sieving?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sieving categorizes dead vs ambulatory; sorting assesses injury severity

 

  • Triage sieving = first rapid step → quickly separates dead, ambulatory ("walking wounded"), and non-ambulatory victims.
    • Purpose: Immediate life prioritization in chaotic settings.
  • Triage sorting = second, more detailed step → evaluates injury severity, resource needs, and prognosis, assigning patients into categories (e.g., red, yellow, green, black).
    • Purpose: Prioritize treatment and transport.
  • Thus, sieving = who needs immediate help vs who can wait; sorting = how severe each case actually is.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sorting is faster and focuses on survivors; sieving is done later: Incorrect. Sieving is the faster first step. Sorting is more detailed and slower.

 

Option C. Sieving is for hospital use; sorting is for field assessment: Incorrect. Both are used in prehospital field triage, not restricted to hospitals.

 

Option D. Sorting uses color codes; sieving does not involve color: Incorrect. Both phases may use color coding, especially in sorting, but sieving can also involve basic tagging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Triage sieving = Quick field separation (ambulatory vs non-ambulatory, dead vs alive).
  • Triage sorting = Detailed injury assessment with color-coded prioritization (red, yellow, green, black).
  • First sieve, then sort.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man sustains a penetrating injury to the medial aspect of his wrist. During surgical exploration, a branch of the ulnar nerve proximal to the site of injury is noted. Which of the following muscles is innervated by this branch before it reaches the injured point?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Palmaris brevis

 

  • The ulnar nerve divides into superficial and deep branches at the level of the wrist. 
  • The superficial branch primarily provides cutaneous innervation to the medial one and a half digits but also sends a motor branch to the palmaris brevis muscle before giving off digital branches. 
  • Because the injury in this case is distal to the branching point for the palmaris brevis, this muscle would already have been supplied by the nerve before the injury site. 
  • This explains why the correct answer is palmaris brevis.
  • The palmaris brevis is a small, thin muscle located in the hypothenar eminence that wrinkles the skin over the hypothenar area, improving grip.
