  • It is innervated by the superficial branch of the ulnar nerve, a unique feature since most hypothenar muscles are innervated by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2nd Palmar interossei: Incorrect. The palmar interossei muscles are supplied by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve after it has passed distal to the branching point to the palmaris brevis. Therefore, if the injury is proximal to the supply to the interossei, these muscles would be affected, not spared.

 

Option C. 3rd Lumbrical: Incorrect. The 3rd lumbrical is innervated by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve, distal to the branch to the palmaris brevis. An injury proximal to its innervation point would impair its function.

 

Option D. Adductor pollicis: Incorrect. This muscle is also supplied by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve after it has passed through the deep palmar space. Its innervation occurs distal to the branch to the palmaris brevis, so it would be impaired if the injury is proximal to that point.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The palmaris brevis is the only muscle supplied by the superficial branch of the ulnar nerve and receives innervation before the nerve enters the hand to supply other intrinsic muscles.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with three months of low back pain and 60 minutes of morning stiffness. The pain improves with activity and worsens with rest. Naproxen twice daily helps but pain recurs off therapy. He denies rashes, eye symptoms, dysuria, or gastrointestinal issues. Examination shows tenderness over the lower spine and sacroiliac joints, with pain reproduced on hip flexion, abduction, and external rotation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ankylosing spondylitis

 

  • The presentation suggests ankylosing spondylitis (AS), a type of axial spondyloarthritis.
  • Chronic low back pain, morning stiffness, and improvement with activity are classic.
  • Sacroiliac joint tenderness and positive FABER test support AS.
  • Typically affects young men and is associated with HLA-B27.
  • Imaging may show sacroiliitis; NSAIDs like naproxen are first-line.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Rheumatoid arthritis: Affects peripheral joints (hands, wrists), not primarily axial skeleton.

 

Option C. Reactive arthritis: Follows infections, includes conjunctivitis or urethritis, not present here.

 

Option D. IBD-associated axial spondyloarthritis: Requires gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., diarrhea), absent in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ankylosing spondylitis causes chronic back pain and sacroiliac stiffness, improving with activity.
  • Positive FABER test and HLA-B27 association aid diagnosis.
  • NSAIDs are the first-line treatment for symptom control.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man arrives at the emergency department with severe abdominal pain after an episode of heavy alcohol intake. On arrival, he is in shock with a blood pressure of 70/50 mmHg, heart rate of 115/min, and oxygen saturation of 70%. Laboratory studies show a creatinine level of 2.4 mg/dL and markedly elevated transaminases. Contrast-enhanced CT of the abdomen is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Severe acute pancreatitis

 

  • The CT image demonstrates large areas of non-enhancing pancreatic tissue, consistent with necrosis.
  • Coupled with the patient’s hemodynamic instability, hypoxia, renal dysfunction, and raised transaminases, this presentation meets criteria for severe acute pancreatitis.
  • Severity scoring systems such as Ranson’s and Modified Glasgow criteria also emphasize age >55, hypoxemia, renal dysfunction, and elevated enzymes as predictors of severe disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Liver abscess: This is incorrect because a liver abscess would typically present as a localized hypodense lesion with rim enhancement in the liver, often accompanied by fever and sepsis. The clinical scenario and CT findings point toward diffuse pancreatic necrosis rather than a hepatic abscess.

 

Option B. Acute pancreatitis: While the patient certainly has acute pancreatitis, the clinical and radiological features suggest severe disease. The presence of multi-organ dysfunction and extensive necrosis upgrades this to “severe acute pancreatitis” rather than just uncomplicated acute pancreatitis.

 

Option C. Acute pyelonephritis: This is incorrect as pyelonephritis typically presents with fever, flank pain, pyuria, and imaging changes in the kidneys (striated nephrogram, perinephric fat stranding). The CT here shows necrotic pancreas, not renal involvement.

 

Educational Objective:


Severe acute pancreatitis is diagnosed when pancreatitis is associated with organ failure and/or pancreatic necrosis, often following alcohol abuse, and requires early recognition with supportive care guided by prognostic scoring systems.

choices.text: ≥4 contractions in 20 minutes with cervical change

questions.text: Which of the following findings would not be part of the diagnostic criteria for preterm labor?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cervix being posterior in position

 

  • Preterm labor is defined as regular uterine contractions causing progressive cervical change before 37 weeks’ gestation.
  • Diagnostic criteria typically include:
    • Cervical dilatation > 2 cm
    • Cervical effacement > 80%
    • Regular uterine contractions (≥4 in 20 minutes or ≥8 in 60 minutes) with cervical change
  • Cervical position (anterior, mid, posterior) is part of the Bishop score used to assess cervical readiness for induction, but it is not a diagnostic criterion for preterm labor. 
  • Therefore, a posterior cervical position alone does not confirm or exclude preterm labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Preterm labor is diagnosed when regular uterine contractions produce measurable cervical change before 37 weeks’ gestation. 
  • Cervical position is not part of the diagnostic criteria.

choices.text: Para‑aminosalicylic acid (PAS) is bactericidal and improves thyroid function.
Cycloserine commonly causes neuropsychiatric adverse effects.
Thioacetazone must be avoided in HIV‑infected patients due to severe hypersensitivity.

questions.text: A 35‑year‑old man with multidrug‑resistant tuberculosis is started on a regimen including several second‑line agents. Which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Para‑aminosalicylic acid (PAS) is bactericidal and improves thyroid function.

 

PAS is bacteriostatic, not bactericidal, and can impair thyroid function (hypothyroidism) rather than improve it.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ethionamide exhibits cross‑resistance with isoniazid: True. Ethionamide shares a similar activation pathway and target as isoniazid. Mutations that confer resistance to isoniazid in the katG or inhA genes often confer cross‑resistance to ethionamide.

 

Option C. Cycloserine commonly causes neuropsychiatric adverse effects: True. Cycloserine crosses the blood–brain barrier and antagonizes GABA receptors, frequently causing depression, psychosis, irritability, and even seizures at higher doses.

 

Option D. Thioacetazone must be avoided in HIV‑infected patients due to severe hypersensitivity: True. Thioacetazone carries a high risk of severe cutaneous hypersensitivity reactions (Stevens–Johnson syndrome, toxic epidermal necrolysis) in HIV‑infected patients and is therefore contraindicated in this population.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ethionamide ↔ Cross‑resistant with isoniazid
  • PAS ↔ Bacteriostatic and may cause hypothyroidism
  • Cycloserine ↔ High risk of neuropsychiatric side effects
  • Thioacetazone ↔ Avoid in HIV due to life‑threatening skin reactions

questions.text: Following is the graph showing renal tubular transport maxima for glucose excretion in a diabetic patient. What will be the urinary glucose in a patient with a blood sugar of 200 mg/dL and a glomerular filtration rate of 90 mL/min?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 30 mg/min

 

Renal transport maximum (Tm or Tmax)

 

  • Refers to the point at which increases in tubular concentration of a substance does not result in an increase in tubular reabsorption due to saturation of ion channels.
  • Quantity of a substance excreted = (filtration + secretion) – reabsorption
  • Glucose is not secreted, so excretion = filtration – reabsorption.
  • Amount Filtered of Glucose = Plasma Concentration × GFR
    90 mL/min × 200 mg/dL = 180 mg/min
  • Excretion rate of glucose = Amount filtered – Tubular maximum
    180 mg/min – 150 mg/min = 30 mg/min
  • So, the urinary glucose excretion rate = 30 mg/min

 

Educational Objective:


Urinary glucose excretion occurs when filtered glucose load exceeds the renal transport maximum (Tm); in this case, with plasma glucose 200 mg/dL and GFR 90 mL/min, urinary glucose = 30 mg/min.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman presents with two weeks of left-sided headache and fever, worsened by chewing. She denies sick contacts or travel. Her temperature is 38.4°C, heart rate 92/min, and blood pressure 128/67 mmHg. Cranial nerves and neurologic exam are normal. Labs are normal except for an ESR of 82 mm/h. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Start high-dose prednisolone

 

  • The presentation suggests giant cell arteritis (temporal arteritis).
  • Left-sided headache, jaw claudication, and fever are classic symptoms.
  • Elevated ESR (82 mm/h) supports an inflammatory process.
  • High-dose prednisolone (e.g., 40–60 mg/day) is started immediately to prevent complications like blindness.
  • Temporal artery biopsy confirms diagnosis but should not delay treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obtain brain MRI: Useful to rule out other headache causes, but not needed for suspected temporal arteritis; treatment should not be delayed.

 

Option B. Obtain lumbar puncture: Indicated for meningitis or hemorrhage, not supported by the absence of meningeal signs.

 

Option C. Obtain temporal artery biopsy: Required for definitive diagnosis but performed after starting prednisone, within 1–2 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Giant cell arteritis presents with headache, jaw claudication, and elevated ESR.
  • Immediate high-dose prednisone prevents vision loss.
  • Temporal artery biopsy confirms diagnosis but does not delay treatment.

choices.text: H. pylori serology and HIV testing

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with no alcohol, drug, or tobacco use presents with six months of epigastric pain, nausea after eating, and greasy, foul-smelling stools. Labs show decreased fecal elastase, fecal fat, HbA1c 9.0%, alkaline phosphatase 350 U/L, and total bilirubin 3.2 mg/dL, with normal ALT/AST. While awaiting imaging, what is the next most appropriate lab test?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Antinuclear antibody and IgG4 testing

 

  • The presentation suggests chronic pancreatitis with exocrine (fecal elastase, fat) and endocrine (HbA1c) dysfunction.
  • Elevated alkaline phosphatase and bilirubin suggest biliary involvement.
  • Without alcohol use, autoimmune pancreatitis (AIP) is a likely cause.
  • ANA and IgG4 levels help diagnose AIP, guiding corticosteroid therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blood and stool cultures: Relevant for infection, unlikely given chronic symptoms and no fever.

 

Option C. H. pylori serology and HIV testing: H. pylori doesn’t cause pancreatic insufficiency; HIV is not indicated without risk factors.

 

Option D. Serum alcohol level: Unnecessary, as the patient denies alcohol use.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chronic pancreatitis with no alcohol use suggests autoimmune pancreatitis.
  • ANA and IgG4 testing diagnose AIP.
  • Exocrine and endocrine pancreatic dysfunction are key features.

questions.text: Match the following conditions (List I) with their characteristic laboratory findings (List II) and select the correct combination:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) a–2, b–1, c–4, d–3

 

a) Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC) → 2) ↓ Platelets, ↑ PT & aPTT, ↓ Fibrinogen, ↑ D-dimer, schistocytes:

 

  • Lab pattern: ↓ Platelets, ↑ PT & aPTT, ↓ Fibrinogen, ↑ D-dimer, schistocytes.
  • Reason: DIC involves widespread activation of the coagulation cascade leading to consumption thrombocytopenia, depletion of clotting factors (↑ PT and aPTT), and hypofibrinogenemia.
  • ↑ D-dimer reflects fibrinolysis of cross-linked fibrin.
  • Schistocytes result from microangiopathic hemolytic anemia due to fibrin deposition in small vessels.
  • Common triggers: obstetric complications, sepsis, malignancy, trauma.

 

b) Hemophilia A → 1) Isolated ↑ aPTT with normal platelets, no fibrinogen decrease:

 

  • Lab pattern: Isolated ↑ aPTT, normal platelets, no fibrinogen decrease.
  • Reason: Hemophilia A is a factor VIII deficiency. Since factor VIII is part of the intrinsic pathway, aPTT is prolonged, but PT is normal.
  • Platelet count and fibrinogen remain normal because the disorder is due to a single coagulation factor deficiency, not consumption.

 

c) Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP) → 4) MAHA + thrombocytopenia, normal PT & aPTT, normal fibrinogen:

 

  • Lab pattern: MAHA + thrombocytopenia, normal PT & aPTT, normal fibrinogen.
  • Reason: TTP results from ADAMTS13 deficiency → accumulation of large vWF multimers → platelet aggregation → vessel obstruction.
  • Causes MAHA (schistocytes) and thrombocytopenia, but coagulation tests (PT & aPTT) remain normal because the coagulation cascade is not activated.
  • Fibrinogen is preserved.

 

d) Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP) → 3) Isolated thrombocytopenia with normal PT, aPTT, fibrinogen:

 

  • Lab pattern: Isolated thrombocytopenia, normal PT, aPTT, fibrinogen.
  • Reason: ITP is due to autoantibody-mediated destruction of platelets in the spleen.
  • Coagulation factors are unaffected, so PT, aPTT, and fibrinogen are normal.
  • No schistocytes because there is no microangiopathic process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • DIC: ↓ platelets, ↑ PT & aPTT, ↓ fibrinogen, ↑ D-dimer, schistocytes.
  • Hemophilia A: Isolated ↑ aPTT, normal platelets, normal fibrinogen.
  • TTP: MAHA + thrombocytopenia, normal PT/aPTT, normal fibrinogen.
  • ITP: Isolated thrombocytopenia, normal PT/aPTT, normal fibrinogen.

questions.text:
Which of the following timings are recommended for IUD insertion? 

 

  1. Within 5-7 days of menses
  2. Immediate postpartum
  3. Within 5-7 days of next menstrual cycle
  4. Within 48 hours of delivery
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2 and 4

 

  • For good acceptance and minimal expulsion risk, IUD insertion should be timed strategically:

 

Statement 1. Within 5-7 days of menses: The cervix is naturally softer and slightly dilated, making insertion easier and confirming non-pregnancy status.

 

Statement 2. Immediate postpartum: Within 10 minutes after placental delivery offers immediate contraception and high compliance.

 

Statement 4. Within 48 hours of delivery: Early postpartum insertion lowers expulsion risk compared to later postpartum attempts.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 3. Within 5-7 days of next menstrual cycle: This is not standard practice; because not sure about pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:    

 

For optimal IUD acceptance and reduced expulsion risk, insertion should be immediate postpartum, within 48 hours postpartum, or within 5-7 days of menstrual onset.

questions.text: A fetal echocardiography performed at 20 weeks’ gestation reveals abnormal morphogenesis of the third aortic arch. Based on this developmental anomaly, which vascular finding is most likely to be identified at birth?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Absent common carotid arteries

 

  • The third aortic arch in embryonic development contributes to the formation of the common carotid arteries, proximal portion of the internal carotid arteries and external carotid arteries
  • Failure in the development of the third aortic arch leads to the absence of these arteries.
  • In a fetus, such a defect is most accurately detected through detailed prenatal imaging or postnatal vascular studies. 
  • The absence of the common carotid arteries directly corresponds to abnormal development of the third aortic arch, making this the most likely vascular anomaly in the given scenario. 
  • This finding is highly specific because the third aortic arch has no significant role in forming the pulmonary trunk, the aortic arch itself, or a double aortic arch.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Double aortic arch: A double aortic arch occurs when the right dorsal aorta persists, forming a vascular ring around the trachea and esophagus. This defect is unrelated to the derivatives of the third aortic arch and instead involves anomalies of the dorsal aortic segments.

 

Option B. Absent pulmonary trunk: The pulmonary trunk develops from the truncus arteriosus and the sixth aortic arch, not the third. Its absence is associated with severe conotruncal anomalies, such as persistent truncus arteriosus, rather than defects in the third aortic arch.

 

Option D. Absent arch of aorta: The arch of the aorta develops from the fourth aortic arch and portions of the aortic sac, not the third. Absence of the aortic arch is a severe anomaly but is not expected from isolated third aortic arch defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The third aortic arch develops into the common carotid arteries and the proximal internal carotid arteries; its abnormal development results in absent common carotid arteries.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man, eight months post-allogeneic stem cell transplant, presents with increased cough and shortness of breath. He is on prolonged steroids for graft-versus-host disease and TMP-SMX for Pneumocystis prophylaxis. He is afebrile, with pulse 92/min, respiratory rate 22/min, blood pressure 122/85 mmHg, and O₂ saturation 90%. CT scan is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Invasive pulmonary aspergillosis

 

  • The presentation suggests invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (IPA) in an immunocompromised patient.
  • Post-transplant steroids increase fungal infection risk.
  • CT halo sign (nodules with ground-glass opacities) is characteristic of IPA.
  • Elevated galactomannan or 1,3 β-D glucan may support the diagnosis.
  • Treatment includes antifungals (e.g., voriconazole).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchiolitis obliterans: Chronic GVHD complication with airflow obstruction, not halo sign.

 

Option C. MRSA pneumonia: Bacterial pneumonia lacks halo sign. 

 

Option D. Respiratory syncytial virus: Causes bronchiolitis, not nodules or halo sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • IPA presents with halo sign and elevated galactomannan/1,2 β-D glucan in immunocompromised patients.
  • Post-transplant steroids increase fungal infection risk.
  • Antifungals are critical for IPA management.

choices.text: Endemic curve with high amplitude and constant baseline

questions.text: A graduate student analyzing disease trends finds that a respiratory infection has a wave-like pattern over 10 years in a region but never drops to zero. Which of the following epidemiological concepts best explains this observation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Endemic curve with high amplitude and constant baseline

 

  • An endemic disease is one that remains constantly present in a population at a predictable level.
  • Some endemics exhibit seasonal or cyclical fluctuations but maintain a baseline presence → e.g., influenza, malaria, RSV.
  • A high-amplitude endemic curve indicates periodic surges (peaks) without complete disappearance.
  • This matches the scenario described (wave-like, never dropping to zero).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Epidemic pattern with periodic resurgences: Epidemics are outbreaks above the expected level; they usually end after control. The infection here is always present → not epidemic.

 

Option C. Endemic curve representing irregular reintroductions: Implies the disease dies out locally and returns only when reintroduced. Here, the infection never dropped to zero → incorrect.

 

Option D. Sporadic pattern with occasional hyperendemicity: Sporadic = random, unpredictable, rare cases; not a regular cyclical trend.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • An endemic curve with high amplitude describes diseases that are always present in a population but fluctuate in intensity over time (seasonal or cyclical).
  • This distinguishes them from epidemics (sudden surges), sporadic cases (random), or reintroduced infections (no constant baseline).

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman at 34 weeks’ gestation presents with sudden, severe abdominal pain and mild vaginal bleeding. Examination reveals a uterine size greater than expected for gestational age, and fetal heart tones are absent on auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Concealed hemorrhage

 

  • In late pregnancy, concealed hemorrhage is a type of placental abruption in which bleeding collects behind the placenta without significant external blood loss. 
  • This results in an enlarged, tense uterus, severe abdominal pain, and, in severe cases, fetal demise (absent fetal heart sounds).
  • The uterine size greater than gestational age is due to accumulation of blood within the uterus. 
  • Because the bleeding is not visible externally, maternal vital signs may not initially reflect the extent of blood loss, but fetal compromise occurs rapidly due to interruption of placental circulation.
  • Key features pointing to concealed hemorrhage here include:
    • Acute-onset abdominal pain
    • Mild vaginal bleeding despite severe presentation
    • Uterine enlargement beyond gestational age
    • Absent fetal heart sounds (fetal demise)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterine rupture: Incorrect. Uterine rupture presents with sudden abdominal pain, loss of fetal station, and abnormal fetal heart tracings (often bradycardia) in a woman with prior uterine surgery. It is not typically associated with a tense, enlarged uterus and concealed intrauterine bleeding without rupture history.

 

Option B. Hydramnios: Incorrect. Hydramnios (polyhydramnios) is excess amniotic fluid and presents with uterine enlargement, maternal discomfort, and sometimes preterm labor, but not with acute abdominal pain, fetal demise, or concealed bleeding.

 

Option C. Active labor: Incorrect. Labor pain is associated with regular contractions, cervical changes, and reassuring fetal heart tones in a viable pregnancy. This patient’s absent fetal heart sounds and uterine size increase from blood accumulation point away from normal labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Concealed hemorrhage in placental abruption occurs when blood collects behind the placenta without significant external loss, leading to uterine enlargement, severe pain, and rapid fetal compromise.

questions.text: A couple undergoing evaluation for infertility has a semen analysis showing a high proportion of nonmotile sperm. Which of the following laboratory tests can best distinguish live but nonmotile sperm from dead sperm?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypoosmotic swelling test

 

  • The hypoosmotic swelling (HOS) test is designed to evaluate the functional integrity of the sperm plasma membrane. 
  • When sperm are placed in a hypoosmotic solution, those with intact membranes allow water to enter, leading to tail swelling or curling.
  • Live but nonmotile sperm will exhibit this swelling because their membranes remain intact.
  • Dead sperm will not swell due to compromised membranes that cannot maintain osmotic gradients.
  • This test is particularly valuable before procedures such as intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI), where selecting viable sperm is crucial for fertilization success.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. DNA fragmentation index: Incorrect. This test measures the proportion of sperm with damaged DNA, which is useful for assessing genetic integrity and predicting reproductive outcomes, but it does not differentiate between dead and live nonmotile sperm.

 

Option C. Mannose fluorescence assay: Incorrect. This evaluates the presence of mannose-binding sites on the sperm head, which relate to acrosome reaction capability. It is not used to assess sperm viability in the context of nonmotility.

 

Option D. Zona penetration assay: Incorrect. This assesses sperm’s ability to penetrate the zona pellucida of an oocyte, reflecting fertilizing capacity, but it cannot determine whether nonmotile sperm are alive or dead.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hypoosmotic swelling test is used to differentiate viable nonmotile sperm from dead sperm by assessing sperm membrane integrity through osmotic swelling.

choices.text: They are classified as neuroendocrine tumors
They are associated with MEN2A and MEN2B syndromes
They constitute about 25% of thyroid cancers
The tumor cells may secrete serotonin, ACTH, and VIP

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman is diagnosed with medullary thyroid carcinoma after presenting with a thyroid nodule and cervical lymphadenopathy. Fine-needle aspiration demonstrates amyloid deposits, and her serum calcitonin levels are elevated. Regarding medullary thyroid carcinoma, which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) They constitute about 25% of thyroid cancers

 

  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) does not account for 25% of thyroid cancers. 
  • Instead, it represents only about 5% -10 of all thyroid malignancies.
  • Overestimating its incidence is a common misconception, making this the incorrect statement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. They are classified as neuroendocrine tumors: This is correct because MTC arises from parafollicular C cells, which are neuroendocrine in origin. These tumors secrete calcitonin, which is used both diagnostically and for follow-up.

 

Option B. They are associated with MEN2A and MEN2B syndromes: This is correct as familial cases of MTC often occur in the setting of MEN2A or MEN2B syndromes, linked to RET proto-oncogene mutations. Such cases are usually bilateral and multicentric, often presenting at a younger age.

 

Option D. The tumor cells may secrete serotonin, ACTH, and VIP: This is correct because, apart from calcitonin, MTC cells may produce other hormones such as serotonin, ACTH, or VIP. Secretion of these peptides can result in systemic symptoms like diarrhea or Cushing-like features.

 

Educational Objective:


Medullary thyroid carcinoma is a rare neuroendocrine tumor derived from C cells, accounting for about 5% of thyroid cancers, often associated with MEN2 syndromes, and may secrete calcitonin along with other hormones.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with intermittent dizziness, palpitations, and shortness of breath that worsen when lying flat and improve when sitting up. On examination, she has a diastolic murmur at the apex. Echocardiogram demonstrates a mass in the left atrium, which is surgically excised. Gross pathology of the specimen is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Left atrial myxoma

 

  • Left atrial myxoma is the most common primary cardiac tumor in adults. Clinical presentation often includes positional symptoms (dyspnea, dizziness, syncope) due to obstruction of the mitral valve orifice by the tumor, which explains why symptoms worsen when lying flat and improve on sitting up. 
  • Myxomas may cause a "tumor plop" or a diastolic murmur.
  • Echocardiography reveals a pedunculated mass in the left atrium, and gross pathology confirms a gelatinous tumor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atrial septal defect (ASD): Produces fixed, wide splitting of S2 and does not cause a mass in the left atrium on echo or pathology.

 

Option C. Infective endocarditis: Characterized by vegetations on valves, not a large atrial mass. Also presents with fever and positive blood cultures, which are absent here.

 

Option D. Mitral valve prolapse: Causes a midsystolic click and late systolic murmur, not a diastolic murmur or mass lesion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Left atrial myxoma is the most common primary cardiac tumor in adults and can mimic mitral valve disease with positional symptoms due to obstruction of blood flow across the mitral valve.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with chronic alcoholism presents with confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia. Laboratory studies reveal elevated blood lactate and pyruvate levels. The physician suspects a deficiency affecting TCA cycle. All of the following cofactors and coenzymes are directly utilized in the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate 

 

  • The TCA cycle (Krebs cycle/citric acid cycle) is the central hub of cellular metabolism occurring in the mitochondrial matrix. 
  • Understanding its cofactor requirements is crucial for diagnosing metabolic disorders and vitamin deficiencies.

 

NADP is Not directly used in TCA cycle:

 

  • Primarily functions in anabolic pathways requiring reducing power (NADPH)
  • Major roles include: 
    • Fatty acid synthesis
    • Cholesterol synthesis
    • Pentose phosphate pathway
    • Glutathione reduction

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide:

 

  • Primary electron acceptor in three dehydrogenase reactions: 
    • Isocitrate dehydrogenase: Isocitrate → α-Ketoglutarate + NADH + H+
    • α-Ketoglutarate dehydrogenase: α-Ketoglutarate → Succinyl-CoA + NADH + H+
    • Malate dehydrogenase: Malate → Oxaloacetate + NADH + H+
  • Produces 3 NADH per cycle turn, contributing 7.5 ATP through oxidative phosphorylation
  • Key distinction: TCA cycle is catabolic (energy-producing) and uses NAD+, while NADP+ supports biosynthetic reactions

 

Option C. Flavin adenine dinucleotide:

 

  • Cofactor for succinate dehydrogenase (Complex II of electron transport chain)
  • Reaction: Succinate + FAD → Fumarate + FADH₂
  • Only TCA cycle reaction directly producing FADH₂ (yields 1.5 ATP)
  • Enzyme is embedded in inner mitochondrial membrane

 

Option D. Coenzyme A:

 

  • Essential for multiple reactions: 
    • Entry: Acetyl-CoA + Oxaloacetate → Citrate + CoA-SH
    • Regeneration: Succinyl-CoA → Succinate + CoA-SH
  • Also required for pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (feeding into TCA cycle)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • NADP⁺ is not involved in the TCA cycle.
  • The TCA cycle primarily requires NAD⁺, FAD, and Coenzyme A for energy production.
  • NADP⁺ supports anabolic pathways and antioxidant mechanisms, not catabolic energy-yielding cycles like TCA.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman delivers a girl child during her second pregnancy. She had registered the pregnancy in time and fulfilled all necessary criteria under PMMVY 2.0. What is the benefit she is entitled to for the second pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) ₹6000

 

 

  • PMMVY 2.0 (launched 2022 under Mission Shakti) provides maternity benefit as follows:
    • First live birth (irrespective of gender): ₹5000 in installments.
    • Second live birth (only if girl child): ₹6000, as an incentive for promoting the survival and well-being of the girl child.
  • Thus, for this woman (2nd pregnancy, girl child), she will receive ₹6000.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For the first child (any gender), the PMMVY 2.0 provides ₹5000 in two installments based on pregnancy registration, ANC, birth registration, and immunization status.
  • Under PMMVY 2.0, a second girl child is eligible for ₹6000 in a single installment if all criteria including timely registration, ANC, birth registration, and immunization are fulfilled.
  • For second pregnancies resulting in twin/triplet girls, PMMVY 2.0 provides ₹6000 per girl child if all eligibility criteria are met.

questions.text: A 32-year-old marathon runner is brought to the emergency department after collapsing during a race. Laboratory findings reveal severe hypoglycaemia (blood glucose: 35 mg/dL), elevated serum lactate, and ketosis. The physician explains that during prolonged exercise, the liver maintains blood glucose through gluconeogenesis. The complete conversion of 2 molecules of pyruvate to 1 molecule of glucose through hepatic gluconeogenesis requires:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4 ATP, 2 GTP, and 2 NADH

 

2 pyruvate → 1 glucose in liver:

 

  • Pyruvate → OAA (pyruvate carboxylase): uses 1 ATP per pyruvate → 2 ATP total
  • OAA → PEP (PEPCK): uses 1 GTP per OAA → 2 GTP total
  • 2 × 3-phosphoglycerate → 2 × 1,3-BPG (phosphoglycerate kinase): uses 1 ATP per 3-PG → 2 ATP total
  • 2 × 1,3-BPG → 2 × GAP (GAP dehydrogenase): requires 1 NADH per 1,3-BPG in the reverse direction → 2 NADH total
  • NADPH is not used in gluconeogenesis (it’s for reductive biosynthesis), so options with NADPH are incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The hepatic conversion of 2 pyruvate to 1 glucose during gluconeogenesis consumes 4 ATP, 2 GTP, and 2 NADH.
  • Understanding these energy requirements is critical in conditions involving fasting, prolonged exercise, or metabolic disorders affecting glucose homeostasis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus is being considered for therapy with a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor. He has a history of both chronic kidney disease and compensated cirrhosis. Which of the following DPP-4 inhibitors requires dose adjustment in this patient with both liver and renal impairment?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vildagliptin

 

  • Gliptins – dose should reduce in renal disease except linagliptin
  • Among the available DPP-4 inhibitors, vildagliptin is notable for requiring dose adjustment in patients who have both hepatic and renal impairment.
  • Most DPP-4 inhibitors are eliminated primarily via the kidneys, necessitating dose adjustment in renal dysfunction. 
  • Vildagliptin, however, undergoes partial hepatic metabolism, so both kidney and liver function influence its clearance and dosing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Saxagliptin: Requires dose adjustment in renal impairment but not typically in mild to moderate hepatic dysfunction.

 

Option C. Sitagliptin: Primarily excreted unchanged by the kidney; dosing is adjusted for renal function only, not liver function in most cases.

 

Option D. Linagliptin: Eliminated mostly via the enterohepatic system; no dose adjustment required in renal impairment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vildagliptin is the DPP-4 inhibitor that needs dose adjustment in patients with both renal and hepatic impairment due to its dual elimination pathways.

questions.text:
A patient has a lesion involving the facial nerve at the geniculate ganglion. Which of the following statements regarding expected clinical findings is/are incorrect? 

 

  1. Dry eye may occur due to involvement of parasympathetic fibers to the lacrimal gland.
  2. There is markedly reduced salivation, especially from the submandibular and sublingual glands.
  3. Taste sensation is diminished in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
  4. Complete loss of sensation from the posterior third of the tongue is expected.
  5. Hyperacusis can result from paralysis of the stapedius muscle.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4 only

 

  • A lesion of the facial nerve at the geniculate ganglion affects both motor and sensory fibers as well as parasympathetic secretomotor fibers. 
  • Expected features include:
    • Dry eye from loss of parasympathetic fibers to the lacrimal gland (via greater petrosal nerve). (Statement 1)
    • Reduced salivation from submandibular and sublingual glands (via chorda tympani and submandibular ganglion). (Statement 2)
    • Loss of taste from anterior two-thirds of the tongue (via chorda tympani). (Statement 3)
    • Hyperacusis from stapedius muscle paralysis. (Statement 5)
  • Loss of sensation from the posterior third of the tongue is not seen in facial nerve lesions; this area is innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX). (Statement 4)

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A lesion of the facial nerve at the geniculate ganglion can cause dry eye, reduced salivation from the submandibular and sublingual glands, loss of taste from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, and hyperacusis, but it does not cause loss of sensation from the posterior third of the tongue (glossopharyngeal nerve function).

choices.text: Whether all included studies used randomized designs
The precision of the pooled estimate for each individual study
The existence of file drawer bias
The quality of systematic review included

questions.text: A clinician is interpreting a meta-analysis that used a forest plot to assess efficacy of beta-blockers in heart failure. Which of the following insights can be directly obtained from this plot?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The precision of the pooled estimate for each individual study

 

  • A forest plot graphically displays the results of multiple studies included in a meta-analysis.

 

 

  • Each study is represented by a square (point estimate) and a horizontal line (confidence interval, CI).
  • Interpretation:
    • The width of the CI line reflects the precision of the study’s estimate (narrower CI = more precision).
    • The size of the square often represents study weight (larger sample → more influence on pooled estimate).
    • The diamond at the bottom represents the pooled effect size and its CI.
  • Thus, the forest plot allows direct assessment of the precision of each study’s estimate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Whether all included studies used randomized designs: This cannot be inferred from the forest plot itself; it requires checking study methodology.

 

Option C. The existence of file drawer bias: File drawer (publication) bias is assessed via funnel plot, not forest plot.

 

Option D. The quality of systematic review included: Forest plot does not evaluate review methodology (risk of bias, PRISMA adherence, etc.).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Forest plot → Visualizes effect size & CI → Precision and direction of effect can be judged.
  • Not shown: study design, publication bias, or overall review quality.

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R correctly explains A.
Both A and R are true, but R does not correctly explain A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Photophobia is encountered in patients with posterior subcapsular cataract.


Reason (R): Posterior subcapsular cataract produces excessive irregular scattering of light in the eye.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Both A and R are true, and R correctly explains A.

 

  • Assertion (A): True. Posterior subcapsular cataracts (PSC) are located near the nodal point of the eye and in the path of incoming light, especially affecting near vision and causing glare/photophobia (worse in bright light, e.g., daylight or while driving at night with headlights).

 

 

  • Reason (R): True. The opacities of PSC scatter light irregularly, causing glare and photophobia.

 

Does R explain A? 

 

  • Yes. The irregular scattering of light explains why patients with PSC experience photophobia and glare.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posterior subcapsular cataracts cause significant glare from irregular light scattering, and therefore typically produce true photophobia.

questions.text: A 16-year-old female presents with recurrent abdominal pain and melena. Examination shows multiple pigmented macules on the lips, buccal mucosa, and fingers. Endoscopy reveals multiple hamartomatous polyps in the stomach and small intestine. Genetic testing confirms a mutation in the STK11 gene. Which of the following complications is she at greatest risk for, in the near term?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intussusception

 

  • This patient’s presentation is consistent with Peutz–Jeghers syndrome (PJS), an autosomal dominant disorder caused by STK11 tumor suppressor gene mutation.
  • Key features: 
    • Mucocutaneous pigmentation (dark macules on lips, buccal mucosa, fingers)
    • Hamartomatous GI polyps, most often in the small intestine
  • While PJS increases lifetime cancer risk (colorectal, pancreatic, breast, gynecologic), the most common acute complication, especially in adolescence, is intussusception.
  • Large polyps can act as a lead point for telescoping of the bowel, leading to intermittent abdominal pain, GI bleeding, and possible bowel obstruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colorectal cancer: Risk is elevated over a lifetime but is not the most likely immediate complication in a 16-year-old.

 

Option B. Small bowel obstruction: Can occur in PJS but is often secondary to intussusception rather than a primary process.

 

Option D. Breast cancer: Increased lifetime risk but generally presents much later in life, not in adolescence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Peutz–Jeghers syndrome, hamartomatous polyps can serve as lead points for intussusception, making it the most common acute complication in young patients, even though the syndrome also carries significant lifetime malignancy risks.
